Question 0:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {pas} {turung} {bandara} {Sentani} {pas} {de} {ketemu} dengang Wamena dorang, pas Wamena dong ___ pinggir situ
Gloss (with missing item): precisely descend airport Sentani precisely 3SG meet with Wamena 3PL precisely Wamena 3PL ___ border L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the moment (he) landed (at) Sentani airport, he met the Wamena people, right then the Wamena people were (sitting) alongside (the airstrip) there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the locits gloss ___ion \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situits gloss ___ion: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the the morpheme ___scourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: suda	 gloss: already
B: word: tinggi	 gloss: be.high
C: word: di	 gloss: at
D: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 1:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {pas} {turung} {bandara} {Sentani} {pas} {de} {ketemu} dengang Wamena dorang, pas Wamena dong di ___ situ
Gloss (with missing item): precisely descend airport Sentani precisely 3SG meet with Wamena 3PL precisely Wamena 3PL at ___ L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the moment (he) landed (at) Sentani airport, he met the Wamena people, right then the Wamena people were (sitting) alongside (the airstrip) there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the location \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situation: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: tinggi	 gloss: be.high
B: word: pinggir	 gloss: border
C: word: pikir	 gloss: think
D: word: pagar	 gloss: fence
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 2:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {pas} {turung} {bandara} {Sentani} {pas} {de} {ketemu} dengang Wamena dorang, pas Wamena dong di pinggir ___
Gloss (with missing item): precisely descend airport Sentani precisely 3SG meet with Wamena 3PL precisely Wamena 3PL at border ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the moment (he) landed (at) Sentani airport, he met the Wamena people, right then the Wamena people were (sitting) alongside (the airstrip) there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the location \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech the morpheme ___ation: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: situ~situ	 gloss: RDP~L.MED
B: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
C: word: obat	 gloss: medicine
D: word: yang	 gloss: REL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 3:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kitorang tiga ... naik di motor ... Martina ___ tenga
Gloss (with missing item): 1PL three ... ascend at motorbike ... Martina ___ middle
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we three ... got onto the motorbike ... Martina was in the middle’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the locits gloss ___ion \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situits gloss ___ion: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the the morpheme ___scourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: di	 gloss: at
C: word: barce	 gloss: Barce
D: word: bangung	 gloss: get.up
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 4:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kitorang tiga ... naik di motor ... Martina di ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1PL three ... ascend at motorbike ... Martina at ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we three ... got onto the motorbike ... Martina was in the middle’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the location \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situation: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: tenga	 gloss: middle
B: word: stenga	 gloss: half
C: word: damay	 gloss: peace
D: word: tenga~tenga	 gloss: RDP~middle
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 6:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {pas} {turung} {bandara} {Sentani} {pas} {de} {ketemu} dengang Wamena dorang, pas Wamena dong di ___ situ
Gloss (with missing item): precisely descend airport Sentani precisely 3SG meet with Wamena 3PL precisely Wamena 3PL at ___ L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the moment (he) landed (at) Sentani airport, he met the Wamena people, right then the Wamena people were (sitting) alongside (the airstrip) there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the location \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situation: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).

B: word: pagar	 gloss: fence
C: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
D: word: pinggir	 gloss: border
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 9:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the location \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situation: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 10:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sumur itu masi ada ... ___ dalam tu ada senjata
Gloss (with missing item): well D.DIST still exist ... ___ inside D.DIST exist rifle
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that well still exists ... inside there are rifles’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the locits gloss ___ion \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situits gloss ___ion: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the the morpheme ___scourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: di	 gloss: at
C: word: bagiang	 gloss: part
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 11:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sumur itu masi ada ... di ___ tu ada senjata
Gloss (with missing item): well D.DIST still exist ... at ___ D.DIST exist rifle
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that well still exists ... inside there are rifles’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the location \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situation: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: dalam	 gloss: inside
B: word: sodara~sodara	 gloss: RDP~sibling
C: word: lagi	 gloss: again
D: word: pedalamang	 gloss: interior
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 12:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): well D.DIST still exist ... at inside ___ exist rifle
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that well still exists ... inside there are rifles’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: satu	 gloss: one
B: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
C: word: kiri	 gloss: left
D: word: tu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 14:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the location \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech situation: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).

B: word: tinggi	 gloss: be.high
C: word: pagar	 gloss: fence
D: word: sampe	 gloss: reach
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 15:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {pas} {turung} {bandara} {Sentani} {pas} {de} {ketemu} dengang Wamena dorang, pas Wamena dong di pinggir ___
Gloss (with missing item): precisely descend airport Sentani precisely 3SG meet with Wamena 3PL precisely Wamena 3PL at border ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the moment (he) landed (at) Sentani airport, he met the Wamena people, right then the Wamena people were (sitting) alongside (the airstrip) there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In the examples in (\ref{Example_5.26}) to (\ref{Example_5.36}), the ground, encoded by the adnominal \isi{noun} in \textsc{N2} position, is mentioned overtly. If the ground is understood from the context, though, the adnominal \isi{noun} denoting it can be omitted and the location \isi{noun} is used as an independent nominal as in (\ref{Example_5.37}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}). In (\ref{Example_5.37}) the ground is understood from the speech the morpheme ___ation: it is the house where the speech acts occurs. In (\ref{Example_5.38}) to (\ref{Example_5.40}) the ground is understood from the discourse: it is \textitbf{kitorang tiga} ‘we three’ in (\ref{Example_5.38}), \textitbf{sumur} ‘well’ in (\ref{Example_5.39}), and \textitbf{bandara} ‘airport’ in (\ref{Example_5.40}).
A: word: situ~situ	 gloss: RDP~L.MED
B: word: laut	 gloss: sea
C: word: obat	 gloss: medicine
D: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

A: word: ips	 gloss: social.sciences
B: word: dua	 gloss: two
C: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG

Question 22:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de kas turung mama Petrus ___ \blueboldatas kursi to?
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG give descend mother Petrus ___ top chair right?
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he (the evil spirit) threw mother Petrus from (the top of her) chair, right?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As shown so far, location nouns more fully specify the spatial relationship between a figure and the ground than is achieved by a bare \isi{preposition} that introduces the ground. If the specific spatial relationship can be deduced its gloss ___ the context, though, the location \isi{noun} can be omitted as illustrated with elided \textitbf{atas} ‘top’ in (\ref{Example_5.41}) and \textitbf{dalam} ‘inside’ in (\ref{Example_5.42}).
A: word: baik	 gloss: be.good
B: word: dari	 gloss: from
C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: cari	 gloss: search
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As shown so far, location nouns more fully specify the spatial relationship between a figure and the ground than is achieved by a bare \isi{preposition} that introduces the ground. If the specific spatial relationship can be deduced from the context, though, the location \isi{noun} can be omitted as illustrated with elided \textitbf{atas} ‘top’ in (\ref{Example_5.41}) and \textitbf{dalam} ‘inside’ in (\ref{Example_5.42}).
A: word: ber–syukur	 gloss: VBLZ\textbf{–}thank.God

Question 24:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. The English translation of this sentence is:‘they were bathing in(side of) the bathroom over there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As shown so far, locits gloss ___ion nouns more fully specify the spits gloss ___ial relits gloss ___ionship between a figure and the ground than is achieved by a bare \isi{preposition} thits gloss ___ introduces the ground. If the specific spits gloss ___ial relits gloss ___ionship can be deduced from the context, though, the locits gloss ___ion \isi{noun} can be omitted as illustrits gloss ___ed with elided \textitbf{its gloss ___as} ‘top’ in (\ref{Example_5.41}) and \textitbf{dalam} ‘inside’ in (\ref{Example_5.42}).
A: word: di	 gloss: at
B: word: siang	 gloss: day
C: word: sarmi	 gloss: Sarmi
D: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 28:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa pu prahu hanyut sampe ke ___ ini
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG POSS boat drift reach to ___ D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘my boat drifted up to the north here’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Direction nouns typically occur as complements in prepositional phrases, as shown with the four cardinal directions in (\ref{Example_5.53}) to (\ref{Example_5.56}) and the two relative directions in (\ref{Example_5.57}) and (\ref{Example_5.58}). Direction nouns can be modified with demonstratives as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ini} ‘this its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.53}) or \textitbf{kiri ini} ‘this left’ in (\ref{Example_5.57}), or with locatives as in \textitbf{slatang sana} ‘south over there’ in (\ref{Example_5.54}) or \textitbf{kanang sana} ‘right over there’ in (\ref{Example_5.58}).
A: word: barat	 gloss: west
B: word: utara	 gloss: north
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: taputar	 gloss: be.turned.around
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 34:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {ko} jalang {trus,} baru ko putar ke kanang ___
Gloss (with missing item): 2SG walk be.continuous and.then 2SG turn.around to right ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you walk on, only then you turn to the right over there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Direction nouns typically occur as complements in prepositional phrases, as shown with the four cardinal directions in (\ref{Example_5.53}) to (\ref{Example_5.56}) and the two relative directions in (\ref{Example_5.57}) and (\ref{Example_5.58}). Direction nouns can be modified with demonstratives as in \textitbf{utara ini} ‘this north’ in (\ref{Example_5.53}) or \textitbf{kiri ini} ‘this left’ in (\ref{Example_5.57}), or with locatives as in \textitbf{slatang the morpheme ___} ‘south over there’ in (\ref{Example_5.54}) or \textitbf{kanang the morpheme ___} ‘right over there’ in (\ref{Example_5.58}).
A: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
B: word: sembu	 gloss: be.healed
C: word: susana	 gloss: Susana
D: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 35:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa pu prahu hanyut sampe ke ___ ini
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG POSS boat drift reach to ___ D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘my boat drifted up to the north here’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Direction nouns typically occur as complements in prepositional phrases, as shown with the four cardinal directions in (\ref{Example_5.53}) to (\ref{Example_5.56}) and the two relative directions in (\ref{Example_5.57}) and (\ref{Example_5.58}). Direction nouns can be modified with demonstratives as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ini} ‘this its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.53}) or \textitbf{kiri ini} ‘this left’ in (\ref{Example_5.57}), or with locatives as in \textitbf{slatang sana} ‘south over there’ in (\ref{Example_5.54}) or \textitbf{kanang sana} ‘right over there’ in (\ref{Example_5.58}).
A: word: barat	 gloss: west
B: word: bukang	 gloss: NEG
C: word: taputar	 gloss: be.turned.around
D: word: utara	 gloss: north
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 43:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {pesawat} {de} {terbang} dari ___ ini, baru lewat sana trus ke Wamena
Gloss (with missing item): airplane 3SG fly from ___ D.PROX and.then pass.by L.DIST next to Wamena
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the plane flies from the left here and passes by over there (and) then (it flies on) to Wamena’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_5.57}) and (\ref{Example_5.58}) the \isi{preposition} is obligatory. With motion verbs that also express direction, however, the allative \isi{preposition} \textitbf{ke} ‘to’ may also be omitted. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.59}) with the motion \isi{verb} \textitbf{belok} ‘turn’. (For details on the \isi{elision} of prepositions encoding location, see §\ref{Para_10.1.5}.)
A: word: kiri	 gloss: left
B: word: tinggalkang	 gloss: leave
C: word: kirim	 gloss: send
D: word: oktober	 gloss: October
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 47:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): di {jembatang} {depang} {ko} {belok} Ø ___ trus di jembatang depang lagi ko belok Ø kiri
Gloss (with missing item): at bridge front 2SG turn ... ___ next at bridge front again 2SG turn ... left
The English translation of this sentence is:‘at the bridge ahead you turn right, and then at the next bridge you turn left’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_5.57}) and (\ref{Example_5.58}) the \isi{preposition} is obligatory. With motion verbs that also express direction, however, the allative \isi{preposition} \textitbf{ke} ‘to’ may also be omitted. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.59}) with the motion \isi{verb} \textitbf{belok} ‘turn’. (For details on the \isi{elision} of prepositions encoding location, see §\ref{Para_10.1.5}.)
A: word: snang	 gloss: feel.happy(.about)
B: word: sumur	 gloss: well
C: word: kanang	 gloss: right
D: word: biking	 gloss: make
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 48:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_5.57}) and (\ref{Example_5.58}) the \isi{preposition} is obligatory. With motion verbs that also express direction, however, the allative \isi{preposition} \textitbf{ke} ‘to’ may also be omitted. Question 49:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kalo ___ {barat} {itu} {kasiang} prempuang tokok prempuang ramas tapi kalo bagiang timur tida
Gloss (with missing item): if ___ west D.DIST pity woman tap woman press but if part east NEG
The English translation of this sentence is:[About regional differences within the regency:] ‘as for the western part there, (it’s a) pity, the women tap (and) the women press (the sagu) but as for the eastern part (it’s) not (like that)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their adnominal uses, the direction nouns are juxtaposed to a head nominal. Semantically, these \isi{noun} phrases designate ``subtype-of'' relations as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ barat} ‘western its gloss ___’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___ timur} ‘eastern its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.60}), or they denote \isi{locational} relations as in \textitbf{sebla kiri} ‘left side’ in (\ref{Example_5.61}), or in \textitbf{tangang kanang} ‘right hand/arm’ in (\ref{Example_5.62}).
A: word: bagi	 gloss: divide
B: word: deng	 gloss: with
C: word: bagiang	 gloss: part
D: word: utara	 gloss: north
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 50:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): if part ___ D.DIST pity woman tap woman press but if part east NEG
The English translation of this sentence is:[About regional differences within the regency:] ‘as for the western part there, (it’s a) pity, the women tap (and) the women press (the sagu) but as for the eastern part (it’s) not (like that)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their adnominal uses, the direction nouns are juxtaposed to a head nominal. Semantically, these \isi{noun} phrases designate ``subtype-of'' relations as in \textitbf{bagiang the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___ern part’ and \textitbf{bagiang timur} ‘eastern part’ in (\ref{Example_5.60}), or they denote \isi{locational} relations as in \textitbf{sebla kiri} ‘left side’ in (\ref{Example_5.61}), or in \textitbf{tangang kanang} ‘right hand/arm’ in (\ref{Example_5.62}).

B: word: pante-barat	 gloss: Pante-Barat

Question 53:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tulang yang ___ kanang ini su kluar ke samping
Gloss (with missing item): bone REL ___ right D.PROX already go.out to side
The English translation of this sentence is:[About an accident:] ‘the bone of the right arm here already stuck out sideways’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their adnominal uses, the direction nouns are juxtaposed to a head nominal. Semantically, these \isi{noun} phrases designate ``subtype-of'' relations as in \textitbf{bagiang barat} ‘western part’ and \textitbf{bagiang timur} ‘eastern part’ in (\ref{Example_5.60}), or they denote \isi{locational} relations as in \textitbf{sebla kiri} ‘left side’ in (\ref{Example_5.61}), or in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ kanang} ‘right its gloss ___/arm’ in (\ref{Example_5.62}).
A: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
B: word: tangang	 gloss: hand
C: word: jempol	 gloss: thumb
D: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 54:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): bone REL hand ___ D.PROX already go.out to side
The English translation of this sentence is:[About an accident:] ‘the bone of the right arm here already stuck out sideways’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their adnominal uses, the direction nouns are juxtaposed to a head nominal. Semantically, these \isi{noun} phrases designate ``subtype-of'' relations as in \textitbf{bagiang barat} ‘western part’ and \textitbf{bagiang timur} ‘eastern part’ in (\ref{Example_5.60}), or they denote \isi{locational} relations as in \textitbf{sebla kiri} ‘left side’ in (\ref{Example_5.61}), or in \textitbf{tangang the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___ hand/arm’ in (\ref{Example_5.62}).
A: word: bertriak	 gloss: scream
B: word: snang	 gloss: feel.happy(.about)
C: word: kanang	 gloss: right

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 55:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): brapa bulang dorang skola ka mace, ___ bulang ka?
Gloss (with missing item): several month 3.PL go.to.school or woman ___ month or
The English translation of this sentence is:‘for how many months have they been going to school, Madam, for five months, right?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The time units listed in \tabref{Table_5.6} are count nouns that can be modified with numerals or quantifiers, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.63}) and (\ref{Example_5.64}). In addition to designating a \isi{time unit}, \textitbf{minggu} ‘week’ also denotes a day of the week, namely ‘Sunday’ (see \tabref{Table_5.8} ).
A: word: enam	 gloss: six
B: word: lima~lima	 gloss: RDP~five
C: word: ceritra	 gloss: tell
D: word: lima	 gloss: five
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 57:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): saya hanya bisa makang, kasi makang dorang ___ malam saja
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG only be.able eat give eat 3PL ___ night just
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I can only eat, feed them just one night’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four periods-of-the-day expressions are count nouns that can be modified with numerals or quantifiers, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.66}) and (\ref{Example_5.67}). In addition, these expressions are also used as modifiers within \isi{noun} phrases, as in (\ref{Example_5.68}) to (\ref{Example_5.70}).
A: word: satu~satu	 gloss: RDP~one
B: word: dulu	 gloss: first
C: word: satu	 gloss: one
D: word: apa	 gloss: what
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 66:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ kitong datang lagi, dong kasi makang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 1PL come again 3PL give eat
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a youth retreat:] ‘in the morning, we came again, they fed (us)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Within the clause, the four expressions typically occur at clause boundaries. Most often, they occur in clause-initial position where they set the temporal stage for the entire clause. Alternatively, although less often, the temporal expressions occur in clause-final position, where they are less prominent. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.71}) to (\ref{Example_5.74}) with near contrastive examples. The time expression \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs in clause-initial position in (\ref{Example_5.71}) and in clause-final position in (\ref{Example_5.72}). Likewise, \textitbf{malam} ‘night’ occurs in clause-initial position in (\ref{Example_5.73}) and in clause-final position in (\ref{Example_5.74}).
A: word: malam	 gloss: night
B: word: pagi	 gloss: morning
C: word: pagi~pagi	 gloss: RDP~morning
D: word: siapa	 gloss: who
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 67:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): precisely father pray ___ D.DIST morning 3SG die
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(my) father prayed that evening, and right away in the morning he (the boy) died’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Within the clause, the four expressions typically occur at clause boundaries. Most often, they occur in clause-initial position where they set the temporal stage for the entire clause. Alternatively, although less often, the temporal expressions occur in clause-final position, where they are less prominent. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.71}) to (\ref{Example_5.74}) with near contrastive examples. The time expression \textitbf{pagi} ‘morning’ occurs in clause-initial position in (\ref{Example_5.71}) and in clause-final position in (\ref{Example_5.72}). Likewise, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs in clause-initial position in (\ref{Example_5.73}) and in clause-final position in (\ref{Example_5.74}).

B: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
C: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
D: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 74:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): slamat ___ pak
Gloss (with missing item): be.safe ___ father
The English translation of this sentence is:‘good morning Sir’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The periods-of-the-day expressions are also used in greetings, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.75}) to (\ref{Example_5.78}).
A: word: pagi~pagi	 gloss: RDP~morning
B: word: desa	 gloss: village
C: word: jam	 gloss: hour
D: word: pagi	 gloss: morning
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 76:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): yo bapa, ___ minggu sa datang
Gloss (with missing item): yes father ___ Sunday 1SG come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes father, on Sunday I’ll come’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the its gloss ___s of the week and the months of the year occur in \textsc{n1n2} \isi{noun} phrases, headed by the common nouns \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ and \textitbf{bulang} ‘month’, respectively (see \tabref{Table_5.6}; see also §\ref{Para_8.2.2}). Examples for the its gloss ___s of the week are given in (\ref{Example_5.79}) and (\ref{Example_5.80}) and for the months of the year in (\ref{Example_5.81}). Occasionally, however, speakers omit \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ or \textitbf{bulang} ‘month’ as with \textitbf{rabu} ‘Wednesits gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.80}) and with \textitbf{oktober} ‘October’ and \textitbf{januari} ‘January’ in (\ref{Example_5.82}), respectively.
A: word: sore	 gloss: afternoon
B: word: hari	 gloss: day
C: word: empat	 gloss: four
D: word: mata-hari	 gloss: sun
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 77:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): yo bapa, hari ___ sa datang
Gloss (with missing item): yes father day ___ 1SG come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes father, on Sunday I’ll come’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the days of the week and the months of the year occur in \textsc{n1n2} \isi{noun} phrases, headed by the common nouns \textitbf{hari} ‘day’ and \textitbf{bulang} ‘month’, respectively (see \tabref{Table_5.6}; see also §\ref{Para_8.2.2}). Examples for the days of the week are given in (\ref{Example_5.79}) and (\ref{Example_5.80}) and for the months of the year in (\ref{Example_5.81}). Occasionally, however, speakers omit \textitbf{hari} ‘day’ or \textitbf{bulang} ‘month’ as with \textitbf{rabu} ‘Wednesday’ in (\ref{Example_5.80}) and with \textitbf{oktober} ‘October’ and \textitbf{januari} ‘January’ in (\ref{Example_5.82}), respectively.
A: word: minggu	 gloss: Sunday
B: word: singgung	 gloss: offend
C: word: malam	 gloss: night
D: word: slasa	 gloss: Tuesday
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 78:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Sentence (with missing item): ___ slasa {itu} ... {de} pu ana prempuang meninggal jadi tong tinggal di ruma sampe rabu

The English translation of this sentence is:‘that Monday ... his daughter died, so we stayed at home until Wednesday’

A: word: akirnya	 gloss: finally
B: word: hari	 gloss: day
C: word: sore	 gloss: afternoon
D: word: mata-hari	 gloss: sun
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 81:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the days of the week and the its gloss ___s of the year occur in \textsc{n1n2} \isi{noun} phrases, headed by the common nouns \textitbf{hari} ‘day’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, respectively (see \tabref{Table_5.6}; see also §\ref{Para_8.2.2}). B: word: tiga~tiga	 gloss: RDP~three
C: word: taung	 gloss: year
D: word: pulang	 gloss: go.home
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 86:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): o nanti ___ e januari baru kitong antar
Gloss (with missing item): oh! very.soon ___ uh January and.then 1PL bring
The English translation of this sentence is:[About wedding customs:] ‘oh later in October uh January, and then we’ll bring (our daughter to your house)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the days of the week and the months of the year occur in \textsc{n1n2} \isi{noun} phrases, headed by the common nouns \textitbf{hari} ‘day’ and \textitbf{bulang} ‘month’, respectively (see \tabref{Table_5.6}; see also §\ref{Para_8.2.2}). A: word: bulang	 gloss: month
B: word: paling	 gloss: most
C: word: oktofina	 gloss: Oktofina
D: word: oktober	 gloss: October
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 87:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, the days of the week and the months of the year occur in \textsc{n1n2} \isi{noun} phrases, headed by the common nouns \textitbf{hari} ‘day’ and \textitbf{bulang} ‘month’, respectively (see \tabref{Table_5.6}; see also §\ref{Para_8.2.2}). Question 88:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kalo ___ de {itu} hadir ke sana tu biking de sperti bos
Gloss (with missing item): if ___ 3SG D.DIST attend to L.DIST D.DIST make 3SG similar.to boss
The English translation of this sentence is:[About an event planned for the next year:] ‘if next year he (the mayor), what’s-its-name, (comes and) attends (the retreat) over there, treat him like a boss’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Within the clause, the relative-time denoting expressions typically occur in clause-initial position. Here they set the temporal stage for the entire clause, similar to the nouns denoting periods of the day, discussed in §\ref{Para_5.2.5.2}. This is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.83}) to (\ref{Example_5.85}). Alternatively, but less often, the relative-time expressions directly precede the predicate where they are less prominent, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.86}). The contrast in meaning conveyed by the different positions within the clause is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the near contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.85}) and (\ref{Example_5.86}). By fronting \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.85}), the speaker accentuates the temporal setting of the entire clause. This is not the case in (\ref{Example_5.86}), where \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ directly precedes the predicate, where it is less salient.
A: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
B: word: besok	 gloss: tomorrow
C: word: kemaring	 gloss: yesterday
D: word: baku	 gloss: RECP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 89:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): bapa nanti ___ hadir di ini retrit pemuda
Gloss (with missing item): father very.soon ___ attend at D.PROX retreat youth
The English translation of this sentence is:[About an event planned for the next year:] ‘you (‘father’) (have to) attend, what’s-its-name, the youth retreat next year’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Within the clause, the relative-time denoting expressions typically occur in clause-initial position. Here they set the temporal stage for the entire clause, similar to the nouns denoting periods of the day, discussed in §\ref{Para_5.2.5.2}. This is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.83}) to (\ref{Example_5.85}). Alternatively, but less often, the relative-time expressions directly precede the predicate where they are less prominent, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.86}). The contrast in meaning conveyed by the different positions within the clause is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the near contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.85}) and (\ref{Example_5.86}). By fronting \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.85}), the speaker accentuates the temporal setting of the entire clause. This is not the case in (\ref{Example_5.86}), where \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ directly precedes the predicate, where it is less salient.
A: word: besok	 gloss: tomorrow
B: word: kemaring	 gloss: yesterday
C: word: kadang	 gloss: sometimes
D: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 90:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kalo ___ de {itu} hadir ke sana tu biking de sperti bos
Gloss (with missing item): if ___ 3SG D.DIST attend to L.DIST D.DIST make 3SG similar.to boss
The English translation of this sentence is:[About an event planned for the next year:] ‘if next year he (the mayor), what’s-its-name, (comes and) attends (the retreat) over there, treat him like a boss’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Within the clause, the relative-time denoting expressions typically occur in clause-initial position. Here they set the temporal stage for the entire clause, similar to the nouns denoting periods of the day, discussed in §\ref{Para_5.2.5.2}. This is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.83}) to (\ref{Example_5.85}). Alternatively, but less often, the relative-time expressions directly precede the predicate where they are less prominent, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.86}). The contrast in meaning conveyed by the different positions within the clause is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the near contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.85}) and (\ref{Example_5.86}). By fronting \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.85}), the speaker accentuates the temporal setting of the entire clause. This is not the case in (\ref{Example_5.86}), where \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ directly precedes the predicate, where it is less salient.
A: word: besok	 gloss: tomorrow
B: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
C: word: badang	 gloss: body
D: word: kemaring	 gloss: yesterday
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 91:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): bapa nanti ___ hadir di ini retrit pemuda
Gloss (with missing item): father very.soon ___ attend at D.PROX retreat youth
The English translation of this sentence is:[About an event planned for the next year:] ‘you (‘father’) (have to) attend, what’s-its-name, the youth retreat next year’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Within the clause, the relative-time denoting expressions typically occur in clause-initial position. Here they set the temporal stage for the entire clause, similar to the nouns denoting periods of the day, discussed in §\ref{Para_5.2.5.2}. This is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.83}) to (\ref{Example_5.85}). Alternatively, but less often, the relative-time expressions directly precede the predicate where they are less prominent, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.86}). The contrast in meaning conveyed by the different positions within the clause is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the near contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.85}) and (\ref{Example_5.86}). By fronting \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.85}), the speaker accentuates the temporal setting of the entire clause. This is not the case in (\ref{Example_5.86}), where \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ directly precedes the predicate, where it is less salient.
A: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
B: word: suda	 gloss: already
C: word: besok	 gloss: tomorrow
D: word: kemaring	 gloss: yesterday
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 92:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): if ___ 3SG D.DIST attend to L.DIST D.DIST make 3SG similar.to boss

Question 94:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kalo ___ de {itu} hadir ke sana tu biking de sperti bos
Gloss (with missing item): if ___ 3SG D.DIST attend to L.DIST D.DIST make 3SG similar.to boss
The English translation of this sentence is:[About an event planned for the next year:] ‘if next year he (the mayor), what’s-its-name, (comes and) attends (the retreat) over there, treat him like a boss’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The examples in (\ref{Example_5.83}) and (\ref{Example_5.85}) also illustrate that the temporal scope of \textitbf{kemaring} ‘yesterday’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is larger than the preceding or following 24-hour period, respectively. Generally speaking \textitbf{kemaring} ‘yesterday’ denotes a past point in time such as \textitbf{kemaring} ‘some time ago’ in (\ref{Example_5.83}). Along similar lines, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ refers to a future point in time which in (\ref{Example_5.85}) is \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘next year’.
A: word: kemaring	 gloss: yesterday
B: word: besok	 gloss: tomorrow
C: word: pace	 gloss: man
D: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 96:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): yo memang ___ minggu besok sa datang
Gloss (with missing item): yes indeed ___ Sunday tomorrow 1SG come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes, indeed, next Sunday I’ll come’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Like other nouns, relative-time denoting nouns also have adnominal uses as shown in (\ref{Example_5.88}) and (\ref{Example_5.89}). In their adnominal uses, they occur in posthead position and have restrictive function. That is, they specify whether the period or point in time encoded by the head nominal is situated in the future or in the past, as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ minggu besok} ‘next Sunits gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.88}) or \textitbf{taung kemaring} ‘a few years back’ in (\ref{Example_5.89}).
A: word: sembu	 gloss: be.healed
B: word: sore	 gloss: afternoon
C: word: mata-hari	 gloss: sun
D: word: hari	 gloss: day
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 97:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): yo memang hari ___ besok sa datang
Gloss (with missing item): yes indeed day ___ tomorrow 1SG come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes, indeed, next Sunday I’ll come’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Like other nouns, relative-time denoting nouns also have adnominal uses as shown in (\ref{Example_5.88}) and (\ref{Example_5.89}). In their adnominal uses, they occur in posthead position and have restrictive function. That is, they specify whether the period or point in time encoded by the head nominal is situated in the future or in the past, as in \textitbf{hari the morpheme ___ besok} ‘next its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.88}) or \textitbf{taung kemaring} ‘a few years back’ in (\ref{Example_5.89}).
A: word: pinggir	 gloss: border
B: word: singgung	 gloss: offend
C: word: minggu	 gloss: Sunday
D: word: slasa	 gloss: Tuesday
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 99:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {banyak} {mati} di {lautang} kas tenggelam sampe ___ kemaring taung ... dua ribu dua
Gloss (with missing item): many die at ocean give sink until ___ yesterday year ... two thousand two
The English translation of this sentence is:[About people in a container who died in the ocean:] ‘many died in the (open) ocean, (the murderers) sank (the containers), (many died in the open ocean) until a few years back, (until) the year 2002’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Like other nouns, relative-time denoting nouns also have adnominal uses as shown in (\ref{Example_5.88}) and (\ref{Example_5.89}). In their adnominal uses, they occur in posthead position and have restrictive function. That is, they specify whether the period or point in time encoded by the head nominal is situated in the future or in the past, as in \textitbf{hari minggu besok} ‘next Sunday’ in (\ref{Example_5.88}) or \textitbf{the morpheme ___ kemaring} ‘a few its gloss ___s back’ in (\ref{Example_5.89}).
A: word: satu~satu	 gloss: RDP~one
B: word: ulang-taung	 gloss: birthday
C: word: bulang	 gloss: month
D: word: taung	 gloss: year
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 105:

That is, they specify whether the period or point in time encoded by the head nominal is situated in the future or in the past, as in \textitbf{hari minggu besok} ‘next Sunday’ in (\ref{Example_5.88}) or \textitbf{taung the morpheme ___} ‘a few years back’ in (\ref{Example_5.89}).

Question 106:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa minum lagi trus sa tinggal ___ besok
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG drink again next 1SG stay ___ tomorrow
The English translation of this sentence is:[About recovering from an accident:] ‘I took (medicine) again, then I stayed until the next day’ (Lit. ‘until tomorrow’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Relative-time expressions also occur as complements in prepositional phrases as, for instance, in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ besok} ‘its gloss ___ the next day’ (literally ‘its gloss ___ tomorrow’) in (\ref{Example_5.90}). This example also illustrates that \textitbf{besok} ‘tomorrow’ denotes \isi{relative time}. As the events described here happened in the past, \textitbf{besok} ‘tomorrow’ refers to a future point in time relative to the narrated events. Hence, \textitbf{besok} translates as ‘the next day’. (Prepositions encoding time are discussed in more detail in §\ref{Para_10.1}.)
A: word: sampeee	 gloss: reach
B: word: sampe	 gloss: until
C: word: sodara	 gloss: sibling
D: word: biking	 gloss: make
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 107:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa minum lagi trus sa tinggal sampe ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG drink again next 1SG stay until ___
The English translation of this sentence is:[About recovering from an accident:] ‘I took (medicine) again, then I stayed until the next day’ (Lit. ‘until tomorrow’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Relative-time expressions also occur as complements in prepositional phrases as, for instance, in \textitbf{sampe the morpheme ___} ‘until the next day’ (literally ‘until its gloss ___’) in (\ref{Example_5.90}). This example also illustrates that \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ denotes \isi{relative time}. As the events described here happened in the past, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ refers to a future point in time relative to the narrated events. Hence, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} translates as ‘the next day’. (Prepositions encoding time are discussed in more detail in §\ref{Para_10.1}.)
A: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
B: word: kemaring	 gloss: yesterday
C: word: bagiang	 gloss: part
D: word: besok	 gloss: tomorrow
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 108:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong {dua} {dapat} {ikang} {ini} ___ ekor dapat ikang tiga ekor dong dua ...
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL two get fish D.PROX ___ tail get fish three tail 3PL two ...
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of them get these fish, three (of them), having gotten three fish, the two of them ...’ (Lit. ‘three tails’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay has a very reduced inventory of classifying nouns. Attested is only one, namely the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{ekor} ‘tail’ which is used to count animals. In this function, it always follows a posthead \isi{numeral}, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.91}).
A: word: tiga~tiga	 gloss: RDP~three
B: word: tiga	 gloss: three
C: word: baru	 gloss: and.then
D: word: snek	 gloss: snack
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 109:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong {dua} {dapat} {ikang} {ini} {tiga} ___ dapat ikang tiga ekor dong dua ...
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL two get fish D.PROX three ___ get fish three tail 3PL two ...
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the two of them get these fish, three (of them), having gotten three fish, the two of them ...’ (Lit. ‘three tails’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay has a very reduced inventory of classifying nouns. Attested is only one, namely the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ which is used to count animals. In this function, it always follows a posthead \isi{numeral}, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.91}).
A: word: kor	 gloss: choir
B: word: kepala	 gloss: head
C: word: ekor	 gloss: tail
D: word: kali	 gloss: river
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 121:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dia ___ kitong daging
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG ___ 1PL meat
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he gave us (fish) meat’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Trivalent verbs have three core arguments, that is, a subject and two grammatical objects. This is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.94}). It is important to note, however, that the attested \isi{trivalent} verbs allow but do not require three syntactic arguments. (For details, see §\ref{Para_11.1.3}.)
A: word: kasi	 gloss: give
B: word: kasi–ang	 gloss: love–PAT
C: word: blum	 gloss: not.yet
D: word: siap	 gloss: provide
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 122:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): bapa de ___ sa deng pisow
Gloss (with missing item): father 3SG ___ 1SG with knife
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(my) husband hit me with a knife’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Bivalent verbs have two core arguments, a subject and one grammatical object. This is shown with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.95}) and \textitbf{mara} ‘feel angry (about)’ in (\ref{Example_5.96}). Bivalent verbs also allow, but do not require two syntactic arguments. (For details see §\ref{Para_11.1.2}.)
A: word: kulit	 gloss: skin
B: word: pukul	 gloss: hit
C: word: blas	 gloss: teens
D: word: tabrak	 gloss: hit.against
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

This is shown with \textitbf{pukul} ‘hit’ in (\ref{Example_5.95}) and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘feel angry (about)’ in (\ref{Example_5.96}). Bivalent verbs also allow, but do not require two syntactic arguments. (For details see §\ref{Para_11.1.2}.)
A: word: lipat	 gloss: fold

Question 124:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Nofita de ___ dari saya
Gloss (with missing item): Nofita 3SG ___ from 1SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Nofita ran (away) from me’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Monovalent verbs have only one core argument. They are further divided into dynamic and stative verbs. Dynamic verbs such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.97}) denote actions involving one participant, while stative verbs, such as \textitbf{besar} ‘be big’ or \textitbf{kecil} ‘be small’ in (\ref{Example_5.98}), express states or more time-stable properties.
A: word: lari	 gloss: run
B: word: balap	 gloss: race
C: word: lari~lari	 gloss: RDP~run
D: word: dua	 gloss: two
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 125:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:‘(his) head here is big but (his) body here is small’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Monovalent verbs have only one core argument. They are further divided into dynamic and stative verbs. Dynamic verbs such as \textitbf{lari} ‘run’ in (\ref{Example_5.97}) denote actions involving one participant, while stative verbs, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be big’ or \textitbf{kecil} ‘be small’ in (\ref{Example_5.98}), express states or more time-stable properties.
A: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
B: word: brat	 gloss: be.heavy

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Monovalent verbs have only one core argument. They are further divided into dynamic and stative verbs. Dynamic verbs such as \textitbf{lari} ‘run’ in (\ref{Example_5.97}) denote actions involving one participant, while stative verbs, such as \textitbf{besar} ‘be big’ or \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be small’ in (\ref{Example_5.98}), express states or more time-stable properties.

Question 127:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): bapa Iskia dong ___ babi
Gloss (with missing item): father Iskia 3PL ___ pig
The English translation of this sentence is:‘father Iskia and his companions killed a pig’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, verbs act “as ‘comment’ on a given \isi{noun} as ‘topic’”, using Dixon’s (\citeyear*[31]{Dixon.1994}) terminology. This typical function of dynamic verbs is demonstrated with \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.99}). The predicative use of \isi{monovalent} stative verbs is illustrated with \textitbf{tinggi} ‘be high’ in (\ref{Example_5.100}). In the corpus, all dynamic verbs have \isi{predicative function}, while only 40% of the stative verbs (139/351) are used predicatively.
A: word: bagiang	 gloss: part
B: word: bunuuu	 gloss: kill
C: word: meninggal	 gloss: die
D: word: bunu	 gloss: kill
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

This typical function of dynamic verbs is demonstrated with \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{bunu} ‘kill’ in (\ref{Example_5.99}). The predicative use of \isi{monovalent} stative verbs is illustrated with \textitbf{tinggi} ‘be high’ in (\ref{Example_5.100}). In the corpus, all dynamic verbs have \isi{predicative function}, while only 40% of the stative verbs (139/351) are used predicatively.

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, verbs act “as ‘comment’ on a given \isi{noun} as ‘topic’”, using Dixon’s (\citeyear*[31]{Dixon.1994}) terminology. This typical function of dynamic verbs is demonstrated with \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{bunu} ‘kill’ in (\ref{Example_5.99}). The predicative use of \isi{monovalent} stative verbs is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be high’ in (\ref{Example_5.100}).
