Question 130:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de ada potong ikang ___ besar di pante
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG exist cut fish ___ be.big at coast
The English translation of this sentence is:‘at the beach he was cutting up a fish that was big’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their \isi{attributive function} within \isi{noun} phrases, the modifying verbs serve to specify or restrict “the reference of the \isi{noun}”, in Dixon’s (\citeyear*[31]{Dixon.1994}) terminology. Cross-linguistically, this is achieved in one of two ways, as \citet{Dixon.1994} points out. One option is verb-via-\isi{juxtaposition} \isi{modification}; that is, the modifying \isi{verb} is directly juxtaposed to a \isi{noun} in a \isi{noun} phrase. The second option is “verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification}” {\citep[19]{Dixon.2004b}; that is, \isi{modification} is achieved by means of a relative clause. }Papuan Malay also makes use of these two options, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.101}) to (\ref{Example_5.105})
A: word: sayang	 gloss: love
B: word: yang	 gloss: REL
C: word: adat	 gloss: tradition
D: word: baku	 gloss: RECP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 131:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de ada potong ikang yang ___ di pante
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG exist cut fish REL ___ at coast
The English translation of this sentence is:‘at the beach he was cutting up a fish that was big’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their \isi{attributive function} within \isi{noun} phrases, the modifying verbs serve to specify or restrict “the reference of the \isi{noun}”, in Dixon’s (\citeyear*[31]{Dixon.1994}) terminology. Cross-linguistically, this is achieved in one of two ways, as \citet{Dixon.1994} points out. One option is verb-via-\isi{juxtaposition} \isi{modification}; that is, the modifying \isi{verb} is directly juxtaposed to a \isi{noun} in a \isi{noun} phrase. The second option is “verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification}” {\citep[19]{Dixon.2004b}; that is, \isi{modification} is achieved by means of a relative clause. }Papuan Malay also makes use of these two options, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.101}) to (\ref{Example_5.105})
A: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
B: word: ambil	 gloss: fetch
C: word: brat	 gloss: be.heavy
D: word: besar~besar	 gloss: RDP~be.big
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 132:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ojek ___ bawa tete tu su pulang
Gloss (with missing item): motorbike.taxi ___ bring grandfather D.DIST already go.home
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that motorbike taxi driver who brought grandfather has already returned home’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The second option of modifying nouns within a \isi{noun} phrase is by placing the \isi{verb} within a relative clause, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.102}) to (\ref{Example_5.105}). This verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification} typically applies to dynamic verbs, such as (monotransitively used) \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{bawa} ‘bring’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.102}), \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{kawing} ‘marry unofficially’ in (\ref{Example_5.103}), or \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{tinggal} ‘stay’ in (\ref{Example_5.104}).
A: word: sayang	 gloss: love
B: word: oktober	 gloss: October
C: word: yang	 gloss: REL
D: word: baku	 gloss: RECP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 138:

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The second option of modifying nouns within a \isi{noun} phrase is by placing the \isi{verb} within a relative clause, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.102}) to (\ref{Example_5.105}). This verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification} typically applies to dynamic verbs, such as (monotransitively used) \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{bawa} ‘bring’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.102}), \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{kawing} ‘marry unofficially’ in (\ref{Example_5.103}), or \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{tinggal} ‘stay’ in (\ref{Example_5.104}).

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The second option of modifying nouns within a \isi{noun} phrase is by placing the \isi{verb} within a relative clause, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.102}) to (\ref{Example_5.105}). This verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification} typically applies to dynamic verbs, such as (monotransitively used) \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{bawa} ‘bring’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.102}), \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{kawing} ‘marry unofficially’ in (\ref{Example_5.103}), or \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.104}).

Question 140:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de ada potong ikang ___ besar di pante
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG exist cut fish ___ be.big at coast
The English translation of this sentence is:‘at the beach he was cutting up a fish that was big’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: All \isi{verb} types can be used attributively. However, when comparing the attested attributively used \isi{verb} tokens across the two types of \isi{noun} phrase \isi{modification}, a clear pattern emerges, shown in \tabref{Table_5.16}. The vast majority of attributively used \isi{monovalent} stative verbs occur in \isi{noun} phrases involving verb-via-juxtapos\-ition \isi{modification}, although stative verbs also occur in verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification}, such as \textitbf{besar} ‘be big’ in (\ref{Example_5.105}). The vast majority of attributively used dynamic verbs, by contrast, occur in \isi{noun} phrases involving verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification}. Cross-linguistically these preferences are rather common \citep[31]{Dixon.1994}.
A: word: yang	 gloss: REL
B: word: bunu	 gloss: kill
C: word: sayang	 gloss: love
D: word: baku	 gloss: RECP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 141:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de ada potong ikang yang ___ di pante
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG exist cut fish REL ___ at coast
The English translation of this sentence is:‘at the beach he was cutting up a fish that was big’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: All \isi{verb} types can be used attributively. However, when comparing the attested attributively used \isi{verb} tokens across the two types of \isi{noun} phrase \isi{modification}, a clear pattern emerges, shown in \tabref{Table_5.16}. The vast majority of attributively used \isi{monovalent} stative verbs occur in \isi{noun} phrases involving verb-via-juxtapos\-ition \isi{modification}, although stative verbs also occur in verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification}, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be big’ in (\ref{Example_5.105}). The vast majority of attributively used dynamic verbs, by contrast, occur in \isi{noun} phrases involving verb-via-relative-clause \isi{modification}. Cross-linguistically these preferences are rather common \citep[31]{Dixon.1994}.
A: word: besar~besar	 gloss: RDP~be.big
B: word: brat	 gloss: be.heavy
C: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
D: word: hanya	 gloss: only
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 142:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): pace dong ___ kasi dia senter
Gloss (with missing item): man 3PL ___ give 3SG flashlight
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the men immediately gave him a flashlight’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, tri-, bi-, and \isi{monovalent} verbs can be modified with adverbs, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.106}) to (\ref{Example_5.113}). In (\ref{Example_5.106}) to (\ref{Example_5.109}), the temporal ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ modifies \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’, \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{tanya} ‘ask’, \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{pulang} ‘go home’, and stative \textitbf{basa} ‘be wet’, respectively; the example in (\ref{Example_5.106}) is elicited.
A: word: langsung	 gloss: immediately
B: word: natanael	 gloss: Natanael
C: word: sungay	 gloss: river
D: word: suda	 gloss: already
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 149:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): bapa langsung ___
Gloss (with missing item): father immediately ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the gentleman was immediately quiet’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, tri-, bi-, and \isi{monovalent} verbs can be modified with adverbs, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.106}) to (\ref{Example_5.113}). In (\ref{Example_5.106}) to (\ref{Example_5.109}), the temporal ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{langsung} ‘immediately’ modifies \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’, \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{tanya} ‘ask’, \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{pulang} ‘go home’, and stative \textitbf{basa} ‘be wet’, respectively; the example in (\ref{Example_5.106}) is elicited.
A: word: perna	 gloss: ever
B: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: diam	 gloss: be.quiet
D: word: bisu	 gloss: be.mute
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 150:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): pace dong ___ kasi dia senter
Gloss (with missing item): man 3PL ___ give 3SG flashlight
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the men immediately gave him a flashlight’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, tri-, bi-, and \isi{monovalent} verbs can be modified with adverbs, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.106}) to (\ref{Example_5.113}). In (\ref{Example_5.106}) to (\ref{Example_5.109}), the temporal ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ modifies \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’, \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{tanya} ‘ask’, \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{pulang} ‘go home’, and stative \textitbf{basa} ‘be wet’, respectively; the example in (\ref{Example_5.106}) is elicited.
A: word: sungay	 gloss: river
B: word: langsung	 gloss: immediately
C: word: murit	 gloss: pupil
D: word: suda	 gloss: already
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

In (\ref{Example_5.106}) to (\ref{Example_5.109}), the temporal ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{langsung} ‘immediately’ modifies \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{tanya} ‘ask’, \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{pulang} ‘go home’, and stative \textitbf{basa} ‘be wet’, respectively; the example in (\ref{Example_5.106}) is elicited.

Question 152:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Dodo ___ Agus air lagi
Gloss (with missing item): Dodo ___ Agus water again
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Dodo fetched water for Agus again’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Along similar lines, frequency ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, also’ modifies the verbs in (\ref{Example_5.110}) to (\ref{Example_5.113}); the example in (\ref{Example_5.110}) is elicited. (For more details on adverbs see §\ref{Para_5.4}.)
A: word: saing	 gloss: compete
B: word: ambil	 gloss: fetch
C: word: bilang	 gloss: say
D: word: kembali	 gloss: return
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 154:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The English translation of this sentence is:‘[it goes on like that] for maybe two years before (the situation gets) lively again’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Along similar lines, frequency ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, also’ modifies the verbs in (\ref{Example_5.110}) to (\ref{Example_5.113}); the example in (\ref{Example_5.110}) is elicited. (For more details on adverbs see §\ref{Para_5.4}.)
A: word: besar	 gloss: be.big

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 158:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa ___ skali dong pu cara masak
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG ___ very 3PL POSS manner cook
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I very (much) enjoy their way of cooking’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, \isi{monovalent} stative and \isi{bivalent} verbs can be intensified with the degree adverbs \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ or \textitbf{terlalu} ‘too’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.114}) to (\ref{Example_5.117}). While \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ follows the \isi{verb} as in (\ref{Example_5.114}) and (\ref{Example_5.115}), \textitbf{terlalu} ‘too’ precedes it as in (\ref{Example_5.116}) and (\ref{Example_5.117}). Intensification of predicatively used \isi{monovalent} dynamic and \isi{trivalent} verbs is unattested in the corpus. Furthermore, \isi{intensification} of attributively used verbs is unattested. (For details on degree adverbs see §\ref{Para_5.4.7}.)
A: word: pinang	 gloss: betel.nut
B: word: kedua	 gloss: second
C: word: snang	 gloss: feel.happy(.about)
D: word: herang	 gloss: feel.surprised(.about)
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 159:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa snang ___ dong pu cara masak
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG feel.happy(.about) ___ 3PL POSS manner cook
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I very (much) enjoy their way of cooking’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, \isi{monovalent} stative and \isi{bivalent} verbs can be intensified with the degree adverbs \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ or \textitbf{terlalu} ‘too’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.114}) to (\ref{Example_5.117}). While \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ follows the \isi{verb} as in (\ref{Example_5.114}) and (\ref{Example_5.115}), \textitbf{terlalu} ‘too’ precedes it as in (\ref{Example_5.116}) and (\ref{Example_5.117}). Intensification of predicatively used \isi{monovalent} dynamic and \isi{trivalent} verbs is unattested in the corpus. Furthermore, \isi{intensification} of attributively used verbs is unattested. (For details on degree adverbs see §\ref{Para_5.4.7}.)
A: word: kali	 gloss: river
B: word: barat	 gloss: west
C: word: skali	 gloss: very
D: word: jadi	 gloss: so
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 168:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): 1SG see mother ___ be.good

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, \isi{monovalent} stative and \isi{bivalent} verbs can be intensified with the degree adverbs \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ or \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘too’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.114}) to (\ref{Example_5.117}). While \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ follows the \isi{verb} as in (\ref{Example_5.114}) and (\ref{Example_5.115}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘too’ precedes it as in (\ref{Example_5.116}) and (\ref{Example_5.117}). (For details on degree adverbs see §\ref{Para_5.4.7}.)
A: word: damay	 gloss: peace
B: word: terbuka	 gloss: be.opened
C: word: terlalu	 gloss: exceedingly
D: word: lari~lari	 gloss: RDP~run
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 169:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa liat mama terlalu ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG see mother exceedingly ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I see you (‘mother’) are too good’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, \isi{monovalent} stative and \isi{bivalent} verbs can be intensified with the degree adverbs \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ or \textitbf{terlalu} ‘too’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.114}) to (\ref{Example_5.117}). While \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ follows the \isi{verb} as in (\ref{Example_5.114}) and (\ref{Example_5.115}), \textitbf{terlalu} ‘too’ precedes it as in (\ref{Example_5.116}) and (\ref{Example_5.117}). Intensification of predicatively used \isi{monovalent} dynamic and \isi{trivalent} verbs is unattested in the corpus. Furthermore, \isi{intensification} of attributively used verbs is unattested. (For details on degree adverbs see §\ref{Para_5.4.7}.)
A: word: minyak	 gloss: oil
B: word: enak	 gloss: be.pleasant
C: word: baik	 gloss: be.good
D: word: ke–baik–ang	 gloss: NMLZ–be.good–NMLZ
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 170:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Dodo de ___ banyak tidor
Gloss (with missing item): Dodo 3SG ___ many sleep
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Dodo sleeps too much’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As mentioned, \isi{intensification} of \isi{monovalent} dynamic verbs is unattested in the corpus. According to one consultant, though, it is possible to intensify them with the expressions \textitbf{the morpheme ___ banyak} ‘its gloss ___ much’ or \textitbf{the morpheme ___ sedikit} ‘its gloss ___ little’, as in the elicited examples in (\ref{Example_5.118}) and (\ref{Example_5.119}).
A: word: terbuka	 gloss: be.opened
B: word: sumur	 gloss: well
C: word: terlalu	 gloss: too
D: word: pasti	 gloss: definitely
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 176:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {prahu} {ini} pu ukurang ___ lari dari ukurang yang ko kasi
Gloss (with missing item): boat D.PROX POSS measurement ___ run from measurement REL 2SG give
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the size of this boat deviates too much from the size that you gave’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In addition, one of the consultants came up with the two examples in (\ref{Example_5.120}) and (\ref{Example_5.121}), respectively, in which dynamic \textitbf{lari} ‘run’ and \textitbf{tunduk} ‘bow’ are directly modified with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’. In (\ref{Example_5.120}), however, \textitbf{lari} means ‘deviate’ rather than ‘run’, and \textitbf{tunduk} ‘bow’ in (\ref{Example_5.121}) receives the stative reading ‘be obedient’.
A: word: apa	 gloss: what
B: word: terlalu	 gloss: too
C: word: sumur	 gloss: well
D: word: terbuka	 gloss: be.opened
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 184:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): a, dong mala ___ sayang saya
Gloss (with missing item): ah! 3PL in.fact ___ love 1SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘ah, they actually loved me more’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their predicative uses, \isi{monovalent} stative and \isi{bivalent} verbs can occur with \isi{grading} adverbs, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.122}) to (\ref{Example_5.125}), whereas \isi{grading} of \isi{monovalent} dynamic and \isi{trivalent} verbs is unattested. The comparative degree is marked with the \isi{grading} ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ and the superlative degree with \textitbf{paling} ‘most’; both adverbs precede the \isi{verb}. (For details on degree adverbs see §\ref{Para_5.4.7}; for details on comparative clauses see §\ref{Para_11.5}.)
A: word: baik	 gloss: be.good
B: word: juga	 gloss: also
C: word: kebiasaang	 gloss: habit
D: word: lebi	 gloss: more
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

The comparative degree is marked with the \isi{grading} ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{lebi} ‘more’ and the superlative degree with \textitbf{paling} ‘most’; both adverbs precede the \isi{verb}. Question 189:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): a, dong mala lebi ___ saya
Gloss (with missing item): ah! 3PL in.fact more ___ 1SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘ah, they actually loved me more’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: ‘ah, they actually \bluebold{its gloss ___d} me \bluebold{more}’ \textstyleExampleSource{[Elicited BR130221.034]}\footnote{The elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.122}) is the corrected version of the original recording \textitbf{dong mana lebi the morpheme ___ saya} ‘they actually[\textsc{spm}] its gloss ___d me more’ [081110-008-NPHt.0021]. That is, the speaker mispronounced \textitbf{mala} ‘in.fact’, realizing it as \textitbf{mana}.}
A: word: sembayang	 gloss: worship
B: word: sayang	 gloss: love
C: word: kasi–ang	 gloss: love–PAT
D: word: lebi	 gloss: more
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 190:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Dodo ___ banyak bertriak dari Agus
Gloss (with missing item): Dodo ___ many scream with Agus
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Dodo screams more than Agus’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Again, \isi{monovalent} dynamic verbs differ from \isi{monovalent} stative and \isi{bivalent} verbs in that they are not directly modified with a \isi{grading} ad\isi{verb}. Instead they are modified with \textitbf{the morpheme ___ banyak} ‘(do s.th.) its gloss ___’ to indicate comparative degree, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.126}), or with \textitbf{paling banyak} ‘(do s.th.) most’ to indicate superlative degree, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.127}).
A: word: lebi	 gloss: more
B: word: kebiasaang	 gloss: habit
C: word: juga	 gloss: also
D: word: stenga	 gloss: half
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 196:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kaka su bilang de begitu, sa ___ kasi ko jempol
Gloss (with missing item): oSb already say 3SG like.that 1SG ___ give 2SG thumb
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I (‘older sibling’) already told him like that, ``I won’t give you a thumbs up'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Verbs are negated with \textitbf{tida} ‘\textsc{neg}’ or \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg}’.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.155}The negator \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ also occurs in verbal clauses. However, it does not negate the \isi{verb} as \textitbf{tida/the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg}’ does. Instead, \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ has scope over the entire proposition and expresses conthe morpheme ___stive \isi{negation} of that proposition as a whole (for details see §\ref{Para_13.1.2}).} This is demonsthe morpheme ___ted with \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’ in (\ref{Example_5.128}), \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{pake} ‘use’ in (\ref{Example_5.129}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{datang} ‘come’ in (\ref{Example_5.130}), and \isi{monovalent} stative \textitbf{baik} ‘be good’ in (\ref{Example_5.131}). These examples also illusthe morpheme ___te that both negators are used interchangeably (for more details on \isi{negation} see §\ref{Para_13.1}).
A: word: baru	 gloss: and.then
B: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
C: word: ceritrakang	 gloss: tell
D: word: tra	 gloss: NEG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 197:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kaka su bilang de begitu, sa tra ___ ko jempol
Gloss (with missing item): oSb already say 3SG like.that 1SG NEG ___ 2SG thumb
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I (‘older sibling’) already told him like that, ``I won’t give you a thumbs up'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Verbs are negated with \textitbf{tida} ‘\textsc{neg}’ or \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.155}The negator \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ also occurs in verbal clauses. However, it does not negate the \isi{verb} as \textitbf{tida/tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ does. Instead, \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ has scope over the entire proposition and expresses contrastive \isi{negation} of that proposition as a whole (for details see §\ref{Para_13.1.2}).} This is demonstrated with \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.128}), \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{pake} ‘use’ in (\ref{Example_5.129}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{datang} ‘come’ in (\ref{Example_5.130}), and \isi{monovalent} stative \textitbf{baik} ‘be good’ in (\ref{Example_5.131}). These examples also illustrate that both negators are used interchangeably (for more details on \isi{negation} see §\ref{Para_13.1}).
A: word: kasi	 gloss: give
B: word: siap	 gloss: provide
C: word: kasi–ang	 gloss: love–PAT
D: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 198:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kalo saya berburu ___ pake anjing malam hari saya kluar
Gloss (with missing item): if 1SG hunt ___ use dog night day 1SG go.out
The English translation of this sentence is:‘if I hunt without taking dogs, I leave at night’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Verbs are negated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg}’ or \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.155}The negator \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ also occurs in verbal clauses. However, it does not negate the \isi{verb} as \textitbf{the morpheme ___/tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ does. Instead, \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ has scope over the entire proposition and expresses contrastive \isi{negation} of that proposition as a whole (for details see §\ref{Para_13.1.2}).} This is demonstrated with \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’ in (\ref{Example_5.128}), \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{pake} ‘use’ in (\ref{Example_5.129}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{datang} ‘come’ in (\ref{Example_5.130}), and \isi{monovalent} stative \textitbf{baik} ‘be good’ in (\ref{Example_5.131}). These examples also illustrate that both negators are used interchangeably (for more details on \isi{negation} see §\ref{Para_13.1}).
A: word: kedua	 gloss: second
B: word: sidaq	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: tida	 gloss: NEG
D: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 201:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de tra datang ... de ___ datang
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG NEG come ... 3SG ___ come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘she did not come ... she did not come’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Verbs are negated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg}’ or \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.155}The negator \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ also occurs in verbal clauses. However, it does not negate the \isi{verb} as \textitbf{the morpheme ___/tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ does. Instead, \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ has scope over the entire proposition and expresses contrastive \isi{negation} of that proposition as a whole (for details see §\ref{Para_13.1.2}).} This is demonstrated with \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’ in (\ref{Example_5.128}), \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{pake} ‘use’ in (\ref{Example_5.129}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{datang} ‘come’ in (\ref{Example_5.130}), and \isi{monovalent} stative \textitbf{baik} ‘be good’ in (\ref{Example_5.131}). These examples also illustrate that both negators are used interchangeably (for more details on \isi{negation} see §\ref{Para_13.1}).
A: word: sidaq	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: ade	 gloss: LIG
C: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
D: word: tida	 gloss: NEG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 203:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Verbs are negated with \textitbf{tida} ‘\textsc{neg}’ or \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.155}The negator \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ also occurs in verbal clauses. Question 204:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong ___ masuk korek di sini
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL ___ enter matches at L.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they inserted matches here’ (Lit. ‘give to enter’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Causative constructions with \textitbf{the morpheme ___i} ‘its gloss ___’ are presented in (\ref{Example_5.132}) to (\ref{Example_5.134}). The V\textsubscript{2} is \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{masuk} ‘enter’ in (\ref{Example_5.132}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{bangung} ‘wake up’ in (\ref{Example_5.133}), and stative \textitbf{sembu} ‘be healed’ in (\ref{Example_5.134}). (For more details on \textitbf{the morpheme ___i}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}.)
A: word: siap	 gloss: provide
B: word: glas	 gloss: glass
C: word: kas	 gloss: give
D: word: kasi	 gloss: give
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 205:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): 3PL give ___ matches at L.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they inserted matches here’ (Lit. ‘give to enter’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Causative constructions with \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’ are presented in (\ref{Example_5.132}) to (\ref{Example_5.134}). The V\textsubscript{2} is \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.132}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{bangung} ‘wake up’ in (\ref{Example_5.133}), and stative \textitbf{sembu} ‘be healed’ in (\ref{Example_5.134}). (For more details on \textitbf{kasi}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}.)
A: word: masuk	 gloss: enter
B: word: pusing	 gloss: be.dizzy
C: word: dapat	 gloss: get
D: word: mas-kawing	 gloss: bride.price
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 206:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ko ___ sembu sa punya ana ini
Gloss (with missing item): 2SG ___ be.healed 1SG POSS child D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[Addressing an evil spirit:] ‘you heal this child of mine!’ (Lit ‘give to be healed’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Causative constructions with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ are presented in (\ref{Example_5.132}) to (\ref{Example_5.134}). The V\textsubscript{2} is \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{masuk} ‘enter’ in (\ref{Example_5.132}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{bangung} ‘wake up’ in (\ref{Example_5.133}), and stative \textitbf{sembu} ‘be healed’ in (\ref{Example_5.134}). (For more details on \textitbf{the morpheme ___}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}.)
A: word: kasi	 gloss: give
B: word: siap	 gloss: provide
C: word: bawa	 gloss: bring
D: word: kasi–ang	 gloss: love–PAT
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 207:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ko kasi ___ sa punya ana ini
Gloss (with missing item): 2SG give ___ 1SG POSS child D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[Addressing an evil spirit:] ‘you heal this child of mine!’ (Lit ‘give to be healed’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Causative constructions with \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’ are presented in (\ref{Example_5.132}) to (\ref{Example_5.134}). The V\textsubscript{2} is \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{masuk} ‘enter’ in (\ref{Example_5.132}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{bangung} ‘wake up’ in (\ref{Example_5.133}), and stative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be healed’ in (\ref{Example_5.134}). (For more details on \textitbf{kasi}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}.)
A: word: kesembuang	 gloss: recovery
B: word: sembu	 gloss: be.healed
C: word: cuma	 gloss: just
D: word: lega	 gloss: be.relieved
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 208:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong ___ masuk korek di sini
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL ___ enter matches at L.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they inserted matches here’ (Lit. ‘give to enter’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Causative constructions with \textitbf{the morpheme ___i} ‘its gloss ___’ are presented in (\ref{Example_5.132}) to (\ref{Example_5.134}). The V\textsubscript{2} is \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{masuk} ‘enter’ in (\ref{Example_5.132}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{bangung} ‘wake up’ in (\ref{Example_5.133}), and stative \textitbf{sembu} ‘be healed’ in (\ref{Example_5.134}). (For more details on \textitbf{the morpheme ___i}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}.)
A: word: kas	 gloss: give
B: word: siap	 gloss: provide
C: word: sedikit~sedikit	 gloss: RDP~few
D: word: kasi	 gloss: give
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 209:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong kas ___ korek di sini
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL give ___ matches at L.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they inserted matches here’ (Lit. ‘give to enter’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Causative constructions with \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’ are presented in (\ref{Example_5.132}) to (\ref{Example_5.134}). The V\textsubscript{2} is \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.132}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{bangung} ‘wake up’ in (\ref{Example_5.133}), and stative \textitbf{sembu} ‘be healed’ in (\ref{Example_5.134}). (For more details on \textitbf{kasi}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}.)
A: word: dapat	 gloss: get
B: word: blas	 gloss: teens
C: word: masuk	 gloss: enter
D: word: mas-kawing	 gloss: bride.price
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 210:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa takut skali jadi sa ___ bangung mama
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG feel.afraid(.of) very so 1SG ___ wake.up mother
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I felt very afraid, so I woke up you (‘mother’)’ (Lit. ‘give to wake up’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Causative constructions with \textitbf{the morpheme ___i} ‘its gloss ___’ are presented in (\ref{Example_5.132}) to (\ref{Example_5.134}). The V\textsubscript{2} is \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{masuk} ‘enter’ in (\ref{Example_5.132}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{bangung} ‘wake up’ in (\ref{Example_5.133}), and stative \textitbf{sembu} ‘be healed’ in (\ref{Example_5.134}). (For more details on \textitbf{the morpheme ___i}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}.)
A: word: barat	 gloss: west
B: word: kas	 gloss: give
C: word: siap	 gloss: provide
D: word: kasi	 gloss: give
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 211:

Question 213:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. The V\textsubscript{2} is \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{masuk} ‘enter’ in (\ref{Example_5.132}), \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{bangung} ‘wake up’ in (\ref{Example_5.133}), and stative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be healed’ in (\ref{Example_5.134}). Question 214:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): yo, dong dua deng Wili tu ___ pusing mama
Gloss (with missing item): yes 3PL two with Wili D.DIST ___ be.dizzy mother
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes!, he and Wili there worried (their) mother’ (Lit. ‘make to be dizzy/confused’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In causatives with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, the V\textsubscript{2} is always \isi{monovalent}. Most often, the \isi{monovalent} \isi{verb} is stative, such as \textitbf{pusing} ‘be dizzy, be confused’ in (\ref{Example_5.135}). However, \textitbf{the morpheme ___}{}-causatives can also be formed with non-agentive dynamic bases, such as \textitbf{tenggelam} ‘sink’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.136}). If the causee is inanimate, or animate but helpless, the base can also be agentive dynamic, such as \textitbf{hidup} ‘live’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.137}). (For more details on \textitbf{the morpheme ___}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.3}; see also examples (\ref{Example_11.55}) and (\ref{Example_11.57}) in §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_11.55}.)
A: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
B: word: yang	 gloss: REL
C: word: taru	 gloss: put
D: word: biking	 gloss: make
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 215:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): yo, dong dua deng Wili tu biking ___ mama
Gloss (with missing item): yes 3PL two with Wili D.DIST make ___ mother
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes!, he and Wili there worried (their) mother’ (Lit. ‘make to be dizzy/confused’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In causatives with \textitbf{biking} ‘make’, the V\textsubscript{2} is always \isi{monovalent}. Most often, the \isi{monovalent} \isi{verb} is stative, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be dizzy, be confused’ in (\ref{Example_5.135}). However, \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives can also be formed with non-agentive dynamic bases, such as \textitbf{tenggelam} ‘sink’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.136}). If the causee is inanimate, or animate but helpless, the base can also be agentive dynamic, such as \textitbf{hidup} ‘live’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.137}). (For more details on \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.3}; see also examples (\ref{Example_11.55}) and (\ref{Example_11.57}) in §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_11.55}.)
A: word: singkong	 gloss: cassava
B: word: tertawa	 gloss: laugh
C: word: pusing	 gloss: be.dizzy
D: word: sakit	 gloss: be.sick
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 216:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): banyak mati di lautang, ___ tenggelam
Gloss (with missing item): many die at ocean ___ sink
The English translation of this sentence is:[About people in a container who died in the ocean:] ‘many died in the (open) ocean, (the murderers) sank (the containers)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In causatives with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, the V\textsubscript{2} is always \isi{monovalent}. Most often, the \isi{monovalent} \isi{verb} is stative, such as \textitbf{pusing} ‘be dizzy, be confused’ in (\ref{Example_5.135}). However, \textitbf{the morpheme ___}{}-causatives can also be formed with non-agentive dynamic bases, such as \textitbf{tenggelam} ‘sink’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.136}). If the causee is inanimate, or animate but helpless, the base can also be agentive dynamic, such as \textitbf{hidup} ‘live’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.137}). (For more details on \textitbf{the morpheme ___}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.3}; see also examples (\ref{Example_11.55}) and (\ref{Example_11.57}) in §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_11.55}.)
A: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
B: word: biking	 gloss: make
C: word: taru	 gloss: put
D: word: smua	 gloss: all
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 217:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): banyak mati di lautang, biking ___
Gloss (with missing item): many die at ocean make ___
The English translation of this sentence is:[About people in a container who died in the ocean:] ‘many died in the (open) ocean, (the murderers) sank (the containers)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In causatives with \textitbf{biking} ‘make’, the V\textsubscript{2} is always \isi{monovalent}. Most often, the \isi{monovalent} \isi{verb} is stative, such as \textitbf{pusing} ‘be dizzy, be confused’ in (\ref{Example_5.135}). However, \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives can also be formed with non-agentive dynamic bases, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.136}). If the causee is inanimate, or animate but helpless, the base can also be agentive dynamic, such as \textitbf{hidup} ‘live’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.137}). (For more details on \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.3}; see also examples (\ref{Example_11.55}) and (\ref{Example_11.57}) in §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_11.55}.)
A: word: senggi	 gloss: Senggi
B: word: badang	 gloss: body
C: word: tenggelam	 gloss: sink
D: word: cuci	 gloss: wash
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 218:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tapi dong ___ bangkit dia lagi, biking hidup dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... but 3PL ___ be.resurrected 3SG again make live 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:[About sorcerers who can resurrect the dead:] ‘[he’s already (dead),] but they resurrect him again, make him live’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In causatives with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, the V\textsubscript{2} is always \isi{monovalent}. Most often, the \isi{monovalent} \isi{verb} is stative, such as \textitbf{pusing} ‘be dizzy, be confused’ in (\ref{Example_5.135}). However, \textitbf{the morpheme ___}{}-causatives can also be formed with non-agentive dynamic bases, such as \textitbf{tenggelam} ‘sink’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.136}). If the causee is inanimate, or animate but helpless, the base can also be agentive dynamic, such as \textitbf{hidup} ‘live’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.137}). (For more details on \textitbf{the morpheme ___}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.3}; see also examples (\ref{Example_11.55}) and (\ref{Example_11.57}) in §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_11.55}.)
A: word: ceritra	 gloss: tell
B: word: biking	 gloss: make
C: word: taru	 gloss: put
D: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 220:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tapi dong biking bangkit dia lagi, biking ___ dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... but 3PL make be.resurrected 3SG again make ___ 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:[About sorcerers who can resurrect the dead:] ‘[he’s already (dead),] but they resurrect him again, make him live’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In causatives with \textitbf{biking} ‘make’, the V\textsubscript{2} is always \isi{monovalent}. Most often, the \isi{monovalent} \isi{verb} is stative, such as \textitbf{pusing} ‘be dizzy, be confused’ in (\ref{Example_5.135}). However, \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives can also be formed with non-agentive dynamic bases, such as \textitbf{tenggelam} ‘sink’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.136}). If the causee is inanimate, or animate but helpless, the base can also be agentive dynamic, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.137}). (For more details on \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.3}; see also examples (\ref{Example_11.55}) and (\ref{Example_11.57}) in §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_11.55}.)
A: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
B: word: tinggal	 gloss: stay
C: word: baru	 gloss: and.then
D: word: hidup	 gloss: live
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 221:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tapi dong kasi bangkit dia lagi, ___ hidup dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... but 3PL give be.resurrected 3SG again ___ live 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:[About sorcerers who can resurrect the dead:] ‘[he’s already (dead),] but they resurrect him again, make him live’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In causatives with \textitbf{biking} ‘make’, the V\textsubscript{2} is always \isi{monovalent}. Most often, the \isi{monovalent} \isi{verb} is stative, such as \textitbf{pusing} ‘be dizzy, be confused’ in (\ref{Example_5.135}). However, \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives can also be formed with non-agentive dynamic bases, such as \textitbf{tenggelam} ‘sink’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.136}). If the causee is inanimate, or animate but helpless, the base can also be agentive dynamic, such as \textitbf{hidup} ‘live’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.137}). (For more details on \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.3}; see also examples (\ref{Example_11.55}) and (\ref{Example_11.57}) in §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_11.55}.)
A: word: kasi	 gloss: give
B: word: laut	 gloss: sea
C: word: siap	 gloss: provide
D: word: kasi–ang	 gloss: love–PAT
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 222:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tapi dong kasi bangkit dia lagi, kasi ___ dia
Gloss (with missing item): ... but 3PL give be.resurrected 3SG again give ___ 3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:[About sorcerers who can resurrect the dead:] ‘[he’s already (dead),] but they resurrect him again, make him live’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In causatives with \textitbf{biking} ‘make’, the V\textsubscript{2} is always \isi{monovalent}. Most often, the \isi{monovalent} \isi{verb} is stative, such as \textitbf{pusing} ‘be dizzy, be confused’ in (\ref{Example_5.135}). However, \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives can also be formed with non-agentive dynamic bases, such as \textitbf{tenggelam} ‘sink’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.136}). If the causee is inanimate, or animate but helpless, the base can also be agentive dynamic, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.137}). (For more details on \textitbf{biking}{}-causatives, see §\ref{Para_11.2.1.3}; see also examples (\ref{Example_11.55}) and (\ref{Example_11.57}) in §\ref{Para_11.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_11.55}.)
A: word: hidup	 gloss: live
B: word: tinggal	 gloss: stay
C: word: kas	 gloss: give
D: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 223:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Markus deng Yan dong ___ ceritra
Gloss (with missing item): Markus with Yan 3PL ___ tell
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Markus and Yan were talking to each other’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Verbs can occur in reciprocal constructions in which the \isi{reciprocity marker} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{recp}’ precedes the \isi{verb} (for more details on reciprocal constructions, see §\ref{Para_11.3}). This is illustrated with \isi{trivalent} \textitbf{ceritra} ‘tell’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.138}), \isi{bivalent} \textitbf{gendong} ‘hold’ in (\ref{Example_5.139}), and \isi{monovalent} dynamic \textitbf{saing} ‘compete’ in (\ref{Example_5.140}). Reciprocal constructions with \isi{monovalent} stative verbs are unattested.
A: word: ayung	 gloss: hit
B: word: baku~baku	 gloss: RDP~RECP
C: word: baku	 gloss: RECP
D: word: besok	 gloss: tomorrow
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 233:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): a, mama ___ mandi, mama masi bangung tidor
Gloss (with missing item): ah! mother ___ bathe mother still wake.up sleep
The English translation of this sentence is:‘ah, I (‘mother’) have not yet bathed, I (‘mother’) am still waking up’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The three adverbs always occur in prepredicate position, as shown in \tabref{Table_5.24}. This applies to their uses in verbal clauses, as in (\ref{Example_5.141}) and (\ref{Example_5.142}), and in nonverbal clauses, as in (\ref{Example_5.145}) to (\ref{Example_5.147}). Likewise, adverbially used \textitbf{ada} ‘exist’ precedes the predicate, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.143}), (\ref{Example_5.144}), and (\ref{Example_5.148}).
A: word: masi	 gloss: still
B: word: seblum	 gloss: before
C: word: blum	 gloss: not.yet
D: word: alpa	 gloss: be.absent
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 242:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): a, mama ___ mandi, mama masi bangung tidor
Gloss (with missing item): ah! mother ___ bathe mother still wake.up sleep
The English translation of this sentence is:‘ah, I (‘mother’) have not yet bathed, I (‘mother’) am still waking up’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In verbal predicate clauses, the aspectual adverbs and adverbially used \textitbf{ada} ‘exist’ modify dynamic verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.141}) and (\ref{Example_5.143}), or stative verbs as in (\ref{Example_5.142}) and (\ref{Example_5.144}).
A: word: alpa	 gloss: be.absent
B: word: seblum	 gloss: before
C: word: blum	 gloss: not.yet
D: word: hampir	 gloss: almost
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 243:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): a, mama blum mandi, mama ___ bangung tidor
Gloss (with missing item): ah! mother not.yet bathe mother ___ wake.up sleep
The English translation of this sentence is:‘ah, I (‘mother’) have not yet bathed, I (‘mother’) am still waking up’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In verbal predicate clauses, the aspectual adverbs and adverbially used \textitbf{ada} ‘exist’ modify dynamic verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.141}) and (\ref{Example_5.143}), or stative verbs as in (\ref{Example_5.142}) and (\ref{Example_5.144}).
A: word: kali	 gloss: river
B: word: kasi	 gloss: give
C: word: masi	 gloss: still
D: word: lanjut	 gloss: continue
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 244:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): 1SG POSS wife ___ sleep because day not.yet day
The English translation of this sentence is:‘my wife was sleeping because it wasn’t daylight yet’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In verbal predicate clauses, the aspectual adverbs and adverbially used \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ modify dynamic verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.141}) and (\ref{Example_5.143}), or stative verbs as in (\ref{Example_5.142}) and (\ref{Example_5.144}).

Question 248:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. The English translation of this sentence is:[About traveling by high or low tide:] ‘that is not yet the wavy season, you know’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The examples in (\ref{Example_5.145}) to (\ref{Example_5.148}) demonstrate the uses of the aspectual adverbs and adverbially used \textitbf{ada} ‘exist’ in nonverbal predicate clauses. (An alternative analysis of clauses with \textitbf{ada} ‘exist’, such as the one in (\ref{Example_5.148}), is presented in §\ref{Para_11.4.1}.)
A: word: bukang	 gloss: NEG
B: word: seblum	 gloss: before
C: word: blum	 gloss: not.yet
D: word: alpa	 gloss: be.absent
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 251:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): yo, de ___ terlalu, ini, egois
Gloss (with missing item): yes 3SG ___ too D.PROX be.egoistic
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes, she’s sometimes too, what’s-its-name, egoistic’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the frequency adverbs is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.149}) to (\ref{Example_5.152}). The adverbs can directly precede the predicate, such as \textitbf{kadang{\Tilde}kadang} ‘sometimes’ in (\ref{Example_5.149}) or \textitbf{perna} ‘ever’ in (\ref{Example_5.151}), or they can precede the subject, such as \textitbf{kadang({\Tilde}kadang)} ‘sometimes’ in (\ref{Example_5.150}) or \textitbf{perna} ‘ever’ in (\ref{Example_5.152}). These examples also show that frequency adverbs not only modify verbal predicates as in (\ref{Example_5.149}) to (\ref{Example_5.151}), but also nonverbal predicates as in (\ref{Example_5.152}). The semantics conveyed by the different positions have to do with scope.
A: word: kadang	 gloss: sometimes
B: word: sring~sring	 gloss: RDP~often
C: word: kadang~kadang	 gloss: RDP~sometimes
D: word: sakit	 gloss: be.sick
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 252:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ___ kitong dua di apa kantor Golkar
Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ 1PL two at what office Golkar
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[so I and, what’s-his-name, Noferus here,] once the two of us were at, what-is-it, the Golkar office’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the frequency adverbs is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.149}) to (\ref{Example_5.152}). The adverbs can directly precede the predicate, such as \textitbf{kadang{\Tilde}kadang} ‘sometimes’ in (\ref{Example_5.149}) or \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.151}), or they can precede the subject, such as \textitbf{kadang({\Tilde}kadang)} ‘sometimes’ in (\ref{Example_5.150}) or \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.152}). These examples also show that frequency adverbs not only modify verbal predicates as in (\ref{Example_5.149}) to (\ref{Example_5.151}), but also nonverbal predicates as in (\ref{Example_5.152}). The semantics conveyed by the different positions have to do with scope.
A: word: taw~taw	 gloss: RDP~know
B: word: tiap	 gloss: every
C: word: perna	 gloss: ever
D: word: pernikaang	 gloss: marriage
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 255:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ sa sa buang bola sama Wili deng Klara to?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 1SG 1SG discard ball to Wili with Klara right?
The English translation of this sentence is:‘sometimes I, I threw the ball to Wili and Klara, right?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the frequency adverbs is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.149}) to (\ref{Example_5.152}). The adverbs can directly precede the predicate, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___{\Tilde}the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.149}) or \textitbf{perna} ‘ever’ in (\ref{Example_5.151}), or they can precede the subject, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___({\Tilde}the morpheme ___)} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.150}) or \textitbf{perna} ‘ever’ in (\ref{Example_5.152}). These examples also show that frequency adverbs not only modify verbal predicates as in (\ref{Example_5.149}) to (\ref{Example_5.151}), but also nonverbal predicates as in (\ref{Example_5.152}). The semantics conveyed by the different positions have to do with scope.
A: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
B: word: tenga	 gloss: middle
C: word: kadang~kadang	 gloss: RDP~sometimes
D: word: kadang	 gloss: sometimes
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 259:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): ... ___ 1PL two at what office Golkar
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[so I and, what’s-his-name, Noferus here,] once the two of us were at, what-is-it, the Golkar office’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the frequency adverbs is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.149}) to (\ref{Example_5.152}). The adverbs can directly precede the predicate, such as \textitbf{kadang{\Tilde}kadang} ‘sometimes’ in (\ref{Example_5.149}) or \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.151}), or they can precede the subject, such as \textitbf{kadang({\Tilde}kadang)} ‘sometimes’ in (\ref{Example_5.150}) or \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.152}). These examples also show that frequency adverbs not only modify verbal predicates as in (\ref{Example_5.149}) to (\ref{Example_5.151}), but also nonverbal predicates as in (\ref{Example_5.152}). B: word: pernikaang	 gloss: marriage
