Question 260:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ tikus de loncat ke klapa lagi
Gloss (with missing item): ___ rat 3SG jump to coconut again
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes, the rat also jumped over to the coconut tree’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four adverbs always take a prepredicate position. Affirmative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is always fronted, while the negative and \isi{prohibitive} adverbs directly precede the predicate. Affirmative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is often realized as \textitbf{ya}, and negative \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ is quite commonly shortened to \textitbf{jang}. Examples are provided in (\ref{Example_5.153}) to (\ref{Example_5.156}): \isi{affirmation} with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.153}), \isi{negation} with interchangeably used \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ and \textitbf{tida} ‘\textsc{neg}’ in (\ref{Example_5.154}), and with \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\ref{Example_5.155}), and prohibition with \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ in (\ref{Example_5.156}). Negation and prohibition are discussed in more detail in §\ref{Para_13.1} and §\ref{Para_13.3.3}, respectively.
A: word: yo	 gloss: yes
B: word: yoram	 gloss: Yoram
C: word: lutut	 gloss: knee
D: word: malam	 gloss: night
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 261:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Nofi ___ ganggu kaka, ade tu, e?
Gloss (with missing item): Nofi ___ disturb oSb ySb D.DIST e?
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Nofi don’t bother that older relative, younger relative, eh?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four adverbs always take a prepredicate position. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is always fronted, while the negative and \isi{prohibitive} adverbs directly precede the predicate. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is often realized as \textitbf{ya}, and negative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ is quite commonly shortened to \textitbf{jang}. Examples are provided in (\ref{Example_5.153}) to (\ref{Example_5.156}): \isi{affirmation} with \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ in (\ref{Example_5.153}), \isi{negation} with interchangeably used \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ and \textitbf{tida} ‘\textsc{neg}’ in (\ref{Example_5.154}), and with \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\ref{Example_5.155}), and prohibition with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ in (\ref{Example_5.156}). Negation and prohibition are discussed in more detail in §\ref{Para_13.1} and §\ref{Para_13.3.3}, respectively.
A: word: jangang~jangang	 gloss: RDP~NEG.IMP
B: word: kapang	 gloss: when
C: word: tida	 gloss: NEG
D: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 262:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ tikus de loncat ke klapa lagi
Gloss (with missing item): ___ rat 3SG jump to coconut again
The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes, the rat also jumped over to the coconut tree’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four adverbs always take a prepredicate position. Affirmative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is always fronted, while the negative and \isi{prohibitive} adverbs directly precede the predicate. Affirmative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is often realized as \textitbf{ya}, and negative \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ is quite commonly shortened to \textitbf{jang}. Examples are provided in (\ref{Example_5.153}) to (\ref{Example_5.156}): \isi{affirmation} with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.153}), \isi{negation} with interchangeably used \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ and \textitbf{tida} ‘\textsc{neg}’ in (\ref{Example_5.154}), and with \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\ref{Example_5.155}), and prohibition with \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ in (\ref{Example_5.156}). Negation and prohibition are discussed in more detail in §\ref{Para_13.1} and §\ref{Para_13.3.3}, respectively.
A: word: lobe	 gloss: walk.searchingly.with.lamp
B: word: yoram	 gloss: Yoram
C: word: yo	 gloss: yes
D: word: pukul	 gloss: hit
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 263:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de ___ datang ... de tida datang
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG ___ come ... 3SG NEG come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘she did not come ... she did not come’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four adverbs always take a prepredicate position. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is always fronted, while the negative and \isi{prohibitive} adverbs directly precede the predicate. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is often realized as \textitbf{ya}, and negative \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ is quite commonly shortened to \textitbf{jang}. Examples are provided in (\ref{Example_5.153}) to (\ref{Example_5.156}): \isi{affirmation} with \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ in (\ref{Example_5.153}), \isi{negation} with interchangeably used \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg}’ and \textitbf{tida} ‘\textsc{neg}’ in (\ref{Example_5.154}), and with \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\ref{Example_5.155}), and prohibition with \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ in (\ref{Example_5.156}). Negation and prohibition are discussed in more detail in §\ref{Para_13.1} and §\ref{Para_13.3.3}, respectively.
A: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
B: word: langsung	 gloss: immediately
C: word: ceritrakang	 gloss: tell
D: word: tra	 gloss: NEG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 264:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de tra datang ... de ___ datang
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG NEG come ... 3SG ___ come
The English translation of this sentence is:‘she did not come ... she did not come’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four adverbs always take a prepredicate position. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is always fronted, while the negative and \isi{prohibitive} adverbs directly precede the predicate. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is often realized as \textitbf{ya}, and negative \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ is quite commonly shortened to \textitbf{jang}. Examples are provided in (\ref{Example_5.153}) to (\ref{Example_5.156}): \isi{affirmation} with \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ in (\ref{Example_5.153}), \isi{negation} with interchangeably used \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg}’ in (\ref{Example_5.154}), and with \textitbf{bukang} ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\ref{Example_5.155}), and prohibition with \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ in (\ref{Example_5.156}). Negation and prohibition are discussed in more detail in §\ref{Para_13.1} and §\ref{Para_13.3.3}, respectively.
A: word: tida	 gloss: NEG
B: word: sidaq	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: stenga	 gloss: half
D: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 265:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): saya ___ anjing hitam
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG ___ dog be.black
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(the situation is) not (that) I am a black dog’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four adverbs always take a prepredicate position. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is always fronted, while the negative and \isi{prohibitive} adverbs directly precede the predicate. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is often realized as \textitbf{ya}, and negative \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ is quite commonly shortened to \textitbf{jang}. Examples are provided in (\ref{Example_5.153}) to (\ref{Example_5.156}): \isi{affirmation} with \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ in (\ref{Example_5.153}), \isi{negation} with interchangeably used \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ and \textitbf{tida} ‘\textsc{neg}’ in (\ref{Example_5.154}), and with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg}’ (\ref{Example_5.155}), and prohibition with \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ in (\ref{Example_5.156}). Negation and prohibition are discussed in more detail in §\ref{Para_13.1} and §\ref{Para_13.3.3}, respectively.
A: word: bukang	 gloss: NEG
B: word: snek	 gloss: snack
C: word: tukang	 gloss: craftsman
D: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 266:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Affirmative \textitbf{yo} ‘yes’ is often realized as \textitbf{ya}, and negative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}’ is quite commonly shortened to \textitbf{jang}. Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 267:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kas tinggal, ___ de nakal
Gloss (with missing item): give stay ___ 3SG be.mischievous
The English translation of this sentence is:‘let it be, indeed, he is mischievous’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the modal adverbs is demonstrated in (\ref{Example_5.157}) to (\ref{Example_5.160}). Typically, they precede the subject. This is illustrated with epistemic \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and \textitbf{pasti} ‘definitely’ in (\ref{Example_5.158}), and with evaluative \textitbf{akirnya} ‘finally’ in (\ref{Example_5.159}) and \textitbf{taw{\Tilde}taw} ‘suddenly’ in (\ref{Example_5.160}). Functioning at clause level, the epistemic adverbs introduce propositions which offer explanations and clarifications for the events depicted in the preceding discourse, while the evaluative adverbs provide an evaluation of the events described in the preceding discourse.
A: word: siapa	 gloss: who
B: word: memang	 gloss: indeed
C: word: temang	 gloss: friend
D: word: jadi	 gloss: so
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 268:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ orang itu tida keliatang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ person D.DIST NEG be.visible
The English translation of this sentence is:‘suddenly that person wasn’t visible (any longer)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the modal adverbs is demonstrated in (\ref{Example_5.157}) to (\ref{Example_5.160}). Typically, they precede the subject. This is illustrated with epistemic \textitbf{memang} ‘indeed’ in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and \textitbf{pasti} ‘definitely’ in (\ref{Example_5.158}), and with evaluative \textitbf{akirnya} ‘finally’ in (\ref{Example_5.159}) and \textitbf{taw{\Tilde}taw} ‘suddenly’ in (\ref{Example_5.160}). Functioning at clause level, the epistemic adverbs introduce propositions which offer explanations and clarifications for the events depicted in the preceding discourse, while the evaluative adverbs provide an evaluation of the events described in the preceding discourse.
A: word: apa~apa	 gloss: RDP~what
B: word: taw	 gloss: know
C: word: tamba	 gloss: add
D: word: taw~taw	 gloss: RDP~know
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 270:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3SG go.home
The English translation of this sentence is:‘certainly, she’ll come home’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the modal adverbs is demonstrated in (\ref{Example_5.157}) to (\ref{Example_5.160}). Typically, they precede the subject. This is illustrated with epistemic \textitbf{memang} ‘indeed’ in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.158}), and with evaluative \textitbf{akirnya} ‘finally’ in (\ref{Example_5.159}) and \textitbf{taw{\Tilde}taw} ‘suddenly’ in (\ref{Example_5.160}). Functioning at clause level, the epistemic adverbs introduce propositions which offer explanations and clarifications for the events depicted in the preceding discourse, while the evaluative adverbs provide an evaluation of the events described in the preceding discourse.

B: word: pas	 gloss: precisely

D: word: sembu	 gloss: be.healed
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 271:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ asap~asap naik, langsung api menyala
Gloss (with missing item): ___ RDP~smoke ascend immediately fire flame
The English translation of this sentence is:‘finally smoke ascended, immediately the fire flared up’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the modal adverbs is demonstrated in (\ref{Example_5.157}) to (\ref{Example_5.160}). Typically, they precede the subject. This is illustrated with epistemic \textitbf{memang} ‘indeed’ in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and \textitbf{pasti} ‘definitely’ in (\ref{Example_5.158}), and with evaluative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.159}) and \textitbf{taw{\Tilde}taw} ‘suddenly’ in (\ref{Example_5.160}). Functioning at clause level, the epistemic adverbs introduce propositions which offer explanations and clarifications for the events depicted in the preceding discourse, while the evaluative adverbs provide an evaluation of the events described in the preceding discourse.
A: word: tanya	 gloss: ask
B: word: lagi	 gloss: again
C: word: oktober	 gloss: October
D: word: akirnya	 gloss: finally
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 272:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ orang itu tida keliatang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ person D.DIST NEG be.visible
The English translation of this sentence is:‘suddenly that person wasn’t visible (any longer)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the modal adverbs is demonstrated in (\ref{Example_5.157}) to (\ref{Example_5.160}). Typically, they precede the subject. This is illustrated with epistemic \textitbf{memang} ‘indeed’ in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and \textitbf{pasti} ‘definitely’ in (\ref{Example_5.158}), and with evaluative \textitbf{akirnya} ‘finally’ in (\ref{Example_5.159}) and \textitbf{taw{\Tilde}taw} ‘suddenly’ in (\ref{Example_5.160}). Functioning at clause level, the epistemic adverbs introduce propositions which offer explanations and clarifications for the events depicted in the preceding discourse, while the evaluative adverbs provide an evaluation of the events described in the preceding discourse.
A: word: taw~taw	 gloss: RDP~know
B: word: apa~apa	 gloss: RDP~what
C: word: timur	 gloss: east
D: word: taw	 gloss: know
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 273:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kas tinggal, ___ de nakal
Gloss (with missing item): give stay ___ 3SG be.mischievous
The English translation of this sentence is:‘let it be, indeed, he is mischievous’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While evaluative modal adverbs always precede the subject, most epistemic adverbs can take two prepredicate positions. Besides preceding the subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), they can also directly precede the predicate. The exceptions are \textitbf{artinya} ‘that means’ and \textitbf{maksutnya} ‘that is to say’, both of which always precede the subject. This position directly preceding the predicate is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.161}) and with \textitbf{pasti} ‘definitely’ in (\ref{Example_5.162}) (compare both examples with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), respectively). Both examples also show that modal adverbs not only occur in verbal clauses as in (\ref{Example_5.162}), but also in nonverbal clauses, as in (\ref{Example_5.161}).
A: word: temang	 gloss: friend
B: word: jadi	 gloss: so
C: word: orang	 gloss: person
D: word: memang	 gloss: indeed
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ de pulang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3SG go.home
The English translation of this sentence is:‘certainly, she’ll come home’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While evaluative modal adverbs always precede the subject, most epistemic adverbs can take two prepredicate positions. Besides preceding the subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), they can also directly precede the predicate. The exceptions are \textitbf{artinya} ‘that means’ and \textitbf{maksutnya} ‘that is to say’, both of which always precede the subject. This position directly preceding the predicate is illustrated with \textitbf{memang} ‘indeed’ in (\ref{Example_5.161}) and with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.162}) (compare both examples with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), respectively). Both examples also show that modal adverbs not only occur in verbal clauses as in (\ref{Example_5.162}), but also in nonverbal clauses, as in (\ref{Example_5.161}).
A: word: pas	 gloss: precisely
B: word: pasti	 gloss: definitely
C: word: timur	 gloss: east
D: word: pante-timur	 gloss: Pante-Timur
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 275:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): jangang ko singgung, tapi ini ___ bukti
Gloss (with missing item): NEG.IMP 2SG offend but this ___ proof
The English translation of this sentence is:[About problems with the local elections:] ‘don’t feel offended but this is indeed the proof’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While evaluative modal adverbs always precede the subject, most epistemic adverbs can take two prepredicate positions. Besides preceding the subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), they can also directly precede the predicate. The exceptions are \textitbf{artinya} ‘that means’ and \textitbf{maksutnya} ‘that is to say’, both of which always precede the subject. This position directly preceding the predicate is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.161}) and with \textitbf{pasti} ‘definitely’ in (\ref{Example_5.162}) (compare both examples with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), respectively). Both examples also show that modal adverbs not only occur in verbal clauses as in (\ref{Example_5.162}), but also in nonverbal clauses, as in (\ref{Example_5.161}).
A: word: temang	 gloss: friend
B: word: jadi	 gloss: so
C: word: dua	 gloss: two
D: word: memang	 gloss: indeed
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 276:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... tapi de ___ kasi swara
Gloss (with missing item): ... but 3SG ___ give voice
The English translation of this sentence is:[About meeting strangers in remote areas:] ‘[most likely, he/she won’t know your name yet,] but he/she’ll definitely call (you)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While evaluative modal adverbs always precede the subject, most epistemic adverbs can take two prepredicate positions. Besides preceding the subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), they can also directly precede the predicate. The exceptions are \textitbf{artinya} ‘that means’ and \textitbf{maksutnya} ‘that is to say’, both of which always precede the subject. This position directly preceding the predicate is illustrated with \textitbf{memang} ‘indeed’ in (\ref{Example_5.161}) and with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.162}) (compare both examples with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), respectively). Both examples also show that modal adverbs not only occur in verbal clauses as in (\ref{Example_5.162}), but also in nonverbal clauses, as in (\ref{Example_5.161}).
A: word: banyak	 gloss: many
B: word: pasti	 gloss: definitely
C: word: pas	 gloss: precisely
D: word: bale	 gloss: turn.around
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 277:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kas tinggal, ___ de nakal
Gloss (with missing item): give stay ___ 3SG be.mischievous
The English translation of this sentence is:‘let it be, indeed, he is mischievous’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While evaluative modal adverbs always precede the subject, most epistemic adverbs can take two prepredicate positions. Besides preceding the subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), they can also directly precede the predicate. The exceptions are \textitbf{artinya} ‘that means’ and \textitbf{maksutnya} ‘that is to say’, both of which always precede the subject. This position directly preceding the predicate is illustrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.161}) and with \textitbf{pasti} ‘definitely’ in (\ref{Example_5.162}) (compare both examples with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.157}) and (\ref{Example_5.158}), respectively). Both examples also show that modal adverbs not only occur in verbal clauses as in (\ref{Example_5.162}), but also in nonverbal clauses, as in (\ref{Example_5.161}).
A: word: perna	 gloss: ever
B: word: memang	 gloss: indeed
C: word: jadi	 gloss: so
D: word: temang	 gloss: friend
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 287:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tong pergi ___ ke Sarmi
Gloss (with missing item): 1PL go ___ to Sarmi
The English translation of this sentence is:‘we’ll go very soon’ to Sarmi’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The postpredicate position is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.167}) to (\ref{Example_5.170}). In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the ad\isi{verb} follows the predicate and precedes the adjunct, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘very soon’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.167}) and \textitbf{langsung} ‘immediately’ in (\ref{Example_5.169}). Clauses, in which the temporal ad\isi{verb} follows the peripheral adjunct are either ungrammatical, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘very soon’ in the elicited examples in (\ref{Example_5.168}), or only marginally grammatical such as \textitbf{langsung} ‘immediately’ in the elicited contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.170}).
A: word: cantik	 gloss: be.beautiful
B: word: nanti	 gloss: very.soon
C: word: janda	 gloss: widow
D: word: dua~dua	 gloss: RDP~two
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 290:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The meaning aspects conveyed by the different positions of the temporal adverbs have to do with scope. This is demonstrated with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in three (near) contrastive examples: the prepredicate position following the subject is shown in (\ref{Example_5.171}), the prepredicate position preceding the subject in (\ref{Example_5.172}), and the postpredicate position in (\ref{Example_5.173}).
A: word: tinggal	 gloss: stay
B: word: sungay	 gloss: river
C: word: suda	 gloss: already
D: word: langsung	 gloss: immediately
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 293:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Temporal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___{\Tilde}the morpheme ___} ‘just now’ only occur in prepredic\-ate position, as in (\ref{Example_5.175}) and (\ref{Example_5.176}). While \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ directly precedes the predicate, \textitbf{the morpheme ___{\Tilde}the morpheme ___} ‘just now’ precedes the subject.
A: word: baru	 gloss: recently
B: word: baru~baru	 gloss: RDP~recently
C: word: ember	 gloss: bucket
D: word: hari	 gloss: day
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 294:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ de masuk ruma-sakit
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3SG enter hospital
The English translation of this sentence is:‘just now, he got into hospital’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Temporal \textitbf{baru} ‘recently’ and \textitbf{baru{\Tilde}baru} ‘just now’ only occur in prepredic\-ate position, as in (\ref{Example_5.175}) and (\ref{Example_5.176}). While \textitbf{baru} ‘recently’ directly precedes the predicate, \textitbf{baru{\Tilde}baru} ‘just now’ precedes the subject.
A: word: baru~baru	 gloss: RDP~recently
B: word: sring~sring	 gloss: RDP~often
C: word: baru	 gloss: and.then
D: word: marga	 gloss: clan
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 295:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru~baru de su turung, ___ de su pulang
Gloss (with missing item): RDP~recently 3SG already descend ___ 3SG already go.home
The English translation of this sentence is:[Reply to an interlocutor who is looking for someone:] ‘just now he already came by, (it’s) just (that) he already went home’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the focus adverbs is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.177}) to (\ref{Example_5.181}). Focus adverbs typically precede the subject. This is shown with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.177}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.179}). Most of them can also take a prepredicate position directly preceding the predicate; the exceptions are \textitbf{apalagi} ‘moreover’, \textitbf{kecuali} ‘except’ and \textitbf{kususnya} ‘especially’ which always precede the subject. The position directly preceding the predicate is shown with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.178}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.180}), respectively. Another exception is prepredicate \textitbf{juga} ‘also’, which always directly precedes the predicate, as in (\ref{Example_5.181}); for its postpredi\-cate uses see (\ref{Example_5.182}). These examples also illustrate that focus adverbs not only modify verbal predicates, as in (\ref{Example_5.177}), and (\ref{Example_5.179}) to (\ref{Example_5.181}), but also nonverbal predicates, such as the \isi{numeral} predicate \textitbf{dua} ‘two’ in (\ref{Example_5.178}).
A: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
B: word: ruma	 gloss: house
C: word: cuma	 gloss: just
D: word: hanya	 gloss: only
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 296:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Ise dong ___ duduk di sana
Gloss (with missing item): Ise 3PL ___ sit at L.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Ise and the others are also sitting over there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the focus adverbs is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.177}) to (\ref{Example_5.181}). Focus adverbs typically precede the subject. This is shown with \textitbf{cuma} ‘just’ in (\ref{Example_5.177}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.179}). Most of them can its gloss ___ take a prepredicate position directly preceding the predicate; the exceptions are \textitbf{apalagi} ‘moreover’, \textitbf{kecuali} ‘except’ and \textitbf{kususnya} ‘especially’ which always precede the subject. The position directly preceding the predicate is shown with \textitbf{cuma} ‘just’ in (\ref{Example_5.178}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.180}), respectively. Another exception is prepredicate \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, which always directly precedes the predicate, as in (\ref{Example_5.181}); for its postpredi\-cate uses see (\ref{Example_5.182}). These examples its gloss ___ illustrate that focus adverbs not only modify verbal predicates, as in (\ref{Example_5.177}), and (\ref{Example_5.179}) to (\ref{Example_5.181}), but its gloss ___ nonverbal predicates, such as the \isi{numeral} predicate \textitbf{dua} ‘two’ in (\ref{Example_5.178}).
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: tugas	 gloss: duty
C: word: selaing	 gloss: besides
D: word: juga	 gloss: also
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 297:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru~baru de su turung, ___ de su pulang
Gloss (with missing item): RDP~recently 3SG already descend ___ 3SG already go.home
The English translation of this sentence is:[Reply to an interlocutor who is looking for someone:] ‘just now he already came by, (it’s) just (that) he already went home’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the focus adverbs is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.177}) to (\ref{Example_5.181}). Focus adverbs typically precede the subject. This is shown with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.177}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.179}). Most of them can also take a prepredicate position directly preceding the predicate; the exceptions are \textitbf{apalagi} ‘moreover’, \textitbf{kecuali} ‘except’ and \textitbf{kususnya} ‘especially’ which always precede the subject. The position directly preceding the predicate is shown with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.178}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.180}), respectively. Another exception is prepredicate \textitbf{juga} ‘also’, which always directly precedes the predicate, as in (\ref{Example_5.181}); for its postpredi\-cate uses see (\ref{Example_5.182}). These examples also illustrate that focus adverbs not only modify verbal predicates, as in (\ref{Example_5.177}), and (\ref{Example_5.179}) to (\ref{Example_5.181}), but also nonverbal predicates, such as the \isi{numeral} predicate \textitbf{dua} ‘two’ in (\ref{Example_5.178}).
A: word: ruma	 gloss: house
B: word: pukul	 gloss: hit
C: word: hanya	 gloss: only
D: word: cuma	 gloss: just
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 301:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The position directly preceding the predicate is shown with \textitbf{cuma} ‘just’ in (\ref{Example_5.178}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.180}), respectively. Another exception is prepredicate \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, which always directly precedes the predicate, as in (\ref{Example_5.181}); for its postpredi\-cate uses see (\ref{Example_5.182}). Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The prepredicate position of the focus adverbs is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.177}) to (\ref{Example_5.181}). Focus adverbs typically precede the subject. This is shown with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.177}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.179}). Most of them can also take a prepredicate position directly preceding the predicate; the exceptions are \textitbf{apalagi} ‘moreover’, \textitbf{kecuali} ‘except’ and \textitbf{kususnya} ‘especially’ which always precede the subject. The position directly preceding the predicate is shown with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.178}) and \textitbf{hanya} ‘only’ in (\ref{Example_5.180}), respectively. Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 304:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {dari} {sini} {deng} {Papua-Lima,} {kembali} ___ deng {Papua-Lima} ... ke sana deng Papua-Lima kembali deng Papua-Lima juga
Gloss (with missing item): from L.PROX with Papua-Lima return ___ with Papua-Lima ... to L.DIST with Papua-Lima return with Papua-Lima also
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(I’ll leave) from here with the Papua-Lima (ship) and return also with the Papua-Lima (ship) ... (I’ll get) over there with the Papua-Lima (ship and) return with the Papua-Lima (ship) also’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Three focus adverbs take a postpredicate position, namely \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’, and \textitbf{saja} ‘just’. This is demonstrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.182}) to (\ref{Example_5.184}). (As shown in (\ref{Example_5.181}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can its gloss ___ take a prepredicate position.) In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the three adverbs can directly follow the predicate, such as the first \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.183}). Alternatively, they can follow the adjunct, such as the second \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.184}). Focus ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{saja} ‘just’ has the same distributional properties as \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’. The semantics expressed with the different positions again have to do with scope.
A: word: juga	 gloss: also
B: word: selaing	 gloss: besides
C: word: tugas	 gloss: duty
D: word: jangang	 gloss: NEG.IMP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Three focus adverbs take a postpredicate position, namely \textitbf{juga} ‘also’, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, also’, and \textitbf{saja} ‘just’. This is demonstrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.182}) to (\ref{Example_5.184}). (As shown in (\ref{Example_5.181}), \textitbf{juga} ‘also’ can also take a prepredicate position.) In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the three adverbs can directly follow the predicate, such as the first \textitbf{juga} ‘also’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, also’ in (\ref{Example_5.183}). D: word: daging	 gloss: meat
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 309:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {dari} {sini} {deng} {Papua-Lima,} {kembali} {juga} deng {Papua-Lima} ... ke sana deng Papua-Lima kembali deng Papua-Lima ___
Gloss (with missing item): from L.PROX with Papua-Lima return also with Papua-Lima ... to L.DIST with Papua-Lima return with Papua-Lima ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(I’ll leave) from here with the Papua-Lima (ship) and return also with the Papua-Lima (ship) ... (I’ll get) over there with the Papua-Lima (ship and) return with the Papua-Lima (ship) also’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Three focus adverbs take a postpredicate position, namely \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’, and \textitbf{saja} ‘just’. This is demonstrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.182}) to (\ref{Example_5.184}). (As shown in (\ref{Example_5.181}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can its gloss ___ take a prepredicate position.) In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the three adverbs can directly follow the predicate, such as the first \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.183}). Alternatively, they can follow the adjunct, such as the second \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.184}). Focus ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{saja} ‘just’ has the same distributional properties as \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’. The semantics expressed with the different positions again have to do with scope.
A: word: mulay	 gloss: start
B: word: selaing	 gloss: besides
C: word: tugas	 gloss: duty
D: word: juga	 gloss: also
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 310:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de kembali ___ ke Papua
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG return ___ to Papua
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he came back again to Papua’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Three focus adverbs take a postpredicate position, namely \textitbf{juga} ‘also’, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, also’, and \textitbf{saja} ‘just’. This is demonstrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.182}) to (\ref{Example_5.184}). (As shown in (\ref{Example_5.181}), \textitbf{juga} ‘also’ can also take a prepredicate position.) In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the three adverbs can directly follow the predicate, such as the first \textitbf{juga} ‘also’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, also’ in (\ref{Example_5.183}). Alternatively, they can follow the adjunct, such as the second \textitbf{juga} ‘also’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, also’ in (\ref{Example_5.184}). Focus ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{saja} ‘just’ has the same distributional properties as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, also’. The semantics expressed with the different positions its gloss ___ have to do with scope.
A: word: akirnya	 gloss: finally
B: word: lagi	 gloss: again
C: word: natanael	 gloss: Natanael
D: word: daging	 gloss: meat
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 311:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): from L.PROX with Papua-Lima return ___ with Papua-Lima ... to L.DIST with Papua-Lima return with Papua-Lima also
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(I’ll leave) from here with the Papua-Lima (ship) and return also with the Papua-Lima (ship) ... (I’ll get) over there with the Papua-Lima (ship and) return with the Papua-Lima (ship) also’

This is demonstrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.182}) to (\ref{Example_5.184}). (As shown in (\ref{Example_5.181}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can its gloss ___ take a prepredicate position.) In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the three adverbs can directly follow the predicate, such as the first \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{lagi} ‘again, its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.183}). A: word: bagemana	 gloss: how

Question 313:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Three focus adverbs take a postpredicate position, namely \textitbf{juga} ‘also’, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, also’, and \textitbf{saja} ‘just’. This is demonstrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_5.182}) to (\ref{Example_5.184}). (As shown in (\ref{Example_5.181}), \textitbf{juga} ‘also’ can also take a prepredicate position.) In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the three adverbs can directly follow the predicate, such as the first \textitbf{juga} ‘also’ token in (\ref{Example_5.182}) and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, also’ in (\ref{Example_5.183}). Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 314:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ana ini ___ bodo
Gloss (with missing item): child D.PROX ___ be.stupid
The English translation of this sentence is:‘this child is most stupid’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four amplifiers modify \isi{monovalent} stative and \isi{bivalent} verbs, as discussed in §\ref{Para_5.3.4} and §\ref{Para_5.3.5} (comparative constructions are discussed in §\ref{Para_11.5}). The amplifiers occur in prepredicate position, following the subject, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.185}). Furthermore, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can precede the subject, although not very often. In this clause-initial position it functions as an epistemic modal ad\isi{verb} which has scope over the entire proposition, as in (\ref{Example_5.186}) (modal adverbs are discussed in §\ref{Para_5.4.4}).
A: word: empat	 gloss: four
B: word: paling	 gloss: most
C: word: paling~paling	 gloss: RDP~most
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 315:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {waktu} {saya} bilang {sa} {mo} biking acara, ___ sa tra kerja, sa sebagey kepala acara
Gloss (with missing item): time 1SG say 1SG want make ceremony ___ 1SG NEG work 1SG as head ceremony
The English translation of this sentence is:‘when I say, I want to hold a festivity, most likely I won’t (have to) work, I’ll be the head of the festivity’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The four amplifiers modify \isi{monovalent} stative and \isi{bivalent} verbs, as discussed in §\ref{Para_5.3.4} and §\ref{Para_5.3.5} (comparative constructions are discussed in §\ref{Para_11.5}). The amplifiers occur in prepredicate position, following the subject, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.185}). Furthermore, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can precede the subject, although not very often. In this clause-initial position it functions as an epistemic modal ad\isi{verb} which has scope over the entire proposition, as in (\ref{Example_5.186}) (modal adverbs are discussed in §\ref{Para_5.4.4}).
A: word: kiri	 gloss: left
B: word: paling	 gloss: most
C: word: banyak	 gloss: many
D: word: paling~paling	 gloss: RDP~most
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 316:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): a, ko ___ bodo
Gloss (with missing item): ah! 2SG ___ be.stupid
The English translation of this sentence is:‘ah, you are too stupid’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The intensifier \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also occurs in prepredicate position, as in (\ref{Example_5.187}). By contrast, \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ takes a postpredicate position, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.188}) to (\ref{Example_5.190}). In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, as in (\ref{Example_5.189}), \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ follows the predicate, such as \textitbf{enak} ‘be pleasant’ in (\ref{Example_5.189}). Clauses in which \textitbf{skali} ‘very’ follows the peripheral adjunct, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.190}), are ungrammatical.
A: word: sumur	 gloss: well
B: word: terbuka	 gloss: be.opened
C: word: terlalu	 gloss: too
D: word: akirnya	 gloss: finally
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 317:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ade bongso jadi ko sayang dia ___ e?
Gloss (with missing item): ySb youngest.offspring so 2SG love 3SG ___ eh
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(your) youngest sibling, so you love her very much, eh?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The intensifier \textitbf{terlalu} ‘too’ also occurs in prepredicate position, as in (\ref{Example_5.187}). By contrast, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes a postpredicate position, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.188}) to (\ref{Example_5.190}). In clauses with peripheral adjuncts, as in (\ref{Example_5.189}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ follows the predicate, such as \textitbf{enak} ‘be pleasant’ in (\ref{Example_5.189}). Clauses in which \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ follows the peripheral adjunct, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.190}), are ungrammatical.
A: word: skali	 gloss: very
B: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
C: word: jadi	 gloss: so
D: word: kali	 gloss: river
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 318:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Gloss (with missing item): 2PL parent be.pleasant ___ at L.DIST

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 320:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa su ___ besar
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG already ___ be.big
The English translation of this sentence is:[About the speaker’s childhood:] ‘I was already rather big’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The diminishers \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ and \textitbf{hampir} ‘almost’ also occur in prepredicate position, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.191}) to (\ref{Example_5.194}). Always directly preceding the \isi{verb}, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ modifies stative verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.191}). Clauses in which \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ precedes the subject, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.192}), are ungrammatical. Diminisher \textitbf{hampir} ‘almost’ typically modifies dynamic verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.193}) and (\ref{Example_5.194}).\footnote{According to one consultant, some Papuan Malay speakers also use \textitbf{hampir} ‘almost’ to modify stative verbs. Much more often though they employ a construction with \textitbf{su mulay} ‘already start to’ as in (\ref{Footnote_Example_5.1}) below:
A: word: ato	 gloss: or
B: word: agak	 gloss: rather
C: word: dua~dua	 gloss: RDP~two
D: word: jaga	 gloss: guard
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 321:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dong bunu bapa
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL kill father
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(it) almost (happened that) they killed (my) father’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The diminishers \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also occur in prepredicate position, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.191}) to (\ref{Example_5.194}). Always directly preceding the \isi{verb}, \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ modifies stative verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.191}). Clauses in which \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ precedes the subject, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.192}), are ungrammatical. Diminisher \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ typically modifies dynamic verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.193}) and (\ref{Example_5.194}).\footnote{According to one consultant, some Papuan Malay speakers also use \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ to modify stative verbs. Much more often though they employ a construction with \textitbf{su mulay} ‘already start to’ as in (\ref{Footnote_Example_5.1}) below:
A: word: hampir	 gloss: almost
B: word: perna	 gloss: ever
C: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
D: word: samping~samping	 gloss: RDP~side
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 324:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dong bunu bapa
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL kill father
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(it) almost (happened that) they killed (my) father’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The diminishers \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also occur in prepredicate position, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.191}) to (\ref{Example_5.194}). Always directly preceding the \isi{verb}, \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ modifies stative verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.191}). Clauses in which \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ precedes the subject, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.192}), are ungrammatical. Diminisher \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ typically modifies dynamic verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.193}) and (\ref{Example_5.194}).\footnote{According to one consultant, some Papuan Malay speakers also use \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ to modify stative verbs. Much more often though they employ a construction with \textitbf{su mulay} ‘already start to’ as in (\ref{Footnote_Example_5.1}) below:
A: word: akirnya	 gloss: finally
B: word: hampir	 gloss: almost
C: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
D: word: samping~samping	 gloss: RDP~side
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 325:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru kita pergi skola, ___ mulay sembu
Gloss (with missing item): and.then 1PL go school ___ start be.healed
The English translation of this sentence is:[After an accident:] ‘and then we went (back) to school, (our wounds) were almost healed’ (Lit. ‘already started to be healed’) [081014-012-NP.0005]
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The diminishers \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ and \textitbf{hampir} ‘almost’ also occur in prepredicate position, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.191}) to (\ref{Example_5.194}). Always directly preceding the \isi{verb}, \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ modifies stative verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.191}). Clauses in which \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ precedes the subject, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.192}), are ungrammatical. Diminisher \textitbf{hampir} ‘almost’ typically modifies dynamic verbs, as in (\ref{Example_5.193}) and (\ref{Example_5.194}).\footnote{According to one consultant, some Papuan Malay speakers also use \textitbf{hampir} ‘almost’ to modify stative verbs. Much more often though they employ a construction with \textitbf{su mulay} ‘its gloss ___ start to’ as in (\ref{Footnote_Example_5.1}) below:
A: word: skarang	 gloss: now
B: word: suda	 gloss: already
C: word: kadang~kadang	 gloss: RDP~sometimes
D: word: pemuda	 gloss: youth
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 326:

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The diminishers \textitbf{agak} ‘rather’ and \textitbf{hampir} ‘almost’ also occur in prepredicate position, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.191}) to (\ref{Example_5.194}). Question 327:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong ___ bunu bapa
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL ___ kill father
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they almost killed (my) father’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The ad\isi{verb} can directly precede the predicate, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.193}), or precede the subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.194}). In the corpus, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ always occurs in the latter position, where the ad\isi{verb} has scope over the entire proposition.
A: word: bunu	 gloss: kill
B: word: hampir	 gloss: almost
C: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
D: word: samping~samping	 gloss: RDP~side
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 328:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dong bunu bapa
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL kill father
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(it) almost (happened that) they killed (my) father’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The ad\isi{verb} can directly precede the predicate, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.193}), or precede the subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.194}). In the corpus, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ always occurs in the latter position, where the ad\isi{verb} has scope over the entire proposition.
A: word: samping~samping	 gloss: RDP~side
B: word: hampir	 gloss: almost
C: word: mungking	 gloss: maybe
D: word: sayang	 gloss: love
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 329:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru satu kali sa sakit ___
Gloss (with missing item): and.then one time 1SG be.sick ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘but then one time I was badly sick’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay does not have manner adverbs. Instead, manner is expressed through stative verbs, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.195}) to (\ref{Example_5.200}). The modifying stative verbs always take a postpredicate position. In (\ref{Example_5.195}), for instance, postpredicate stative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be harsh’ modifies stative \textitbf{sakit} ‘be sick’, and in (\ref{Example_5.198}) \textitbf{trus} ‘be continuous’ modifies \textitbf{tatap dia} ‘observe him’. In verbal clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the modifying stative \isi{verb} can directly follow the predicate as in (\ref{Example_5.199}), or follow the adjunct, as in (\ref{Example_5.200}).
A: word: kras~kras	 gloss: RDP~be.harsh
B: word: pahit	 gloss: be.bitter
C: word: diam	 gloss: be.quiet
D: word: kras	 gloss: be.harsh
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 330:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... terendam di air ___
Gloss (with missing item): ... be.soaked at water ___
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a motorbike that got stuck in a river:] ‘[(the motorbike) is still there ...,] (it) is immersed in water continuously’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay does not have manner adverbs. Instead, manner is expressed through stative verbs, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.195}) to (\ref{Example_5.200}). The modifying stative verbs always take a postpredicate position. In (\ref{Example_5.195}), for instance, postpredicate stative \textitbf{kras} ‘be harsh’ modifies stative \textitbf{sakit} ‘be sick’, and in (\ref{Example_5.198}) \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘be continuous’ modifies \textitbf{tatap dia} ‘observe him’. In verbal clauses with peripheral adjuncts, the modifying stative \isi{verb} can directly follow the predicate as in (\ref{Example_5.199}), or follow the adjunct, as in (\ref{Example_5.200}).
A: word: pokoknya	 gloss: the.main.thing.is
B: word: petrus	 gloss: Petrus
C: word: trus	 gloss: be.continuous
D: word: tenga	 gloss: middle
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 335:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ana itu ___ paling sayang dia tu ana itu
Gloss (with missing item): child D.DIST ___ most love 3SG D.DIST child D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that child, I love her (emph) most, that child’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The personal pronouns have pronominal and adnominal uses. This is illustrated with two examples. The utterance in (\ref{Example_5.201}) demonstrates the pronominal uses of short \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ and long \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, while the example in (\ref{Example_5.202}) shows the adnominal uses of short \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’. The personal pronouns are discussed in detail in \chapref{Para_6}.
A: word: bisa	 gloss: be.able
B: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
C: word: sa	 gloss: 1SG
D: word: nomor	 gloss: number
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 337:

Question 339:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): Natanael ___ win
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a volleyball game:] ‘Natanael and his friends won’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The personal pronouns have pronominal and adnominal uses. This is illustrated with two examples. The utterance in (\ref{Example_5.201}) demonstrates the pronominal uses of short \textitbf{sa} ‘\textsc{1sg}’ and long \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’, while the example in (\ref{Example_5.202}) shows the adnominal uses of short \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3pl}’. The personal pronouns are discussed in detail in \chapref{Para_6}.
A: word: minggu	 gloss: Sunday
B: word: kam	 gloss: 2PL
C: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
D: word: dong/dorang	 gloss: 3PL

Question 340:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang gara~gara ___ dia itu!
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP~irritate ___ 3SG D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constituents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Constituents occurring to the right of the demonstratives such as \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ in (\ref{Example_5.206}) are not part of the \isi{noun} phrase: \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ is a clausal predicate. The examples in (\ref{Example_5.203}) and (\ref{Example_5.204}) show that the demonstratives signal specificity (and not definiteness). The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{the morpheme ___ dia itu} ‘that its gloss ___’ (literally ‘that she its gloss ___’) designates a specific and \isi{definite} referent with distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals definiteness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). By contrast, the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ana kecil satu ini} ‘this particular small child’ in (\ref{Example_5.204}) denotes a specific but \isi{indefinite} referent with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ again indicating specificity while posthead \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ signals \isi{indefiniteness} (see also §\ref{Para_5.9.4}).
A: word: mantang	 gloss: former
B: word: tanta	 gloss: aunt
C: word: cuma	 gloss: just
D: word: nene	 gloss: grandmother
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 341:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang gara~gara tanta ___ itu!
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP~irritate aunt ___ D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constituents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Constituents occurring to the right of the demonstratives such as \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ in (\ref{Example_5.206}) are not part of the \isi{noun} phrase: \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ is a clausal predicate. The examples in (\ref{Example_5.203}) and (\ref{Example_5.204}) show that the demonstratives signal specificity (and not definiteness). The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta the morpheme ___ itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’) designates a specific and \isi{definite} referent with distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals definiteness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). By contrast, the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ana kecil satu ini} ‘this particular small child’ in (\ref{Example_5.204}) denotes a specific but \isi{indefinite} referent with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ again indicating specificity while posthead \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ signals \isi{indefiniteness} (see also §\ref{Para_5.9.4}).
A: word: diai	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: dei	 gloss: 3sg
C: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
D: word: ekor	 gloss: tail
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 342:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang gara~gara tanta dia ___
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP~irritate aunt 3SG ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constthe morpheme ___ents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Constthe morpheme ___ents occurring to the right of the demonstratives such as \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ in (\ref{Example_5.206}) are not part of the \isi{noun} phrase: \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ is a clausal predicate. The examples in (\ref{Example_5.203}) and (\ref{Example_5.204}) show that the demonstratives signal specificity (and not definiteness). The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia the morpheme ___} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’) designates a specific and \isi{definite} referent with distal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals definiteness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). By contrast, the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ana kecil satu ini} ‘this particular small child’ in (\ref{Example_5.204}) denotes a specific but \isi{indefinite} referent with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ again indicating specificity while posthead \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ signals \isi{indefiniteness} (see also §\ref{Para_5.9.4}).
A: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
B: word: rame	 gloss: be.crowded
C: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
D: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 343:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Papua-Satu ada muncul dari ___ sana itu
Gloss (with missing item): Papua-Satu exist appear from ___ L.DIST D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(the ship) Papua-Satu is appearing from the sea over there (emph)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constituents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Question 346:
