Question 347:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... karna babi ___ liar
Gloss (with missing item): ... because pig ___ be.wild
The English translation of this sentence is:‘... because this pig is wild’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constituents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Constituents occurring to the right of the demonstratives such as \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ in (\ref{Example_5.206}) are not part of the \isi{noun} phrase: \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ is a clausal predicate. The examples in (\ref{Example_5.203}) and (\ref{Example_5.204}) show that the demonstratives signal specificity (and not defthe morpheme ___teness). The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’) designates a specific and \isi{defthe morpheme ___te} referent with distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals defthe morpheme ___teness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). By contrast, the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ana kecil satu the morpheme ___} ‘this particular small child’ in (\ref{Example_5.204}) denotes a specific but \isi{indefthe morpheme ___te} referent with proximal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ again indicating specificity while posthead \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ signals \isi{indefthe morpheme ___teness} (see also §\ref{Para_5.9.4}).
A: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
B: word: rabu	 gloss: Wednesday
C: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
D: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 348:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Wili ko jangang gara~gara ___ dia itu!
Gloss (with missing item): Wili 2SG NEG.IMP RDP~irritate ___ 3SG D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you Wili don’t irritate that aunt!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{the morpheme ___ dia itu} ‘that its gloss ___’ (literally ‘that she its gloss ___’) designates a specific and \isi{definite} referent with distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals definiteness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). Question 354:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} {ana} {kecil} {satu} ___ de tra gambar ana murit satu ni de tra gambar
Gloss (with missing item): and.then child be.small one ___ 3SG NEG draw child pupil one D.PROX 3SG NEG draw
The English translation of this sentence is:‘but then this particular small child, he doesn’t draw, this particular school kid, he doesn’t draw’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constituents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Constituents occurring to the right of the demonstratives such as \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ in (\ref{Example_5.206}) are not part of the \isi{noun} phrase: \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ is a clausal predicate. The examples in (\ref{Example_5.203}) and (\ref{Example_5.204}) show that the demonstratives signal specificity (and not defthe morpheme ___teness). The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’) designates a specific and \isi{defthe morpheme ___te} referent with distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals defthe morpheme ___teness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). By contrast, the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ana kecil satu the morpheme ___} ‘this particular small child’ in (\ref{Example_5.204}) denotes a specific but \isi{indefthe morpheme ___te} referent with proximal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ again indicating specificity while posthead \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ signals \isi{indefthe morpheme ___teness} (see also §\ref{Para_5.9.4}).
A: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
B: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
C: word: langsung	 gloss: immediately
D: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 355:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} {ana} {kecil} {satu} {ini} de tra gambar ___ murit satu ni de tra gambar
Gloss (with missing item): and.then child be.small one D.PROX 3SG NEG draw ___ pupil one D.PROX 3SG NEG draw
The English translation of this sentence is:‘but then this particular small child, he doesn’t draw, this particular school kid, he doesn’t draw’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constituents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Constituents occurring to the right of the demonstratives such as \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ in (\ref{Example_5.206}) are not part of the \isi{noun} phrase: \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ is a clausal predicate. The examples in (\ref{Example_5.203}) and (\ref{Example_5.204}) show that the demonstratives signal specificity (and not definiteness). The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’) designates a specific and \isi{definite} referent with distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals definiteness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). By contrast, the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{the morpheme ___ kecil satu ini} ‘this particular small its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.204}) denotes a specific but \isi{indefinite} referent with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ again indicating specificity while posthead \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ signals \isi{indefiniteness} (see also §\ref{Para_5.9.4}).
A: word: ana	 gloss: child
B: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
C: word: bayi	 gloss: baby
D: word: sakit	 gloss: be.sick
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 356:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The English translation of this sentence is:‘but then this particular small child, he doesn’t draw, this particular school kid, he doesn’t draw’

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 365:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} {ana} {kecil} {satu} {ini} de tra gambar ana murit ___ ni de tra gambar
Gloss (with missing item): and.then child be.small one D.PROX 3SG NEG draw child pupil ___ D.PROX 3SG NEG draw
The English translation of this sentence is:‘but then this particular small child, he doesn’t draw, this particular school kid, he doesn’t draw’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constituents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Constituents occurring to the right of the demonstratives such as \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ in (\ref{Example_5.206}) are not part of the \isi{noun} phrase: \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ is a clausal predicate. The examples in (\ref{Example_5.203}) and (\ref{Example_5.204}) show that the demonstratives signal specificity (and not definiteness). The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’) designates a specific and \isi{definite} referent with distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals definiteness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). By contrast, the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ana kecil the morpheme ___ ini} ‘this particular small child’ in (\ref{Example_5.204}) denotes a specific but \isi{indefinite} referent with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ again indicating specificity while posthead \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ signals \isi{indefiniteness} (see also §\ref{Para_5.9.4}).
A: word: dulu	 gloss: first
B: word: satu~satu	 gloss: RDP~one
C: word: oktober	 gloss: October
D: word: satu	 gloss: one
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 366:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): {baru} {ana} {kecil} {satu} {ini} de tra gambar ana murit satu ___ de tra gambar
Gloss (with missing item): and.then child be.small one D.PROX 3SG NEG draw child pupil one ___ 3SG NEG draw
The English translation of this sentence is:‘but then this particular small child, he doesn’t draw, this particular school kid, he doesn’t draw’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used demonstratives occur in posthead position at the right periphery of the \isi{noun} phrase. That is, all \isi{noun} phrase constituents occur to the left of the \isi{demonstrative}, with the \isi{demonstrative} having scope over the entire \isi{noun} phrase as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.203}) to (\ref{Example_5.205}). Constituents occurring to the right of the demonstratives such as \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ in (\ref{Example_5.206}) are not part of the \isi{noun} phrase: \textitbf{liar} ‘be wild’ is a clausal predicate. The examples in (\ref{Example_5.203}) and (\ref{Example_5.204}) show that the demonstratives signal specificity (and not defithe morpheme ___teness). The \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{tanta dia itu} ‘that aunt’ (literally ‘that she aunt’) designates a specific and \isi{defithe morpheme ___te} referent with distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ indicating specificity while adnominally used \textitbf{dia} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ signals defithe morpheme ___teness (§\ref{Para_5.5}). By contrast, the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ana kecil satu ithe morpheme ___} ‘this particular small child’ in (\ref{Example_5.204}) denotes a specific but \isi{indefithe morpheme ___te} referent with proximal \textitbf{ithe morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ again indicating specificity while posthead \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ signals \isi{indefithe morpheme ___teness} (see also §\ref{Para_5.9.4}).
A: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
B: word: ni	 gloss: D.PROX
C: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
D: word: sampe	 gloss: reach
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Demonstratives can also modify constituents other than nouns, namely personal pronouns as in (\ref{Example_5.207}), interrogatives as in (\ref{Example_5.208}), or locatives as in (\ref{Example_5.209}).
A: word: ko	 gloss: 2SG
B: word: basa	 gloss: be.wet
C: word: skola	 gloss: go.to.school

Question 373:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): yo, ___ mo putus
Gloss (with missing item): yes ___ want break
The English translation of this sentence is:[About redirecting a river for a street building project:] ‘yes, it (the river) is going to get dispersed’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their pronominal uses, the demonstratives stand for \isi{noun} phrases, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.210}) to (\ref{Example_5.215}). They occur in all syntactic positions within the clause. In (\ref{Example_5.210}), a \isi{demonstrative} takes the subject slot, in (\ref{Example_5.211}) the direct object slot, and in (\ref{Example_5.212}) the oblique object slot.
A: word: tiga~tiga	 gloss: RDP~three
B: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
C: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
D: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 387:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de ___ ni, dong ribut apa ka
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG ___ D.PROX 3PL trouble what or
The English translation of this sentence is:‘he thought (emph), ``what are they troubled about?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their adverbial uses, the demonstratives co-occur with verbs as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ni} ‘its gloss ___ (\textsc{emph})’ in (\ref{Example_5.216}) or with adverbs as in \textitbf{pasti tu} ‘exactly (\textsc{emph})’ in (\ref{Example_5.217}).
A: word: ber–pikir	 gloss: VBLZ–think
B: word: pikirang	 gloss: thought
C: word: pikir	 gloss: think
D: word: pasti	 gloss: definitely
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 390:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The English translation of this sentence is:‘yes, the news are exactly (emph) as I told (you)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their adverbial uses, the demonstratives co-occur with verbs as in \textitbf{pikir ni} ‘think (\textsc{emph})’ in (\ref{Example_5.216}) or with adverbs as in \textitbf{pasti the morpheme ___} ‘exactly (\textsc{emph})’ in (\ref{Example_5.217}).
A: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
B: word: satu	 gloss: one
C: word: tu	 gloss: D.DIST

Question 391:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ada segala macang tulang dia buang ___ ni]
Gloss (with missing item): exist all variety bone 3SG throw(.away) ___ D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘there were all kinds of bones, he threw away these very (ones)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay also allows the stacking of demonstratives. Typically, only identical demonstratives are stacked, as in (\ref{Example_5.218}) and (\ref{Example_5.219}). To some degree, however, non-identical demonstratives can also be stacked, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.220}) and (\ref{Example_5.221}).\footnote{Juxtaposed \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ni} ‘\textsc{d.prox d.prox}’ and \textitbf{itu tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist d.dist}’ are not taken as instances of partial \isi{reduplication}. As discussed in §\ref{Para_4.1.2}, partial \isi{reduplication} of the stems \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ and \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ should result in the reduplicated forms \textitbf{in{\Tilde}the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox{\Tilde}d.prox}’ and \textitbf{it{\Tilde}itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}{\Tilde}\textsc{d.dist}’, respectively. Therefore, \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ni} ‘\textsc{d.prox d.prox}’ and \textitbf{itu tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist} \textsc{d.dist}’ are taken as instances of \isi{demonstrative} stacking. Reduplication of demonstratives does occur, however, as discussed in §\ref{Para_4.2.5.2}.}
A: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
B: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
C: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
D: word: timur	 gloss: east
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 392:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ada segala macang tulang dia buang [ini ___
Gloss (with missing item): exist all variety bone 3SG throw(.away) D.PROX ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘there were all kinds of bones, he threw away these very (ones)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay also allows the stacking of demonstratives. Typically, only identical demonstratives are stacked, as in (\ref{Example_5.218}) and (\ref{Example_5.219}). To some degree, however, non-identical demonstratives can also be stacked, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.220}) and (\ref{Example_5.221}).\footnote{Juxtaposed \textitbf{ithe morpheme ___ the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox d.prox}’ and \textitbf{itu tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist d.dist}’ are not taken as instances of partial \isi{reduplication}. As discussed in §\ref{Para_4.1.2}, partial \isi{reduplication} of the stems \textitbf{ithe morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ and \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ should result in the reduplicated forms \textitbf{in{\Tilde}ithe morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox{\Tilde}d.prox}’ and \textitbf{it{\Tilde}itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}{\Tilde}\textsc{d.dist}’, respectively. Therefore, \textitbf{ithe morpheme ___ the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox d.prox}’ and \textitbf{itu tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist} \textsc{d.dist}’ are taken as instances of \isi{demonstrative} stacking. Reduplication of demonstratives does occur, however, as discussed in §\ref{Para_4.2.5.2}.}
A: word: satu	 gloss: one
B: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
C: word: ni	 gloss: D.PROX
D: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Typically, only identical demonstratives are stacked, as in (\ref{Example_5.218}) and (\ref{Example_5.219}). To some degree, however, non-identical demonstratives can also be stacked, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.220}) and (\ref{Example_5.221}).\footnote{Juxtaposed \textitbf{ini ni} ‘\textsc{d.prox d.prox}’ and \textitbf{itu tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist d.dist}’ are not taken as instances of partial \isi{reduplication}. Reduplication of demonstratives does occur, however, as discussed in §\ref{Para_4.2.5.2}.}

Typically, only identical demonstratives are stacked, as in (\ref{Example_5.218}) and (\ref{Example_5.219}). To some degree, however, non-identical demonstratives can also be stacked, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.220}) and (\ref{Example_5.221}).\footnote{Juxtaposed \textitbf{ini ni} ‘\textsc{d.prox d.prox}’ and \textitbf{ithe morpheme ___ the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.dist d.dist}’ are not taken as instances of partial \isi{reduplication}. Question 396:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ada segala macang tulang dia buang ___ ni]
Gloss (with missing item): exist all variety bone 3SG throw(.away) ___ D.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘there were all kinds of bones, he threw away these very (ones)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_5.218}), short proximal \textitbf{ni} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ modifies the pronominally used long proximal \isi{demonstrative}, such that ``\textsc{dem} \textsc{dem}''. In (\ref{Example_5.219}), short distal \textitbf{tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ modifies a nested \isi{noun} phrase with the adnominally used long distal \isi{demonstrative}, such that ``[[\textsc{n} \textsc{dem}] \textsc{dem}]''.
A: word: barat	 gloss: west
B: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
C: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
D: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 397:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:‘there were all kinds of bones, he threw away these very (ones)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{Example_5.218}), short proximal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ modifies the pronominally used long proximal \isi{demonstrative}, such that ``\textsc{dem} \textsc{dem}''. In (\ref{Example_5.219}), short distal \textitbf{tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ modifies a nested \isi{noun} phrase with the adnominally used long distal \isi{demonstrative}, such that ``[[\textsc{n} \textsc{dem}] \textsc{dem}]''.
A: word: kaing	 gloss: cloth
B: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
C: word: ni	 gloss: D.PROX

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 398:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ini tu percaya sama Tuhang Yesus
Gloss (with missing item): ___ D.PROX D.DIST trust to God Jesus
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that person here believes in God Jesus’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While unattested in the corpus, speakers do allow one combination of non-identical \isi{demonstrative} stacking in elicitation. Acceptable is the order of proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ followed by short distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’, as shown in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.220}). The reverse order is not permitted by speakers even in elicitation, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.221}). At this point in the research on Papuan Malay, however, the semantics of ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{ini tu}'' constructions as compared to ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{ini ni}''' and ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{itu tu}'' constructions remain uncertain.
A: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: manusia	 gloss: human.being
C: word: orang	 gloss: person
D: word: timur	 gloss: east
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Acceptable is the order of proximal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ followed by short distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’, as shown in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.220}). The reverse order is not permitted by speakers even in elicitation, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.221}). At this point in the research on Papuan Malay, however, the semantics of ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{the morpheme ___ tu}'' constructions as compared to ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{the morpheme ___ ni}''' and ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{itu tu}'' constructions remain uncertain.

Question 400:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): orang ini ___ percaya sama Tuhang Yesus
Gloss (with missing item): person D.PROX ___ trust to God Jesus
The English translation of this sentence is:‘that person here believes in God Jesus’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While unattested in the corpus, speakers do allow one combination of non-identical \isi{demonstrative} stacking in elicitation. Acceptable is the order of proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ followed by short distal \textitbf{ithe morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’, as shown in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.220}). The reverse order is not permitted by speakers even in elicitation, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.221}). At this point in the research on Papuan Malay, however, the semantics of ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{ini the morpheme ___}'' constructions as compared to ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{ini ni}''' and ``\textsc{n} \textitbf{ithe morpheme ___ the morpheme ___}'' constructions remain uncertain.
A: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
B: word: orang	 gloss: person
C: word: satu	 gloss: one
D: word: tu	 gloss: D.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 401:

B: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: nanti	 gloss: 45pt
D: word: manusia	 gloss: human.being
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 404:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa tinggal di ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG stay at ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I live over there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their pronominal uses the locatives substitute or stand for \isi{noun} phrases, as illustrated with the four elicited contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.222}). Distal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’ in (\ref{Example_5.222b}) substitutes for the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ruma yang paling di bawa itu} ‘that house that’s the furthest down’ in (\ref{Example_5.222a}). The ungrammatical construction in (\ref{Example_5.222c}) shows that the \isi{locative} replaces the entire \isi{noun} phrase and not only its nominal head \textitbf{ruma} ‘house’.
A: word: susana	 gloss: Susana
B: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
C: word: prempuang	 gloss: 10pt
D: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 405:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa tinggal di ___ yang paling di bawa itu
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG stay at ___ REL most at bottom D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I live in the house that’s the furthest down there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their pronominal uses the locatives substitute or stand for \isi{noun} phrases, as illustrated with the four elicited contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.222}). Distal \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’ in (\ref{Example_5.222b}) substitutes for the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{the morpheme ___ yang paling di bawa itu} ‘that its gloss ___ that’s the furthest down’ in (\ref{Example_5.222a}). The ungrammatical construction in (\ref{Example_5.222c}) shows that the \isi{locative} replaces the entire \isi{noun} phrase and not only its nominal head \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’.
A: word: ruma-sakit	 gloss: hospital
B: word: baik	 gloss: be.good
C: word: halamang	 gloss: yard
D: word: ruma	 gloss: house
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 408:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The English translation of this sentence is:‘I live in the house that’s the furthest down there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their pronominal uses the locits gloss ___ives substitute or stand for \isi{noun} phrases, as illustrits gloss ___ed with the four elicited contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.222}). Distal \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.the morpheme ___st}’ in (\ref{Example_5.222b}) substitutes for the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ruma yang paling the morpheme ___ bawa itu} ‘thits gloss ___ house thits gloss ___’s the furthest down’ in (\ref{Example_5.222a}). The ungrammits gloss ___ical construction in (\ref{Example_5.222c}) shows thits gloss ___ the \isi{locits gloss ___ive} replaces the entire \isi{noun} phrase and not only its nominal head \textitbf{ruma} ‘house’.
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: sama	 gloss: to
C: word: di	 gloss: at
D: word: kursi	 gloss: chair
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 410:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. The English translation of this sentence is:‘I live in the house that’s the furthest down there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In their pronominal uses the locatives substthe morpheme ___te or stand for \isi{noun} phrases, as illustrated with the four elicited contrastive examples in (\ref{Example_5.222}). Distal \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’ in (\ref{Example_5.222b}) substthe morpheme ___tes for the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{ruma yang paling di bawa the morpheme ___} ‘that house that’s the furthest down’ in (\ref{Example_5.222a}). The ungrammatical construction in (\ref{Example_5.222c}) shows that the \isi{locative} replaces the entire \isi{noun} phrase and not only its nominal head \textitbf{ruma} ‘house’.
A: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
B: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
C: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 411:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kam datang Ø ___ kam biking kaco saja
Gloss (with missing item): 2PL come ... ___ 2PL make be.confused just
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you come here, you’re just stirring up trouble’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Locatives are always embedded in prepositional phrases. The \isi{prepositional phrase} can be a peripheral adjunct, as in the first clause in (\ref{Example_5.223}) or in (\ref{Example_5.225}), a prepositional predicate, as in the second clause in (\ref{Example_5.223}), or an adnominal \isi{prepositional phrase}, as in (\ref{Example_5.224}). Usually, the locatives are introduced with an overt \isi{preposition} as in (\ref{Example_5.223}) or (\ref{Example_5.224}). The \isi{preposition} may, however, also be elided as in (\ref{Example_5.225}): the omitted \isi{preposition} is allative \textitbf{ke} ‘to’ (the \isi{elision} of prepositions is discussed in §\ref{Para_10.1.5}).
A: word: sini–nya	 gloss: L.PROX–3POSSR
B: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
C: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
D: word: yang	 gloss: REL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 412:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dari sana itu ... dorang itu kerja sendiri
Gloss (with missing item): ___ from L.DIST D.DIST ... 3PL D.DIST work be.alone
The English translation of this sentence is:‘those people from over there, .... they work by themselves’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Locatives are always embedded in prepositional phrases. The \isi{prepositional phrase} can be a peripheral adjunct, as in the first clause in (\ref{Example_5.223}) or in (\ref{Example_5.225}), a prepositional predicate, as in the second clause in (\ref{Example_5.223}), or an adnominal \isi{prepositional phrase}, as in (\ref{Example_5.224}). Usually, the locatives are introduced with an overt \isi{preposition} as in (\ref{Example_5.223}) or (\ref{Example_5.224}). The \isi{preposition} may, however, also be elided as in (\ref{Example_5.225}): the omitted \isi{preposition} is allative \textitbf{ke} ‘to’ (the \isi{elision} of prepositions is discussed in §\ref{Para_10.1.5}).
A: word: manusia	 gloss: human.being
B: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
C: word: tidor	 gloss: sleep
D: word: orang	 gloss: person
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 420:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kam datang Ø ___ kam biking kaco saja
Gloss (with missing item): 2PL come ... ___ 2PL make be.confused just
The English translation of this sentence is:‘you come here, you’re just stirring up trouble’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Locatives are always embedded in prepositional phrases. The \isi{prepositional phrase} can be a peripheral adjunct, as in the first clause in (\ref{Example_5.223}) or in (\ref{Example_5.225}), a prepositional predicate, as in the second clause in (\ref{Example_5.223}), or an adnominal \isi{prepositional phrase}, as in (\ref{Example_5.224}). The \isi{preposition} may, however, also be elided as in (\ref{Example_5.225}): the omitted \isi{preposition} is allative \textitbf{ke} ‘to’ (the \isi{elision} of prepositions is discussed in §\ref{Para_10.1.5}).
A: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
B: word: sini–nya	 gloss: L.PROX–3POSSR
C: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
D: word: marga	 gloss: clan
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 421:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong lobe ke ___ itu
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL walk.searchingly.with.lamp to ___ D.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they walk searchingly with lights to over there (emph)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The pronominally used locatives can be modified with demonstratives or relative clauses. Modification with the demonstratives typically involves short distal \textitbf{tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ as in (\ref{Example_5.226}), while \isi{modification} with long distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ is only attested for the non-proximal locatives, as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ itu} ‘over there (\textsc{emph})’ in (\ref{Example_5.227}). These distributional patterns still require further investigation. Modification with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ is unattested but possible, as shown in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.228}). Modification with relative clauses is also possible, as illustrated for proximal \textitbf{sini} ‘\textsc{l.prox}’ in (\ref{Example_5.229}) and medial \textitbf{situ} ‘\textsc{l.med}’ in (\ref{Example_5.230}). In the corpus, however, such \isi{modification} is rare and unattested for distal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’.
A: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
B: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
C: word: ruma	 gloss: house
D: word: susana	 gloss: Susana
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 422:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong lobe ke sana ___
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL walk.searchingly.with.lamp to L.DIST ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they walk searchingly with lights to over there (emph)’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The pronominally used locatives can be modified with demonstratives or relative clauses. Modification with the demonstratives typically involves short distal \textitbf{tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ as in (\ref{Example_5.226}), while \isi{modification} with long distal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ is only attested for the non-proximal locatives, as in \textitbf{sana the morpheme ___} ‘over there (\textsc{emph})’ in (\ref{Example_5.227}). These distributional patterns still require further investigation. Modification with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ is unattested but possible, as shown in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.228}). Modification with relative clauses is also possible, as illustrated for proximal \textitbf{sini} ‘\textsc{l.prox}’ in (\ref{Example_5.229}) and medial \textitbf{sthe morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{l.med}’ in (\ref{Example_5.230}). In the corpus, however, such \isi{modification} is rare and unattested for distal \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’.
A: word: snek	 gloss: snack
B: word: itu	 gloss: D.DIST
C: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
D: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 423:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): di ___ ni orang tida taw makang pinang
Gloss (with missing item): at ___ D.PROX person NEG know eat betel.nut
The English translation of this sentence is:‘here (emph) people don’t habitually eat betel nuts’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The pronominally used locatives can be modified with demonstratives or relative clauses. Modification with the demonstratives typically involves short distal \textitbf{tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ as in (\ref{Example_5.226}), while \isi{modification} with long distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ is only attested for the non-proximal locatives, as in \textitbf{sana itu} ‘over there (\textsc{emph})’ in (\ref{Example_5.227}). These distributional patterns still require further investigation. Modification with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ is unattested but possible, as shown in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.228}). Modification with relative clauses is also possible, as illustrated for proximal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{l.prox}’ in (\ref{Example_5.229}) and medial \textitbf{situ} ‘\textsc{l.med}’ in (\ref{Example_5.230}). In the corpus, however, such \isi{modification} is rare and unattested for distal \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’.
A: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
B: word: sini–nya	 gloss: L.PROX–3POSSR
C: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
D: word: smua	 gloss: all
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 427:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... sa mandi di situ, di ___ yang mungking nangka
Gloss (with missing item): ... 1SG bathe at L.MED at ___ REL maybe jackfruit
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[I saw (the poles),] I bathed there, there where (there are) maybe jackfruits’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The pronominally used locatives can be modified with demonstratives or relative clauses. Modification with the demonstratives typically involves short distal \textitbf{tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ as in (\ref{Example_5.226}), while \isi{modification} with long distal \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ is only attested for the non-proximal locatives, as in \textitbf{sana itu} ‘over there (\textsc{emph})’ in (\ref{Example_5.227}). These distributional patterns still require further investigation. Modification with proximal \textitbf{ini} ‘\textsc{d.prox}’ is unattested but possible, as shown in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.228}). Modification with relative clauses is also possible, as illustrated for proximal \textitbf{sini} ‘\textsc{l.prox}’ in (\ref{Example_5.229}) and medial \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{l.med}’ in (\ref{Example_5.230}). In the corpus, however, such \isi{modification} is rare and unattested for distal \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’.

B: word: lebi	 gloss: more
C: word: obat	 gloss: medicine
D: word: situ~situ	 gloss: RDP~L.MED
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 429:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ke sebla ___
Gloss (with missing item): to side ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘to the side {here’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used locatives always occur in posthead position. Most commonly, they occur in \isi{noun} phrases embedded in prepositional phrases, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.231}). In (\ref{Example_5.231a}), proximal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{l.prox}’ modifies the \isi{locational} \isi{noun} \textitbf{sebla} ‘side’; the \isi{noun} phrase is introduced with allative \textitbf{ke} ‘to’. In (\ref{Example_5.231b}), distal \textitbf{sana} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’ modifies the \isi{noun} \textitbf{laut} ‘sea’; the \isi{preposition} is \isi{locative} \textitbf{di} ‘at, in’.
A: word: sini–nya	 gloss: L.PROX–3POSSR
B: word: muka	 gloss: front
C: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
D: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

In (\ref{Example_5.231a}), proximal \textitbf{sini} ‘\textsc{l.prox}’ modifies the \isi{locational} \isi{noun} \textitbf{sebla} ‘side’; the \isi{noun} phrase is introduced with allative \textitbf{ke} ‘to’. In (\ref{Example_5.231b}), distal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{l.dist}’ modifies the \isi{noun} \textitbf{laut} ‘sea’; the \isi{preposition} is \isi{locative} \textitbf{di} ‘at, in’.

Question 431:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong ___
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they {here’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Adnominally used locatives also occur in unembedded \isi{noun} phrases as in (\ref{Example_5.232}), although considerably less frequently. In (\ref{Example_5.232a}), proximal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘\textsc{l.prox}’ modifies the personal \isi{pronoun} \textitbf{dong} ‘\textsc{3pl}’, while in (\ref{Example_5.232a}) medial \textitbf{situ} ‘\textsc{l.med}’ modifies the \isi{noun} phrase \textitbf{orang kantor} ‘office employees’.
A: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
B: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
C: word: sini–nya	 gloss: L.PROX–3POSSR
D: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 433:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): e, ___ suru kam minum~minum di sini?
Gloss (with missing item): hey ___ order 2PL RDP~drink at L.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘hey, who told you to keep drinking here’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the identity of human referents. Its pronominal uses are illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.233}) to (\ref{Example_5.240}), its adnominal uses in (\ref{Example_5.241}) and (\ref{Example_5.242}), and its predicative uses in (\ref{Example_5.243}) and (\ref{Example_5.244}). In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ serves as a \isi{placeholder} as shown in (\ref{Example_5.245}). Furthermore, the \isi{interrogative} is also used in one-word utterances.
A: word: ceritra	 gloss: tell
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: siapa	 gloss: who
D: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 440:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Sarles antar ___ Bolikarfus
Gloss (with missing item): Sarles bring ___ Bolikarfus
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Sarles gave a ride to, who-is-it, Bolikarfus’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the identity of human referents. Its pronominal uses are illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.233}) to (\ref{Example_5.240}), its adnominal uses in (\ref{Example_5.241}) and (\ref{Example_5.242}), and its predicative uses in (\ref{Example_5.243}) and (\ref{Example_5.244}). In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ serves as a \isi{placeholder} as shown in (\ref{Example_5.245}). Furthermore, the \isi{interrogative} is also used in one-word utterances.
A: word: siapa	 gloss: who
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
D: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 441:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): e, ___ suru kam minum~minum di sini?
Gloss (with missing item): hey ___ order 2PL RDP~drink at L.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘hey, who told you to keep drinking here’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs in all syntactic positions, as shown (\ref{Example_5.233}) to (\ref{Example_5.240}), typically remaining in-situ. In the \isi{verbal clause} in (\ref{Example_5.233}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot. In the corpus, however, verbal clauses with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the subject slot are rare. Typically, speakers use equative nominal clauses when they want to question the identity of the clausal subject. In such nonverbal clauses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot while a headless relative clause takes the predicate slot. This is shown with the elicited contrastive example in (\ref{Example_5.234}). In this equative clause, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is the subject, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang suru {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ ordered {\ldots}’ is the predicate. Likewise in (\ref{Example_5.235}), the \isi{interrogative} takes the subject slot while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang datang {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ came {\ldots}’ takes the predicate slot.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.168} Alternatively, as one anonymous reviewer points out, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.234}) and (\ref{Example_5.235}) the typical subject-predicate word order is inverted and that \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ does not take the subject but the predicate slot, whereas the relative clause introduced with \textitbf{yang} ‘\textsc{rel}’ takes the subject slot.
A: word: tinggal	 gloss: stay
B: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
C: word: siapa	 gloss: who
D: word: mantang	 gloss: former
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 442:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ pu mata yang buta?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ POSS eye REL be.blind
The English translation of this sentence is:‘whose eyes are blind?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs in all syntactic positions, as shown (\ref{Example_5.233}) to (\ref{Example_5.240}), typically remaining in-situ. In the \isi{verbal clause} in (\ref{Example_5.233}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot. In the corpus, however, verbal clauses with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the subject slot are rare. Typically, speakers use equative nominal clauses when they want to question the identity of the clausal subject. In such nonverbal clauses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot while a headless relative clause takes the predicate slot. This is shown with the elicited contrastive example in (\ref{Example_5.234}). In this equative clause, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is the subject, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang suru {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ ordered {\ldots}’ is the predicate. Likewise in (\ref{Example_5.235}), the \isi{interrogative} takes the subject slot while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang datang {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ came {\ldots}’ takes the predicate slot.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.168} Alternatively, as one anonymous reviewer points out, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.234}) and (\ref{Example_5.235}) the typical subject-predicate word order is inverted and that \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ does not take the subject but the predicate slot, whereas the relative clause introduced with \textitbf{yang} ‘\textsc{rel}’ takes the subject slot.
A: word: siapa	 gloss: who
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: barat	 gloss: west
D: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 443:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): siapa ___ mata yang buta?
Gloss (with missing item): who ___ eye REL be.blind
The English translation of this sentence is:‘whose eyes are blind?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ occurs in all syntactic positions, as shown (\ref{Example_5.233}) to (\ref{Example_5.240}), typically remaining in-situ. In the \isi{verbal clause} in (\ref{Example_5.233}), \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ takes the subject slot. In the corthe morpheme ___s, however, verbal clauses with \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ in the subject slot are rare. Typically, speakers use equative nominal clauses when they want to question the identity of the clausal subject. In such nonverbal clauses, \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ takes the subject slot while a headless relative clause takes the predicate slot. This is shown with the elicited contrastive example in (\ref{Example_5.234}). In this equative clause, \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ is the subject, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang suru {\ldots}} ‘(the one) who ordered {\ldots}’ is the predicate. Likewise in (\ref{Example_5.235}), the \isi{interrogative} takes the subject slot while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang datang {\ldots}} ‘(the one) who came {\ldots}’ takes the predicate slot.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.168} Alternatively, as one anonymous reviewer points out, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.234}) and (\ref{Example_5.235}) the typical subject-predicate word order is inverted and that \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ does not take the subject but the predicate slot, whereas the relative clause introduced with \textitbf{yang} ‘\textsc{rel}’ takes the subject slot.
A: word: gendong	 gloss: hold
B: word: pu	 gloss: POSS
C: word: hendro	 gloss: POSSR
D: word: pukul	 gloss: hit
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 445:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): e, ___ yang suru kam minum~minum di sini?
Gloss (with missing item): hey ___ REL order 2PL RDP~drink at L.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘hey, who (is the one) who told you to keep drinking here’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs in all syntactic positions, as shown (\ref{Example_5.233}) to (\ref{Example_5.240}), typically remaining in-situ. In the \isi{verbal clause} in (\ref{Example_5.233}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot. In the corpus, however, verbal clauses with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the subject slot are rare. Typically, speakers use equative nominal clauses when they want to question the identity of the clausal subject. In such nonverbal clauses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot while a headless relative clause takes the predicate slot. This is shown with the elicited contrastive example in (\ref{Example_5.234}). In this equative clause, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is the subject, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang suru {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ ordered {\ldots}’ is the predicate. Likewise in (\ref{Example_5.235}), the \isi{interrogative} takes the subject slot while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang datang {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ came {\ldots}’ takes the predicate slot.\footnote{\label{Footnote_5.168} Alternatively, as one anonymous reviewer points out, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.234}) and (\ref{Example_5.235}) the typical subject-predicate word order is inverted and that \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ does not take the subject but the predicate slot, whereas the relative clause introduced with \textitbf{yang} ‘\textsc{rel}’ takes the subject slot.

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 446:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): ___ REL come pick.up 1SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘who (is the one) who came (and) picked me up?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs in all syntactic positions, as shown (\ref{Example_5.233}) to (\ref{Example_5.240}), typically remaining in-situ. In such nonverbal clauses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot while a headless relative clause takes the predicate slot. This is shown with the elicited contrastive example in (\ref{Example_5.234}). In this equative clause, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is the subject, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang suru {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ ordered {\ldots}’ is the predicate. Question 449:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong cari ___
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL search ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘for whom are they looking?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Interrogative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also takes non-subject slots. In (\ref{Example_5.236}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the direct object slot in a mono\isi{transitive clause}, in (\ref{Example_5.237}) a direct object slot in a \isi{double-object} construction, in (\ref{Example_5.238}) the oblique object slot, and in (\ref{Example_5.239}) the peripheral adjunct slot.\footnote{Alternatively, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.238}) \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ does not take an oblique object but an adjunct slot.} In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the possessor’s identity in adnominal possessive constructions, as in (\ref{Example_5.240}).
A: word: mantang	 gloss: former
B: word: siapa	 gloss: who
C: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
D: word: mara	 gloss: feel.angry(.about)
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 450:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 451:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... ke mana?, ke kampung?, deng ___
Gloss (with missing item): ... to where to village with ___
The English translation of this sentence is:[Talking to her young son:] ‘[do you want to leave today?,] where to?, to the village?, with whom?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Interrogative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also takes non-subject slots. In (\ref{Example_5.236}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the direct object slot in a mono\isi{transitive clause}, in (\ref{Example_5.237}) a direct object slot in a \isi{double-object} construction, in (\ref{Example_5.238}) the oblique object slot, and in (\ref{Example_5.239}) the peripheral adjunct slot.\footnote{Alternatively, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.238}) \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ does not take an oblique object but an adjunct slot.} In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the possessor’s identity in adnominal possessive constructions, as in (\ref{Example_5.240}).
A: word: lari	 gloss: run
B: word: mantang	 gloss: former
C: word: siapa	 gloss: who
D: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 452:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): baru nanti minggu keduanya sembayang di ___
Gloss (with missing item): and.then very.soon week second:3POSSR worship at ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘then later in the second week (of this month), (we’ll) worship at whose (place)?’ (Lit. ‘at who’)

A: word: kursi	 gloss: chair
B: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
C: word: siapa	 gloss: who
D: word: mantang	 gloss: former
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 453:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Sentence (with missing item): ... ke mana?, ke kampung?, deng ___
Gloss (with missing item): ... to where to village with ___
The English translation of this sentence is:[Talking to her young son:] ‘[do you want to leave today?,] where to?, to the village?, with whom?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Interrogative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also takes non-subject slots. In (\ref{Example_5.236}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the direct object slot in a mono\isi{transitive clause}, in (\ref{Example_5.237}) a direct object slot in a \isi{double-object} construction, in (\ref{Example_5.238}) the oblique object slot, and in (\ref{Example_5.239}) the peripheral adjunct slot.\footnote{Alternatively, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.238}) \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ does not take an oblique object but an adjunct slot.} In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the possessor’s identity in adnominal possessive constructions, as in (\ref{Example_5.240}).
A: word: mantang	 gloss: former
B: word: hari	 gloss: day
C: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
D: word: siapa	 gloss: who
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 454:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ pu mata yang buta?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ POSS eye REL be.blind
The English translation of this sentence is:‘whose eyes are blind?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Interrogative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also takes non-subject slots. In (\ref{Example_5.236}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the direct object slot in a mono\isi{transitive clause}, in (\ref{Example_5.237}) a direct object slot in a \isi{double-object} construction, in (\ref{Example_5.238}) the oblique object slot, and in (\ref{Example_5.239}) the peripheral adjunct slot.\footnote{Alternatively, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.238}) \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ does not take an oblique object but an adjunct slot.} In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the possessor’s identity in adnominal possessive constructions, as in (\ref{Example_5.240}).
A: word: siapa	 gloss: who
B: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
C: word: bangung	 gloss: get.up
D: word: mantang	 gloss: former
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 456:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ siapa] biking sa jadi bingung?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ who make 1SG become be.confused
The English translation of this sentence is:‘which woman made me become confused?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As a nominal modifier, \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ takes the position of a modifying \isi{noun} which it replaces. This illustrated with the \isi{interrogative} clauses (\ref{Example_5.241}) and (\ref{Example_5.242}.
A: word: prempuang	 gloss: woman
B: word: siapa	 gloss: who
C: word: uang	 gloss: money
D: word: maytua	 gloss: wife
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 461:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ su gigit sa pu lutut
Gloss (with missing item): ___ already bite 1SG POSS knee
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what has bitten my knee?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the identity of nonhuman referents, name\-ly entities and events; in addition, it can question reason. The pronominal uses of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ are illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.246}) to (\ref{Example_5.251}), its adnominal uses in (\ref{Example_5.252}) and (\ref{Example_5.253}), and its predicative uses in (\ref{Example_5.254}) and (\ref{Example_5.255}). The \isi{interrogative} is also used as a \isi{placeholder} as shown in (\ref{Example_5.256}). Besides, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is also used in one-word utterances.
A: word: brapa	 gloss: several
B: word: cuma	 gloss: just
C: word: apa	 gloss: what
D: word: dang	 gloss: and
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 465:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): 3SG ask 1SG 2SG ___ what

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ questions the identity of nonhuman referents, name\-ly entities and events; in addition, it can question reason. The pronominal uses of \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ are illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.246}) to (\ref{Example_5.251}), its adnominal uses in (\ref{Example_5.252}) and (\ref{Example_5.253}), and its predicative uses in (\ref{Example_5.254}) and (\ref{Example_5.255}). C: word: marga	 gloss: clan
D: word: kampung	 gloss: village
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The pronominal uses of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ are illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.246}) to (\ref{Example_5.251}), its adnominal uses in (\ref{Example_5.252}) and (\ref{Example_5.253}), and its predicative uses in (\ref{Example_5.254}) and (\ref{Example_5.255}). Question 468:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ su gigit sa pu lutut
Gloss (with missing item): ___ already bite 1SG POSS knee
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what has bitten my knee?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs in all syntactic positions, as demonstrated in (\ref{Example_5.246}) to (\ref{Example_5.251}), always remaining in-situ. In the elicited \isi{verbal clause} in (\ref{Example_5.246}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot. While this construction is grammatically correct and acceptable, verbal clauses with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the subject slot are unattested in the corpus. Instead, speakers always use equative clauses when they want to question the identity of the clausal subject, similar to the questions formed with \textitbf{sithe morpheme ___} ‘who’ in (\ref{Example_5.234}) and (\ref{Example_5.235}) (§\ref{Para_5.8.1}). This is demonstrated with the contrastive equative clause in (\ref{Example_5.247}). In this example, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang su gigit {\ldots}} ‘(the one) who has already bitten {\ldots}’ takes the predicate slot.\footnote{Similar to the comment in Footnote \ref{Footnote_5.168} in §\ref{Para_5.8.1} (p. \pageref{Footnote_5.168}), one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.246}) the subject-predicate word order is inverted and that \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ fills the predicate rather than the subject slot, while the relative clause introduced with \textitbf{yang} ‘\textsc{rel}’ takes the subject slot.} (For details on relative clauses see §\ref{Para_14.3.2}.)
A: word: dang	 gloss: and
B: word: apa	 gloss: what
C: word: mandi	 gloss: bathe
D: word: brapa	 gloss: several
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 469:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

In the elicited \isi{verbal clause} in (\ref{Example_5.246}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot. While this construction is grammatically correct and acceptable, verbal clauses with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the subject slot are unattested in the corpus. Instead, speakers always use equative clauses when they want to question the identity of the clausal subject, similar to the questions formed with \textitbf{sithe morpheme ___} ‘who’ in (\ref{Example_5.234}) and (\ref{Example_5.235}) (§\ref{Para_5.8.1}). In this example, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the subject slot, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang su gigit {\ldots}} ‘(the one) who has already bitten {\ldots}’ takes the predicate slot.\footnote{Similar to the comment in Footnote \ref{Footnote_5.168} in §\ref{Para_5.8.1} (p. \pageref{Footnote_5.168}), one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.246}) the subject-predicate word order is inverted and that \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ fills the predicate rather than the subject slot, while the relative clause introduced with \textitbf{yang} ‘\textsc{rel}’ takes the subject slot.} (For details on relative clauses see §\ref{Para_14.3.2}.)
A: word: perna	 gloss: ever

C: word: apa	 gloss: what
