Question 471:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): e, ___ yang suru kam minum~minum di sini?
Gloss (with missing item): hey ___ REL order 2PL RDP~drink at L.PROX
The English translation of this sentence is:‘hey, who (is the one) who told you to keep drinking here’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ occurs in all syntactic positions, as demonstrated in (\ref{Example_5.246}) to (\ref{Example_5.251}), always remaining in-situ. In the elicited \isi{verbal clause} in (\ref{Example_5.246}), \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ takes the subject slot. While this construction is grammatically correct and acceptable, verbal clauses with \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ in the subject slot are unattested in the corpus. Instead, speakers always use equative clauses when they want to question the identity of the clausal subject, similar to the questions formed with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.234}) and (\ref{Example_5.235}) (§\ref{Para_5.8.1}). This is demonstrated with the contrastive equative clause in (\ref{Example_5.247}). In this example, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ takes the subject slot, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang su gigit {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ has already bitten {\ldots}’ takes the predicate slot.\footnote{Similar to the comment in Footnote \ref{Footnote_5.168} in §\ref{Para_5.8.1} (p. \pageref{Footnote_5.168}), one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.246}) the subject-predicate word order is inverted and that \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ fills the predicate rather than the subject slot, while the relative clause introduced with \textitbf{yang} ‘\textsc{rel}’ takes the subject slot.} (For details on relative clauses see §\ref{Para_14.3.2}.)
A: word: mantang	 gloss: former
B: word: jam	 gloss: hour
C: word: siapa	 gloss: who
D: word: siapa~siapa	 gloss: RDP~who
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 472:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): ___ REL come pick.up 1SG
The English translation of this sentence is:‘who (is the one) who came (and) picked me up?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ occurs in all syntactic positions, as demonstrated in (\ref{Example_5.246}) to (\ref{Example_5.251}), always remaining in-situ. While this construction is grammatically correct and acceptable, verbal clauses with \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ in the subject slot are unattested in the corpus. Instead, speakers always use equative clauses when they want to question the identity of the clausal subject, similar to the questions formed with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.234}) and (\ref{Example_5.235}) (§\ref{Para_5.8.1}). This is demonstrated with the contrastive equative clause in (\ref{Example_5.247}). In this example, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ takes the subject slot, while the headless relative clause \textitbf{yang su gigit {\ldots}} ‘(the one) its gloss ___ has already bitten {\ldots}’ takes the predicate slot.\footnote{Similar to the comment in Footnote \ref{Footnote_5.168} in §\ref{Para_5.8.1} (p. \pageref{Footnote_5.168}), one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.246}) the subject-predicate word order is inverted and that \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ fills the predicate rather than the subject slot, while the relative clause introduced with \textitbf{yang} ‘\textsc{rel}’ takes the subject slot.} (For details on relative clauses see §\ref{Para_14.3.2}.)

Question 475:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Gloss (with missing item): 2PL search ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘what are you looking for?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Interrogative \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also takes non-subject slots. In (\ref{Example_5.248}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ takes the direct object slot, in (\ref{Example_5.249}) the oblique object slot, and in (\ref{Example_5.250}) the peripheral adjunct slot.\footnote{Alternatively, one could argue that in (\ref{Example_5.249}) \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ does not take an oblique object but an adjunct slot.} Besides, speakers use \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ to question reasons or motives, as in (\ref{Example_5.251}).
A: word: pasti	 gloss: definitely
B: word: apa	 gloss: what
C: word: dang	 gloss: and
D: word: brapa	 gloss: several
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Its pronominal uses are illustrits gloss ___ed in (\ref{Example_5.257}) and (\ref{Example_5.258}), its adnominal uses in (\ref{Example_5.259}) and (\ref{Example_5.260}), and its prethe morpheme ___cits gloss ___ive uses in (\ref{Example_5.261}) to (\ref{Example_5.263}). A: word: terpengaru	 gloss: be.influenced
B: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
C: word: rabu	 gloss: Wednesday

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 489:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. A: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
B: word: apa	 gloss: what
C: word: bayi	 gloss: baby
D: word: ana	 gloss: child
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 490:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kalo {[ana} ___ {yang} {sa} {duduk} ceritra deng dia, itu ana itu, de hormat torang
Gloss (with missing item): if child ___ REL 1SG sit tell with 3SG D.DIST child D.DIST 3SG respect 1PL
The English translation of this sentence is:[Conversation about a certain teenager:] ‘as for which kid with whom I sit and talk with, that is that kid, she respects us’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, which’ questions locations and single items. Its pronominal uses are illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.257}) and (\ref{Example_5.258}), its adnominal uses in (\ref{Example_5.259}) and (\ref{Example_5.260}), and its predicative uses in (\ref{Example_5.261}) to (\ref{Example_5.263}). The \isi{interrogative} is also used in one-word utterances, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.264}).
A: word: mana	 gloss: where
B: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
C: word: tempat	 gloss: place
D: word: tunduk	 gloss: bow
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 496:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Sentence (with missing item): ko tinggal ___ mana?
Gloss (with missing item): 2SG stay ___ where
The English translation of this sentence is:‘where do you live?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses as the head of a \isi{noun} phrase, \textitbf{mana} ‘where, which’ questions locits gloss ___ions, as in (\ref{Example_5.257}) and (\ref{Example_5.258}). More specifically, it functions as the complement in a \isi{prepositional phrase} which is headed by a \isi{preposition} encothe morpheme ___ng locits gloss ___ion (details on prepositional phrases are provided in \chapref{Para_10}).
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: di	 gloss: at
C: word: juga	 gloss: also
D: word: adat	 gloss: tradition
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 500:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. A: word: tiga	 gloss: one
B: word: bayi	 gloss: baby
C: word: ana	 gloss: child

Question 504:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sabung mandi di ___
Gloss (with missing item): soap bathe at ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘where is (our) soap?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its predicative uses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, which’ occurs in prepositional predicates which question the subject’s location (for details on prepositional predicates see §\ref{Para_12.4}). Like predicate clauses with \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ (§\ref{Para_5.8.1}) and \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ (§\ref{Para_5.8.2}), prepositional predicates with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, which’ can take two positions. They can remain in-situ, following the clausal subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.261}). Alternatively, they can be fronted to the marked clause-initial position, its gloss ___ they stress the questioning of the subject’s location, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.262}). In the corpus, though, the \isi{preposition} is always omitted from fronted prepositional predicates, as in (\ref{Example_5.263}).
A: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
B: word: tempat	 gloss: place
C: word: mana	 gloss: where
D: word: glas	 gloss: glass
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 505:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): at ___ soap bathe

They can remain in-situ, following the clausal subject, as in (\ref{Example_5.261}). Alternatively, they can be fronted to the marked clause-initial position, its gloss ___ they stress the questioning of the subject’s location, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.262}). A: word: tempat	 gloss: place

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 508:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... adu, babi ni sa harus angkat ___
Gloss (with missing item): ... oh.no! pig D.PROX 1SG have.to lift ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[the pig was very big, I alone could not transport it, I thought,] ``oh no!, this pig, how am I going to transport it?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions manner or circumstance in the sense of ‘its gloss ___, what (is it) like’. The \isi{interrogative} has pronominal uses, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.265}) and (\ref{Example_5.267}), and predicative uses, as sits gloss ___n in (\ref{Example_5.268}) to (\ref{Example_5.271}). In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ has \isi{placeholder} uses as in (\ref{Example_5.272}). It also occurs in one-word utterances, as in (\ref{Example_5.273}) and (\ref{Example_5.274}).
A: word: mana	 gloss: where
B: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
C: word: sembu	 gloss: be.healed
D: word: apa	 gloss: what
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 509:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:[About bride-price children:] ‘she also asked (me), ``how can you give this child (of yours away)?'''

The \isi{interrogative} has pronominal uses, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.265}) and (\ref{Example_5.267}), and predicative uses, as sits gloss ___n in (\ref{Example_5.268}) to (\ref{Example_5.271}). It also occurs in one-word utterances, as in (\ref{Example_5.273}) and (\ref{Example_5.274}).
A: word: apa	 gloss: what
B: word: mana	 gloss: where
C: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
D: word: ini	 gloss: D.PROX
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 510:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong tida taw itu, Yesus itu, injil itu ___
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL NEG know D.DIST Jesus D.DIST Gospel D.DIST ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they don’t know, what’s-his-name, Jesus, (they don’t know) what the Gospel (is like)’ (Lit. ‘the gospel is how?’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions manner or circumstance in the sense of ‘its gloss ___, what (is it) like’. The \isi{interrogative} has pronominal uses, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.265}) and (\ref{Example_5.267}), and predicative uses, as sits gloss ___n in (\ref{Example_5.268}) to (\ref{Example_5.271}). In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ has \isi{placeholder} uses as in (\ref{Example_5.272}). It also occurs in one-word utterances, as in (\ref{Example_5.273}) and (\ref{Example_5.274}).
A: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
B: word: menangis	 gloss: cry
C: word: apa	 gloss: what
D: word: mana	 gloss: where
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 511:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): eh, ___ ipar?, sore, dari Jayapura?
Gloss (with missing item): hey! ___ sibling-in-law afternoon from Jayapura
The English translation of this sentence is:[Greeting a visitor:] ‘hey, how (is it going) brother-in-law?, (good) afternoon! (did you just get here) from Jayapura?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions manner or circumstance in the sense of ‘its gloss ___, what (is it) like’. The \isi{interrogative} has pronominal uses, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.265}) and (\ref{Example_5.267}), and predicative uses, as sits gloss ___n in (\ref{Example_5.268}) to (\ref{Example_5.271}). In addition, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ has \isi{placeholder} uses as in (\ref{Example_5.272}). It also occurs in one-word utterances, as in (\ref{Example_5.273}) and (\ref{Example_5.274}).
A: word: mana	 gloss: where
B: word: apa	 gloss: what
C: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
D: word: damay	 gloss: peace
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 515:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... adu, babi ni sa harus angkat ___
Gloss (with missing item): ... oh.no! pig D.PROX 1SG have.to lift ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[the pig was very big, I alone could not transport it, I thought,] ``oh no!, this pig, how am I going to transport it?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its pronominal uses, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can remain in-situ, in the unmarked clause-final position, or can occur in the marked clause-initial position. In the clause-final position, the \isi{interrogative} questions the specific manner of an event or activity such as the best way of transporting a pig in (\ref{Example_5.265}). In the clause-initial position, the scope of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is larger. Here it questions an entire proposition, as in (\ref{Example_5.266}) and (\ref{Example_5.267}), and not only a specific manner, as in (\ref{Example_5.265}). The example in (\ref{Example_5.267}) also sits gloss ___s that, depending on the context, fronted \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ also question reasons.
A: word: pake	 gloss: use
B: word: mana	 gloss: where
C: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
D: word: apa	 gloss: what
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 517:

Question 520:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dong tida taw itu, Yesus itu, injil itu ___
Gloss (with missing item): 3PL NEG know D.DIST Jesus D.DIST Gospel D.DIST ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘they don’t know, what’s-his-name, Jesus, (they don’t know) what the Gospel (is like)’ (Lit. ‘the gospel is how?’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When used predicatively, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can remain in-situ, as in (\ref{Example_5.268}) and (\ref{Example_5.270}), or can be fronted, as in (\ref{Example_5.269}) and (\ref{Example_5.271}). Similar to the predicative uses of the interrogatives discussed in the previous sections, the clause-final in-situ position is the unmarked one where the \isi{interrogative} is less prominent in comparison to the clause-initial subject, as sits gloss ___n in (\ref{Example_5.268}). When placed in the marked clause-initial position, by contrast, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ accentuates the questioning of the subject’s circumstance, as in (\ref{Example_5.269}). In addition, predicatively used \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ inquires about the well-being of one’s interlocutor(s) as in (\ref{Example_5.270}) and (\ref{Example_5.271}).
A: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
B: word: apa	 gloss: what
C: word: mana	 gloss: where
D: word: ceritra	 gloss: tell
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 522:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): ... be.difficult see evil.spirit D.DIST ___ form evil.spirit
The English translation of this sentence is:[About evil spirits:] ‘[but for us who ... already believe in Jesus, we can’t,] (for us) it is difficult to see that evil spirit, what the evil spirit’s face (is like)’ (Lit. ‘how (is) the evil spirit’s form?’)

In addition, predicatively used \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ inquires about the well-being of one’s interlocutor(s) as in (\ref{Example_5.270}) and (\ref{Example_5.271}).
A: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
B: word: apa	 gloss: what
C: word: ikang	 gloss: fish
D: word: mana	 gloss: where
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Gloss (with missing item): hey! ___ sibling-in-law afternoon from Jayapura
The English translation of this sentence is:[Greeting a visitor:] ‘hey, how (is it going) brother-in-law?, (good) afternoon! (did you just get here) from Jayapura?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When used predicatively, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can remain in-situ, as in (\ref{Example_5.268}) and (\ref{Example_5.270}), or can be fronted, as in (\ref{Example_5.269}) and (\ref{Example_5.271}). Similar to the predicative uses of the interrogatives discussed in the previous sections, the clause-final in-situ position is the unmarked one where the \isi{interrogative} is less prominent in comparison to the clause-initial subject, as sits gloss ___n in (\ref{Example_5.268}). When placed in the marked clause-initial position, by contrast, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ accentuates the questioning of the subject’s circumstance, as in (\ref{Example_5.269}). In addition, predicatively used \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ inquires about the well-being of one’s interlocutor(s) as in (\ref{Example_5.270}) and (\ref{Example_5.271}).
A: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
B: word: mana	 gloss: where
C: word: hampir	 gloss: almost
D: word: apa	 gloss: what
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 528:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): 1SG ask 1SG POSS father ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I asked my father, ``how (did this happen)?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In one-word utterances, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the circumstances of an event or state, as in (\ref{Example_5.273}), or signals lack of understanding as in (\ref{Example_5.274}).
A: word: apa	 gloss: what
B: word: dua	 gloss: two
C: word: mana	 gloss: where
D: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 531:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kasiang, sa ___ mandi deng dorang lagi e?
Gloss (with missing item): pity 1SG ___ bathe with 3PL again eh
The English translation of this sentence is:[About a sick boy:] ‘what a pity, when will I bathe with them (my friends) again, eh?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The \isi{interrogative} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions time. Always used pronominally, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ usually occurs in clause-initial position, as shown with its first and third occurrences in (\ref{Example_5.275}). Here, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ questions the temporal setting of the events or states expressed by the entire clause. When the temporal setting is less important, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs in clause-final position, as shown with the second \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ token in (\ref{Example_5.275}). Hence, the different positions of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ within the clause have functions which parallel those of the time-denoting nouns which the \isi{interrogative} replaces (see §\ref{Para_5.2.5}). Alternatively, but rarely, the \isi{interrogative} occurs between the subject and the predicate, as in (\ref{Example_5.276}). According to one consultant, this position of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is acceptable, although the semantics conveyed by this position are still ill understood.
A: word: mana	 gloss: where
B: word: kapang	 gloss: when
C: word: dlapang	 gloss: eight
D: word: seblum	 gloss: before
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Its pronominal uses are illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.277}) to (\ref{Example_5.279}), its predicative uses in (\ref{Example_5.280}), and its uses in one-word utterances in (\ref{Example_5.281}).
A: word: knapa	 gloss: why

C: word: karna	 gloss: because

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Typically, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is used pronominally. Most often it occurs in clause-initial position, as in (\ref{Example_5.277}). In clauses marked with an initial \isi{conjunction}, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ follows the \isi{conjunction} as in (\ref{Example_5.278}). Alternatively, but rarely, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ occurs between the subject and the predicate, as in (\ref{Example_5.279}). According to one consultant, this position of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is acceptable; the semantics of this position still need to be investigated, though.
A: word: ceritra	 gloss: tell
B: word: brapa	 gloss: several
C: word: karna	 gloss: because
D: word: knapa	 gloss: why
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 541:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ bulang dorang skola ka?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ month 3PL go.to.school or
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(for) how many months will they go to school?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In its \isi{interrogative} uses, the mid-range \isi{quantifier} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ receives the reading ‘how many’. It questions quantities of countable entities and, in combination with the mid-range \isi{quantifier} \textitbf{banyak} ‘many’, of non-countable entities. Its adnominal uses are shown in (\ref{Example_5.282}) to (\ref{Example_5.284}), and its predicative uses in (\ref{Example_5.286}) and (\ref{Example_5.289}).
A: word: banyak	 gloss: many
B: word: parapara	 gloss: platform
C: word: pagi	 gloss: morning
D: word: brapa	 gloss: several
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 548:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ bulang dorang skola ka?
Gloss (with missing item): ___ month 3PL go.to.school or
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(for) how many months will they go to school?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ functions as a nominal modifier which takes the position of the \isi{numeral} or \isi{quantifier} it replaces. Corresponding to the syntax of adnominally used numerals and quantifiers, it precedes or follows its head nominal, as in (\ref{Example_5.282}) to (\ref{Example_5.284}). In prehead position of countable referents, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ questions the absolute numbers of items denoted by the head nominals, as in (\ref{Example_5.282}). In posthead position of countable referents, it questions unique positions within series, as in (\ref{Example_5.283}). When following mass nouns, the \isi{interrogative} questions the nonnumeric amounts of its referents, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.284}). Like other quantifiers, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ is unattested in prehead position of mass nouns. If the referent’s identity is known from the context, the head nominal can be omitted, as with numerals and other quantifiers. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.285}), where the omitted head is \textitbf{rupia} ‘rupiah’. (Details on numerals and quantifiers are given in §\ref{Para_5.9} and §\ref{Para_5.10}, respectively.)
A: word: parapara	 gloss: platform
B: word: brapa	 gloss: several
C: word: banyak	 gloss: many
D: word: bukang	 gloss: NEG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 549:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): brapa ___ dorang skola ka?
Gloss (with missing item): several ___ 3PL go.to.school or
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(for) how many months will they go to school?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, \textitbf{brapa} ‘several, how many’ functions as a nominal modifier which takes the position of the \isi{numeral} or \isi{quantifier} it replaces. Corresponding to the syntax of adnominally used numerals and quantifiers, it precedes or follows its head nominal, as in (\ref{Example_5.282}) to (\ref{Example_5.284}). In prehead position of countable referents, \textitbf{brapa} ‘several, how many’ questions the absolute numbers of items denoted by the head nominals, as in (\ref{Example_5.282}). In posthead position of countable referents, it questions unique positions within series, as in (\ref{Example_5.283}). When following mass nouns, the \isi{interrogative} questions the nonnumeric amounts of its referents, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.284}). Like other quantifiers, \textitbf{brapa} ‘several, how many’ is unattested in prehead position of mass nouns. If the referent’s identity is known from the context, the head nominal can be omitted, as with numerals and other quantifiers. This is illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.285}), where the omitted head is \textitbf{rupia} ‘rupiah’. (Details on numerals and quantifiers are given in §\ref{Para_5.9} and §\ref{Para_5.10}, respectively.)
A: word: pulang	 gloss: go.home
B: word: taung	 gloss: year
C: word: kasi	 gloss: give
D: word: bulang	 gloss: month
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 555:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 560:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): bapa pu ana~ana ___
Gloss (with missing item): father POSS RDP~child ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘how many children do you (‘father’) have?’ (Lit. ‘father’s children are how many?’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The predicative uses of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ are shown in (\ref{Example_5.286}) to (\ref{Example_5.289}). Like \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ (§\ref{Para_5.8.1}), \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ (§\ref{Para_5.8.2}), and \textitbf{mana} ‘where, which’ (§\ref{Para_5.8.3}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ can remain in the unmarked clause-final position, as in (\ref{Example_5.286}) and \ref{Example_5.288}), or it can be fronted to the marked clause-initial position, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.287}) and \ref{Example_5.289}). Again, the fronting of the \isi{interrogative} serves to emphasize the questioning, namely of numeric quantities in (\ref{Example_5.287}), and of nonnumeric quantities in (\ref{Example_5.289}). These two examples are elicited, though, as interrogatives with fronted \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ are unattested in the corpus. (See also §\ref{Para_12.3} for details on \isi{numeral} and \isi{quantifier} predicate clauses.)
A: word: skali	 gloss: very
B: word: parapara	 gloss: platform
C: word: banyak	 gloss: many
D: word: brapa	 gloss: several
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Question 562:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): bapa pu ana~ana ___
Gloss (with missing item): father POSS RDP~child ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘how many children do you (‘father’) have?’ (Lit. ‘father’s children are how many?’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The predicative uses of \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ are shown in (\ref{Example_5.286}) to (\ref{Example_5.289}). Like \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’ (§\ref{Para_5.8.1}), \textitbf{apa} ‘what’ (§\ref{Para_5.8.2}), and \textitbf{mana} ‘where, which’ (§\ref{Para_5.8.3}), \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ can remain in the unmarked clause-final position, as in (\ref{Example_5.286}) and \ref{Example_5.288}), or it can be fronted to the marked clause-initial position, as in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.287}) and \ref{Example_5.289}). Again, the fronting of the \isi{interrogative} serves to emphasize the questioning, namely of numeric quantities in (\ref{Example_5.287}), and of nonnumeric quantities in (\ref{Example_5.289}). These two examples are elicited, though, as interrogatives with fronted \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___, how many’ are unattested in the corpus. (See also §\ref{Para_12.3} for details on \isi{numeral} and \isi{quantifier} predicate clauses.)
A: word: minyak	 gloss: oil
B: word: banyak	 gloss: many
C: word: parapara	 gloss: platform
D: word: brapa	 gloss: several
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 563:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): 1PL POSS money ___

Question 567:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ saja sa pu kaka de mo pulang Jayapura
Gloss (with missing item): ___ just 1SG POSS oSb 3SG want go.home Jayapura
The English translation of this sentence is:‘my older sibling wants to return to Jayapura, for whatever reason’ (Lit. ‘whyever’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, the \isi{indefinite} reading is achieved by juxtaposing the focus ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{saja} ‘just’ to the \isi{interrogative}, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.295}). In the corpus, this function of the interrogatives is only attested for \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’, and \textitbf{mana} ‘where, which’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.293}). The elicited respective examples in (\ref{Example_5.293}) to (\ref{Example_5.295}) illustrate, however, that \textitbf{bagemana} ‘how’, \textitbf{kapang} ‘when’, and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ can also have this function.
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: knapa	 gloss: why
C: word: brapa	 gloss: several
D: word: karna	 gloss: because
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 568:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): knapa ___ sa pu kaka de mo pulang Jayapura
Gloss (with missing item): why ___ 1SG POSS oSb 3SG want go.home Jayapura
The English translation of this sentence is:‘my older sibling wants to return to Jayapura, for whatever reason’ (Lit. ‘whyever’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, the \isi{indefinite} reading is achieved by juxtaposing the focus ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ to the \isi{interrogative}, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.295}). In the corpus, this function of the interrogatives is only attested for \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’, and \textitbf{mana} ‘where, which’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.293}). The elicited respective examples in (\ref{Example_5.293}) to (\ref{Example_5.295}) illustrate, however, that \textitbf{bagemana} ‘how’, \textitbf{kapang} ‘when’, and \textitbf{knapa} ‘why’ can also have this function.
A: word: hanya	 gloss: only
B: word: ajar	 gloss: teach
C: word: saja	 gloss: just
D: word: tiga~tiga	 gloss: RDP~three
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 569:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa tra mo taw!, ___ saja ko harus pigi skola!
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG NEG want know ___ just 2SG have.to go school
The English translation of this sentence is:[Addressing a child who does not want to go to school for various reasons:] ‘I don’t want to know!, you have to go to school, no matter what!’ (Lit. ‘however’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, the \isi{indefinite} reading is achieved by juxtaposing the focus ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{saja} ‘just’ to the \isi{interrogative}, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.295}). In the corpus, this function of the interrogatives is only attested for \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’, and \textitbf{mana} ‘where, which’, as sits gloss ___n in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.293}). The elicited respective examples in (\ref{Example_5.293}) to (\ref{Example_5.295}) illustrate, its gloss ___ever, that \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, \textitbf{kapang} ‘when’, and \textitbf{knapa} ‘why’ can also have this function.
A: word: apa	 gloss: what
B: word: mana	 gloss: where
C: word: lebi	 gloss: more
D: word: bagemana	 gloss: how
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 570:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sa tra mo taw!, bagemana ___ ko harus pigi skola!
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG NEG want know how ___ 2SG have.to go school
The English translation of this sentence is:[Addressing a child who does not want to go to school for various reasons:] ‘I don’t want to know!, you have to go to school, no matter what!’ (Lit. ‘however’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In Papuan Malay, the \isi{indefinite} reading is achieved by juxtaposing the focus ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ to the \isi{interrogative}, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.295}). In the corpus, this function of the interrogatives is only attested for \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’, and \textitbf{mana} ‘where, which’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.293}). A: word: sedikit~sedikit	 gloss: RDP~few
B: word: hanya	 gloss: only
C: word: ajar	 gloss: teach
D: word: saja	 gloss: just
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 574:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. In the corpus, this function of the interrogatives is only attested for \textitbf{siapa} ‘who’, \textitbf{apa} ‘what’, and \textitbf{mana} ‘where, which’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.290}) to (\ref{Example_5.293}). The elicited respective examples in (\ref{Example_5.293}) to (\ref{Example_5.295}) illustrate, however, that \textitbf{bagemana} ‘how’, \textitbf{kapang} ‘when’, and \textitbf{knapa} ‘why’ can also have this function.
A: word: saja	 gloss: just
B: word: ajar	 gloss: teach
C: word: kapang	 gloss: when

Question 575:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): mungking ___ orang mati
Gloss (with missing item): maybe ___ person die
The English translation of this sentence is:‘about five people died’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, cardinal numerals are used adnominally to enumerate entities. In this function they may precede or follow their head nominal. With a preposed \isi{numeral}, the \isi{noun} phrase signals the absolute number of items denoted by the head nominal, as in \textitbf{the morpheme ___ orang} ‘the morpheme ___ people’ in (\ref{Example_5.298}). Thereby the composite nature of countable referents is underlined. Posthead numerals, by contrast, express exhaustivity of \isi{definite} referents such as \textitbf{pace dua ini} ‘both of these men’ in (\ref{Example_5.299}), or denote unique positions within a series. (For details on the adnominal uses of numerals see §\ref{Para_8.3.1}.)
A: word: pace	 gloss: man
B: word: lima~lima	 gloss: RDP~five
C: word: lima	 gloss: five
D: word: enam	 gloss: six
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 576:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): mungking lima ___ mati
Gloss (with missing item): maybe five ___ die
The English translation of this sentence is:‘about five people died’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, cardinal numerals are used adnominally to enumerate entities. In this function they may precede or follow their head nominal. With a preposed \isi{numeral}, the \isi{noun} phrase signals the absolute number of items denoted by the head nominal, as in \textitbf{lima the morpheme ___} ‘lima people’ in (\ref{Example_5.298}). Thereby the composite nature of countable referents is underlined. Posthead numerals, by contrast, express exhaustivity of \isi{definite} referents such as \textitbf{pace dua ini} ‘both of these men’ in (\ref{Example_5.299}), or denote unique positions within a series. (For details on the adnominal uses of numerals see §\ref{Para_8.3.1}.)
A: word: manusia	 gloss: human.being
B: word: orang	 gloss: person
C: word: dorang	 gloss: 3PL
D: word: muka	 gloss: front
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 577:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ dua ini dong dua dari pedalamang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ two D.DIST 3PL two from interior
The English translation of this sentence is:‘both these men, the two of them are from the interior’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, cardinal numerals are used adnominally to enumerate entities. In this function they may precede or follow their head nominal. With a preposed \isi{numeral}, the \isi{noun} phrase signals the absolute number of items denoted by the head nominal, as in \textitbf{lima orang} ‘lima people’ in (\ref{Example_5.298}). Thereby the composite nature of countable referents is underlined. Posthead numerals, by contrast, express exhaustivity of \isi{definite} referents such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___ dua ini} ‘both of these men’ in (\ref{Example_5.299}), or denote unique positions within a series. (For details on the adnominal uses of numerals see §\ref{Para_8.3.1}.)
A: word: bapa	 gloss: father
B: word: mace	 gloss: woman
C: word: jam	 gloss: hour
D: word: pace	 gloss: man
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 578:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): pace ___ ini dong dua dari pedalamang
Gloss (with missing item): man ___ D.DIST 3PL two from interior
The English translation of this sentence is:‘both these men, the two of them are from the interior’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, cardinal numerals are used adnominally to enumerate entities. In this function they may precede or follow their head nominal. With a preposed \isi{numeral}, the \isi{noun} phrase signals the absolute number of items denoted by the head nominal, as in \textitbf{lima orang} ‘lima people’ in (\ref{Example_5.298}). Thereby the composite nature of countable referents is underlined. Posthead numerals, by contrast, express exhaustivity of \isi{definite} referents such as \textitbf{pace the morpheme ___ ini} ‘both of these men’ in (\ref{Example_5.299}), or denote unique positions within a series. (For details on the adnominal uses of numerals see §\ref{Para_8.3.1}.)
A: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
B: word: kedua	 gloss: second
C: word: satu~satu	 gloss: RDP~one
D: word: dua	 gloss: two
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 579:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): pace dua ___ dong dua dari pedalamang
Gloss (with missing item): man two ___ 3PL two from interior
The English translation of this sentence is:‘both these men, the two of them are from the interior’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most often, cardinal numerals are used adnominally to enumerate entities. In this function they may precede or follow their head nominal. With a preposed \isi{numeral}, the \isi{noun} phrase signals the absolute number of items denoted by the head nominal, as in \textitbf{lima orang} ‘lima people’ in (\ref{Example_5.298}). Thereby the composite nature of countable referents is underlined. Posthead numerals, by contrast, express exhaustivity of \isi{defthe morpheme ___te} referents such as \textitbf{pace dua the morpheme ___} ‘both of these men’ in (\ref{Example_5.299}), or denote unique positions within a series. (For details on the adnominal uses of numerals see §\ref{Para_8.3.1}.)
A: word: ini	 gloss: D.DIST
B: word: sana	 gloss: L.DIST
C: word: agak	 gloss: rather
D: word: begini	 gloss: like.this
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 582:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): di kalender de ___ blas
Gloss (with missing item): at calendar 3SG ___ teens
The English translation of this sentence is:‘in the calendar\bluebold...there are twelve (moons)’ (Lit. ‘it (the moon) is twelve’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In addition to their adnominal uses, numerals are used predicatively. In (\ref{Example_5.301}), for example, the \isi{numeral} \textitbf{the morpheme ___ blas} ‘twelve’ functions as a predicate that provides information about the numeric quantity of its subject \textitbf{de} ‘\textsc{3sg}’ (‘the moon’). (For details on \isi{numeral} predicate clauses see §\ref{Para_12.3}).
A: word: dua	 gloss: two
B: word: siduasi	 gloss: Siduas
C: word: kedua	 gloss: second
D: word: pace	 gloss: man
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 584:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In natural conversations, however, calculations occur only very rarely. Therefore, the following examples are elicited: the function of its gloss ___ition is presented in (\ref{Example_5.302}), subtraction in (\ref{Example_5.303}), multiplication in (\ref{Example_5.304}), and division in (\ref{Example_5.305}).
A: word: tamba	 gloss: add
B: word: diam	 gloss: be.quiet

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 588:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): saya {tida} bole {kasi} {sama} {bapa} {punya} {sodara} ana prempuang yang sa bilang ___ tiga
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG NEG may give to father POSS sibling child woman REL 1SG say ___ three
The English translation of this sentence is:[About bride-price children:] ‘I shouldn’t have given to father’s sibling the daughter that, as I said, was (my) third (child)’ (Lit. ‘number three’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay employs two strategies to express the notion of ordinal numerals. For kinship terms the concept of ordinal numerals is encoded by a ``NNum'' \isi{noun} phrase headed by the \isi{noun} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.306}) and (\ref{Example_5.307}). This \isi{noun} phrase ``\textitbf{the morpheme ___} Num'' gives the ordinal reading ``Num-th'' such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___ tiga} ‘third’ in (\ref{Example_5.306}) or \textitbf{the morpheme ___ empat} ‘fourth’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.307}).
A: word: nomor	 gloss: number
B: word: astronomi	 gloss: astronomy
C: word: apa	 gloss: what
D: word: ribu	 gloss: thousand
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 589:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. For kinship terms the concept of ordinal numerals is encoded by a ``NNum'' \isi{noun} phrase headed by the \isi{noun} \textitbf{nomor} ‘number’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.306}) and (\ref{Example_5.307}). This \isi{noun} phrase ``\textitbf{nomor} Num'' gives the ordinal reading ``Num-th'' such as \textitbf{nomor the morpheme ___} ‘third’ in (\ref{Example_5.306}) or \textitbf{nomor empat} ‘fourth’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.307}).

Question 596:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): saya {tida} bole {kasi} {sama} {bapa} {punya} {sodara} ana prempuang yang sa bilang ___ tiga
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG NEG may give to father POSS sibling child woman REL 1SG say ___ three
The English translation of this sentence is:[About bride-price children:] ‘I shouldn’t have given to father’s sibling the daughter that, as I said, was (my) third (child)’ (Lit. ‘number three’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: According to one consultant, the strategy presented in (\ref{Example_5.306}) and (\ref{Example_5.307}) is the inherited Papuan Malay strategy to express the notion of ordinal its gloss ___s. This strategy used to be employed not only for kinship terms but for countable nouns in general. With the increasing influence of \ili{Standard Indonesian}, however, Papuan Malay speakers have started employing ordinal its gloss ___s of Indonesian origins more frequently. Hence, in the corpus the ordinal its gloss ___s for countable nouns other than kinship terms are of \ili{Standard Indonesian} origins, such as \textitbf{kedua} ‘second’ in (\ref{Example_5.308}) or \textitbf{ketiga} ‘third’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.309}).\footnote{In \ili{Standard Indonesian}, ordinal numerals, with the exception of \textitbf{pertama} ‘first’, are derived by prefixing \textitbf{ke-} to the cardinal its gloss ___ (for details see \citealt[293]{Mintz.1994}).}
A: word: skali	 gloss: very
B: word: ribu	 gloss: thousand
C: word: astronomi	 gloss: astronomy
D: word: nomor	 gloss: number
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 597:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): saya {tida} bole {kasi} {sama} {bapa} {punya} {sodara} ana prempuang yang sa bilang nomor ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG NEG may give to father POSS sibling child woman REL 1SG say number ___
The English translation of this sentence is:[About bride-price children:] ‘I shouldn’t have given to father’s sibling the daughter that, as I said, was (my) third (child)’ (Lit. ‘number three’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: According to one consultant, the strategy presented in (\ref{Example_5.306}) and (\ref{Example_5.307}) is the inherited Papuan Malay strategy to express the notion of ordinal numbers. This strategy used to be employed not only for kinship terms but for countable nouns in general. With the increasing influence of \ili{Standard Indonesian}, however, Papuan Malay speakers have started employing ordinal numbers of Indonesian origins more frequently. Hence, in the corpus the ordinal numbers for countable nouns other than kinship terms are of \ili{Standard Indonesian} origins, such as \textitbf{kedua} ‘second’ in (\ref{Example_5.308}) or \textitbf{kethe morpheme ___} ‘third’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.309}).\footnote{In \ili{Standard Indonesian}, ordinal numerals, with the exception of \textitbf{pertama} ‘first’, are derived by prefixing \textitbf{ke-} to the cardinal number (for details see \citealt[293]{Mintz.1994}).}
A: word: tiga	 gloss: three
B: word: tiga~tiga	 gloss: RDP~three
C: word: hanya	 gloss: only
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 598:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Aleks ini sa pu tete pu ade ___ empat
Gloss (with missing item): Aleks D.PROX 1SG POSS grandfather POSS ySb ___ four
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Aleks here is my grandfather’s fourth youngest sibling’ (Lit. ‘number four’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: According to one consultant, the strategy presented in (\ref{Example_5.306}) and (\ref{Example_5.307}) is the inherited Papuan Malay strategy to express the notion of ordinal its gloss ___s. This strategy used to be employed not only for kinship terms but for countable nouns in general. With the increasing influence of \ili{Standard Indonesian}, however, Papuan Malay speakers have started employing ordinal its gloss ___s of Indonesian origins more frequently. Hence, in the corpus the ordinal its gloss ___s for countable nouns other than kinship terms are of \ili{Standard Indonesian} origins, such as \textitbf{kedua} ‘second’ in (\ref{Example_5.308}) or \textitbf{ketiga} ‘third’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.309}).\footnote{In \ili{Standard Indonesian}, ordinal numerals, with the exception of \textitbf{pertama} ‘first’, are derived by prefixing \textitbf{ke-} to the cardinal its gloss ___ (for details see \citealt[293]{Mintz.1994}).}
A: word: astronomi	 gloss: astronomy
B: word: murit	 gloss: pupil
C: word: nomor	 gloss: number
D: word: ribu	 gloss: thousand
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 599:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): Aleks ini sa pu tete pu ade nomor ___
Gloss (with missing item): Aleks D.PROX 1SG POSS grandfather POSS ySb number ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Aleks here is my grandfather’s fourth youngest sibling’ (Lit. ‘number four’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: According to one consultant, the strategy presented in (\ref{Example_5.306}) and (\ref{Example_5.307}) is the inherited Papuan Malay strategy to express the notion of ordinal numbers. This strategy used to be employed not only for kinship terms but for countable nouns in general. With the increasing influence of \ili{Standard Indonesian}, however, Papuan Malay speakers have started employing ordinal numbers of Indonesian origins more frequently. Hence, in the corpus the ordinal numbers for countable nouns other than kinship terms are of \ili{Standard Indonesian} origins, such as \textitbf{kedua} ‘second’ in (\ref{Example_5.308}) or \textitbf{ketiga} ‘third’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.309}).\footnote{In \ili{Standard Indonesian}, ordinal numerals, with the exception of \textitbf{pertama} ‘first’, are derived by prefixing \textitbf{ke-} to the cardinal number (for details see \citealt[293]{Mintz.1994}).}
A: word: empat	 gloss: four
B: word: januari	 gloss: January
C: word: tempat	 gloss: place
D: word: lima	 gloss: five
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 600:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: According to one consultant, the strategy presented in (\ref{Example_5.306}) and (\ref{Example_5.307}) is the inherited Papuan Malay strategy to express the notion of ordinal numbers. This strategy used to be employed not only for kinship terms but for countable nouns in general. With the increasing influence of \ili{Standard Indonesian}, however, Papuan Malay speakers have started employing ordinal numbers of Indonesian origins more frequently. Hence, in the corpus the ordinal numbers for countable nouns other than kinship terms are of \ili{Standard Indonesian} origins, such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in (\ref{Example_5.308}) or \textitbf{ketiga} ‘third’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.309}).\footnote{In \ili{Standard Indonesian}, ordinal numerals, with the exception of \textitbf{pertama} ‘first’, are derived by prefixing \textitbf{ke-} to the cardinal number (for details see \citealt[293]{Mintz.1994}).}

B: word: kedua	 gloss: second

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 601:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: According to one consultant, the strategy presented in (\ref{Example_5.306}) and (\ref{Example_5.307}) is the inherited Papuan Malay strategy to express the notion of ordinal numbers. This strategy used to be employed not only for kinship terms but for countable nouns in general. With the increasing influence of \ili{Standard Indonesian}, however, Papuan Malay speakers have started employing ordinal numbers of Indonesian origins more frequently. Hence, in the corpus the ordinal numbers for countable nouns other than kinship terms are of \ili{Standard Indonesian} origins, such as \textitbf{kedua} ‘second’ in (\ref{Example_5.308}) or \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_5.309}).\footnote{In \ili{Standard Indonesian}, ordinal numerals, with the exception of \textitbf{pertama} ‘first’, are derived by prefixing \textitbf{ke-} to the cardinal number (for details see \citealt[293]{Mintz.1994}).}

Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 602:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tong tiga cari jalang ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1PL three search walk ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the three of us looked for a path (through the river) one-by-one’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Distributive numerals express that “a property or action” applies “to the individual members of a group, as opposed to the group as a whole” {\citep[154]{Crystal.2008}}. In Papuan Malay, this notion of ``one by one'' or ``two by two'' is expressed through \isi{reduplication} of the \isi{numeral}. This is illustrated with \textitbf{satu{\Tilde}satu} ‘one by one’ or ‘in groups of one each’ in (\ref{Example_5.310}), and with \textitbf{dua{\Tilde}dua} ‘two by two’ or ‘in groups of two’ in (\ref{Example_5.311}). (See also §\ref{Para_4.2.4}.)
A: word: ade	 gloss: LIG
B: word: satu~satu	 gloss: RDP~one
C: word: satu	 gloss: one
D: word: apa~apa	 gloss: RDP~what
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 603:

In Papuan Malay, this notion of ``one by one'' or ``two by two'' is expressed through \isi{reduplication} of the \isi{numeral}. Question 607:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ada ___ satu di situ
Gloss (with missing item): exist ___ one at L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(there) is a certain younger sibling there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In addition to its enumerating function in postposed position, adnominally used \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ is employed to encode “specific \isi{indefiniteness}”, using Crystal’s (\citeyear*[444]{Crystal.2008}) terminology. That is, in \textsc{nn}um-\textsc{np}s adnominal \textitbf{satu} ‘one’ denotes specific but nonidentifiable referents, giving the specific \isi{indefinite} reading \textscItal{n} \textitbf{satu} ‘a certain \textsc{n}’. The specific \isi{indefinite} referent may be animate human such as \textitbf{the morpheme ___ satu} ‘a certain younger sibling’ in (\ref{Example_5.312}) or inanimate such as \textitbf{kampung satu} ‘a certain village’ in (\ref{Example_5.313}). The referent of \textitbf{ojek satu} in (\ref{Example_5.313}) can be interpreted as the animate referent ‘motorbike taxi driver’, or as the inanimate referent ‘motorbike taxi’.
A: word: mama-ade	 gloss: aunt
B: word: ade	 gloss: ySb
C: word: kadang	 gloss: sometimes
D: word: rajing	 gloss: be.diligent
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 608:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ada ade ___ di situ
Gloss (with missing item): exist ySb ___ at L.MED
The English translation of this sentence is:‘(there) is a certain younger sibling there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In addition to its enumerating function in postposed position, adnominally used \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is employed to encode “specific \isi{indefiniteness}”, using Crystal’s (\citeyear*[444]{Crystal.2008}) terminology. That is, in \textsc{nn}um-\textsc{np}s adnominal \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ denotes specific but nonidentifiable referents, giving the specific \isi{indefinite} reading \textscItal{n} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘a certain \textsc{n}’. The specific \isi{indefinite} referent may be animate human such as \textitbf{ade the morpheme ___} ‘a certain younger sibling’ in (\ref{Example_5.312}) or inanimate such as \textitbf{kampung the morpheme ___} ‘a certain village’ in (\ref{Example_5.313}). The referent of \textitbf{ojek the morpheme ___} in (\ref{Example_5.313}) can be interpreted as the animate referent ‘motorbike taxi driver’, or as the inanimate referent ‘motorbike taxi’.
A: word: dulu	 gloss: first
B: word: mana	 gloss: where
C: word: satu	 gloss: one
D: word: satu~satu	 gloss: RDP~one
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 609:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ jam
Gloss (with missing item): ___ hour
The English translation of this sentence is:‘half an hour’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Noun phrases with adnominal quantifiers have syntactic properties similar to those with adnominal numerals, as illustrated in (\ref{Example_5.314}) to (\ref{Example_5.322}). Noun phrases with prehead quantifiers (``\textsc{q}t\textsc{n-np}'') express nonnumeric amounts or quantities of the items indicated by their head nominals. Thereby, the composite nature of countable referents is accentuated. Posthead quantifiers, by contrast, may denote exhaustivity of \isi{indefinite} referents or signal unknown positions within series or sequences; they modify countable as well as uncountable referents.
A: word: tenga	 gloss: middle
B: word: bagiang	 gloss: part
C: word: besar	 gloss: be.big
D: word: stenga	 gloss: half
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 610:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ jam
Gloss (with missing item): ___ hour
The English translation of this sentence is:‘half an hour’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The data in (\ref{Example_5.314}) to (\ref{Example_5.322}) shows that not all quantifiers occur in all positions. Only five quantifiers occur in either pre- or posthead position, namely \textitbf{banyak} ‘many’, \textitbf{brapa} ‘several’, \textitbf{masing-masing} ‘each’, \textitbf{sedikit} ‘few’, and \textitbf{smua} ‘all’. While \textitbf{banyak} ‘many’, \textitbf{sedikit} ‘few’, and \textitbf{smua} ‘all’ can modify both count and mass nouns, \textitbf{brapa} ‘several’ and \textitbf{masing-masing} ‘each’ only modify count nouns. The remaining four quantifiers occur in prehead position only, namely \textitbf{segala} ‘all’, \textitbf{sembarang} ‘any (kind of)’, \textitbf{(se)tiap} ‘every’, and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’. These quantifiers modify count nouns only.
A: word: tenga	 gloss: middle
B: word: stenga	 gloss: half
C: word: langsung	 gloss: immediately
D: word: bagiang	 gloss: part
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 611:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ Ø mati di, e, di di pulow~pulow, banyak Ø mati di lautang
Gloss (with missing item): ___ ... die at uh at at RDP~island many ... die at ocean
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[there are many Papuans who died,] many (Papuans) died on, uh, on on the islands, many (Papuans) died on the ocean’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When the identity of the referent was established earlier or can be deduced from the context, the head nominal can be omitted. Not all quantifiers, however, are used in \isi{noun} phrases with elided head nominal. Attested are only \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ as in (\ref{Example_5.323}), \textitbf{brapa} ‘several’ as in (\ref{Example_5.324}), \textitbf{sedikit} ‘few’ as in (\ref{Example_5.325}), and \textitbf{smua} ‘all’ as in (\ref{Example_5.326}).
A: word: banyak	 gloss: many
B: word: brapa	 gloss: several
C: word: banyak~banyak	 gloss: RDP~many
D: word: situ	 gloss: L.MED
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Attested are only \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ as in (\ref{Example_5.323}), \textitbf{brapa} ‘several’ as in (\ref{Example_5.324}), \textitbf{sedikit} ‘few’ as in (\ref{Example_5.325}), and \textitbf{smua} ‘all’ as in (\ref{Example_5.326}).

Question 613:

Not its gloss ___ quantifiers, however, are used in \isi{noun} phrases with elided head nominal. Attested are only \textitbf{banyak} ‘many’ as in (\ref{Example_5.323}), \textitbf{brapa} ‘several’ as in (\ref{Example_5.324}), \textitbf{sedikit} ‘few’ as in (\ref{Example_5.325}), and \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ as in (\ref{Example_5.326}).
