Question 614:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ... picaang juga ___
Gloss (with missing item): ... splinter also ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘[at the beach] there are also lots (of) splinters’ (Lit. ‘the splinters (are) also many’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In addition to their adnominal uses, quantifies are also used predicatively. In (\ref{Example_5.327}), for instance, predicatively used \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ conveys information about the nonnumeric quantity of its subject \textitbf{picaang} ‘splinter’. (For details on \isi{quantifier} predicate clauses see §\ref{Para_12.3}).
A: word: banyak~banyak	 gloss: RDP~many
B: word: brapa	 gloss: several
C: word: pikir	 gloss: think
D: word: banyak	 gloss: many
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 615:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tong tiga cari jalang ___
Gloss (with missing item): 1PL three search walk ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘the three of us looked for a path (through the river) one-by-one’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The notion of ``little by little'' or ``many by many'' is expressed through \isi{reduplication} of the \isi{quantifier}, similar to the formation of distributive numerals presented in (\ref{Example_5.310}) and (\ref{Example_5.311}) (§\ref{Para_5.9.3}; see also §\ref{Para_4.2.4}). Distributive quantifiers denote events that affect an \isi{indefinite} number of members of a group or set at different points in time. In (\ref{Example_5.328}), for example, \textitbf{uang banyak{\Tilde}banyak} denotes ‘sets of lots of money’, while in (\ref{Example_5.329}) \textitbf{sedikit{\Tilde}sedikit} designates ‘sets of little (food)’.
A: word: dia	 gloss: 3SG
B: word: satu~satu	 gloss: RDP~one
C: word: satu	 gloss: one
D: word: apa~apa	 gloss: RDP~what
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 616:

Question 620:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Gloss (with missing item): father send ___ RDP~many
The English translation of this sentence is:[Phone conversation:] ‘father send lots of money at regular intervals’ (Lit. ‘lots by lots of money’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The notion of ``little by little'' or ``many by many'' is expressed through \isi{reduplication} of the \isi{quantifier}, similar to the formation of distributive numerals presented in (\ref{Example_5.310}) and (\ref{Example_5.311}) (§\ref{Para_5.9.3}; see also §\ref{Para_4.2.4}). Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 622:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. The English translation of this sentence is:[About organizing the food distribution during a retreat:] ‘they haven’t yet filled (their plates), moreover they’ll fill (their plates only) with little (food), right?’ (Lit. ‘little by little (food)’)
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The notion of ``little by little'' or ``many by many'' is expressed through \isi{reduplication} of the \isi{quantifier}, similar to the formation of distributive numerals presented in (\ref{Example_5.310}) and (\ref{Example_5.311}) (§\ref{Para_5.9.3}; see also §\ref{Para_4.2.4}). B: word: banyak~banyak	 gloss: RDP~many
C: word: sedikit	 gloss: few
D: word: sedikit~sedikit	 gloss: RDP~few

Question 623:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sebentar pasti hujang karna awang hitam ___
Gloss (with missing item): in.a.moment definitely rain because cloud be.black ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘in a bit it will certainly rain because of the black clouds, right?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay has three tags, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, \textitbf{e} ‘eh?’ and \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’, as shown in (\ref{Example_5.330}) the morpheme ___ (\ref{Example_5.336}). They are short questions that are “tagged” onthe morpheme ___ the end of an utterance and have a rising inthe morpheme ___nation. Their main function is the morpheme ___ confirm what is being said.
A: word: to	 gloss: right?
B: word: blas	 gloss: teens
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: komputer	 gloss: computer
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 624:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): hari minggu ko ke ruma ___ ke Siduas punya ruma e?
Gloss (with missing item): day Sunday 2SG to house ___ to Siduas POSS house eh
The English translation of this sentence is:‘on Sunday you go to the house, eh?!, to Siduas’ house, eh?!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Papuan Malay has thrthe morpheme ___the morpheme ___ tags, \tthe morpheme ___xtitbf{to} ‘right?’, \tthe morpheme ___xtitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘the morpheme ___h?’ and \tthe morpheme ___xtitbf{kang} ‘you know?’, as shown in (\rthe morpheme ___f{Examplthe morpheme ____5.330}) to (\rthe morpheme ___f{Examplthe morpheme ____5.336}). Ththe morpheme ___y arthe morpheme ___ short quthe morpheme ___stions that arthe morpheme ___ “taggthe morpheme ___d” onto ththe morpheme ___ the morpheme ___nd of an uttthe morpheme ___rancthe morpheme ___ and havthe morpheme ___ a rising intonation. Ththe morpheme ___ir main function is to confirm what is bthe morpheme ___ing said.
A: word: perna	 gloss: ever
B: word: blas	 gloss: teens
C: word: sentu	 gloss: touch
D: word: e	 gloss: eh
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 625:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): day Sunday 2SG to house eh to Siduas POSS house ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘on Sunday you go to the house, eh?!, to Siduas’ house, eh?!’

Ththe morpheme ___y arthe morpheme ___ short quthe morpheme ___stions that arthe morpheme ___ “taggthe morpheme ___d” onto ththe morpheme ___ the morpheme ___nd of an uttthe morpheme ___rancthe morpheme ___ and havthe morpheme ___ a rising intonation. Question 626:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): sebentar pasti hujang karna awang hitam ___
Gloss (with missing item): in.a.moment definitely rain because cloud be.black ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘in a bit it will certainly rain because of the black clouds, right?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: With \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, speakers ask for agreement or disagreement, as in (\ref{Example_5.330}) and (\ref{Example_5.331}),\footnote{The \isi{tag} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is a loanword from \ili{Dutch}, which uses \textitbf{the morpheme ___ch} ‘its gloss ___’ as a \isi{tag}.} while with \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’ speakers assume their interlocuthe morpheme ___rs the morpheme ___ agree with their statements, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}) and (\ref{Example_5.332}). Speakers use \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ at the end of an utterance. When employing \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’, by contrast, they usually continue their utterance and add further information related the morpheme ___ the issue under discussion. In this context, \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’ quite often co-occurs with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}).
A: word: net	 gloss: (sport.)net
B: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
C: word: natanael	 gloss: Natanael
D: word: to	 gloss: right?
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 627:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de suda tidor, ___ dia hosa to?
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG already sleep ___ 3SG pant right?
The English translation of this sentence is:‘she was already sleeping, you know?, she has breathing difficulties, right?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: With \textitbf{to} ‘right?’, speakers ask for agreement or disagreement, as in (\ref{Example_5.330}) and (\ref{Example_5.331}),\footnote{The \isi{tag} \textitbf{to} ‘right?’ is a loanword from \ili{Dutch}, which uses \textitbf{toch} ‘right?’ as a \isi{tag}.} while with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘you know?’ speakers assume their interlocutors to agree with their statements, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}) and (\ref{Example_5.332}). Speakers use \textitbf{to} ‘right?’ at the end of an utterance. When employing \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘you know?’, by contrast, they usually continue their utterance and add further information related to the issue under discussion. In this context, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘you know?’ quite often co-occurs with \textitbf{to} ‘right?’, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}).
A: word: ikang	 gloss: fish
B: word: kang	 gloss: you.know
C: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
D: word: taw	 gloss: know
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 628:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): 3SG already sleep you.know 3SG pant ___

Speakers use \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ at the end of an utterance. When employing \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’, by contrast, they usually continue their utterance and add further information related the morpheme ___ the issue under discussion. In this context, \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’ quite often co-occurs with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}).
A: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
B: word: indonesia	 gloss: Indonesia

D: word: to	 gloss: right?
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 631:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Correct Answer: C

Question 632:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de suda tidor, ___ dia hosa to?
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG already sleep ___ 3SG pant right?
The English translation of this sentence is:‘she was already sleeping, you know?, she has breathing difficulties, right?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: With \textitbf{to} ‘right?’, speakers ask for agreement or disagreement, as in (\ref{Example_5.330}) and (\ref{Example_5.331}),\footnote{The \isi{tag} \textitbf{to} ‘right?’ is a loanword from \ili{Dutch}, which uses \textitbf{toch} ‘right?’ as a \isi{tag}.} while with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘you know?’ speakers assume their interlocutors to agree with their statements, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}) and (\ref{Example_5.332}). Speakers use \textitbf{to} ‘right?’ at the end of an utterance. When employing \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘you know?’, by contrast, they usually continue their utterance and add further information related to the issue under discussion. In this context, \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘you know?’ quite often co-occurs with \textitbf{to} ‘right?’, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}).
A: word: ekor	 gloss: tail
B: word: taw	 gloss: know
C: word: kang	 gloss: you.know
D: word: ikang	 gloss: fish
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 633:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): de suda tidor, kang?, dia hosa ___
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG already sleep you.know 3SG pant ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘she was already sleeping, you know?, she has breathing difficulties, right?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: With \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, speakers ask for agreement or disagreement, as in (\ref{Example_5.330}) and (\ref{Example_5.331}),\footnote{The \isi{tag} \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ is a loanword from \ili{Dutch}, which uses \textitbf{the morpheme ___ch} ‘its gloss ___’ as a \isi{tag}.} while with \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’ speakers assume their interlocuthe morpheme ___rs the morpheme ___ agree with their statements, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}) and (\ref{Example_5.332}). Speakers use \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’ at the end of an utterance. When employing \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’, by contrast, they usually continue their utterance and add further information related the morpheme ___ the issue under discussion. In this context, \textitbf{kang} ‘you know?’ quite often co-occurs with \textitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘its gloss ___’, as in (\ref{Example_5.331}).
A: word: pukul	 gloss: hit
B: word: guntur	 gloss: thunder
C: word: tong	 gloss: 1PL
D: word: to	 gloss: right?
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 634:

Its usthe morpheme ___s sthe morpheme ___the morpheme ___m to bthe morpheme ___ morthe morpheme ___ rthe morpheme ___strictthe morpheme ___d, though, than thosthe morpheme ___ of ththe morpheme ___ two oththe morpheme ___r tags. Spthe morpheme ___akthe morpheme ___rs tthe morpheme ___nd to the morpheme ___mploy \tthe morpheme ___xtitbf{the morpheme ___} ‘the morpheme ___h?’ as a markthe morpheme ___r of assurancthe morpheme ___, that is, whthe morpheme ___n ththe morpheme ___y want to givthe morpheme ___ assurancthe morpheme ___, as in (\rthe morpheme ___f{Examplthe morpheme ____5.333}), or ask for assurancthe morpheme ___ as in (\rthe morpheme ___f{Examplthe morpheme ____5.334}) and (\rthe morpheme ___f{Examplthe morpheme ____5.335}). Question 635:

Question 640:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): pace Oktofernus de, ___ masi urus dorang sana
Gloss (with missing item): man Oktofernus 3SG ___ still arrange 3PL L.DIST
The English translation of this sentence is:‘Mr. Oktofernus, uh, was still taking care of them over there’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Hesitation markers, by contrast, have no lexical meaning. As vocal indicators they mainly serve to fill pathe morpheme ___ses. The main Papthe morpheme ___an Malay \isi{hesitation marker} is \textitbf{e(m)} ‘the morpheme ___h’, as in (\ref{Example_5.337}); alternative realizations are \textitbf{the morpheme ___(m)} ‘the morpheme ___h’ as in (\ref{Example_5.338}), or \textitbf{a(m)}, \textitbf{mmm}, or \textitbf{nnn} ‘the morpheme ___h’.
A: word: baku	 gloss: RECP
B: word: tajam	 gloss: be.sharp
C: word: u	 gloss: uh
D: word: sungay	 gloss: river
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 646:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3PL feel.angry(.about) eh
The English translation of this sentence is:‘oh!, they’ll be angry, eh?’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Examples the morpheme ___f primary interjectithe morpheme ___ns in natural discthe morpheme ___urse are presented in (\ref{Example_5.339}) tthe morpheme ___ (\ref{Example_5.341}).
A: word: dong	 gloss: 3PL
B: word: sini	 gloss: L.PROX
C: word: adu	 gloss: oh.no!
D: word: o	 gloss: oh!
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 647:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ sa bulang oktober sa pu alpa cuma dua saja
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 1SG month October 1SG POSS be.absent just two just
The English translation of this sentence is:‘my goodness!, in October I, I had just only two absences’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Examples of secondary interjections are presented in (\ref{Example_5.342}) to (\ref{Example_5.344}).
A: word: hormat	 gloss: respect
B: word: damay	 gloss: peace
C: word: kamar	 gloss: room
D: word: lebi	 gloss: more
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 649:
You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. A: word: iii	 gloss: oh!
B: word: ada	 gloss: exist
C: word: pake	 gloss: use
D: word: pak	 gloss: bang!
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

You are a linguist specializing in Papuan Malay. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Gloss (with missing item): 1SG hit 3SG three time bang! bang! ___
The English translation of this sentence is:‘I hit him three times, bang!, bang!, bang!’
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Examples of onomatopoeic words in context are presented in (\ref{Example_5.345}) to (\ref{Example_5.347}).

B: word: pake	 gloss: use

D: word: paling	 gloss: most
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
